summary: Paul Merson and Andros Townsend have exchanged ongoing exchanges over Townsend’s England selection and performances: Merson initially questioned Townsend’s inclusion, then praised Townsend after he scored England’s equaliser against Italy, admitted he was wrong, and later made another dig when Townsend played late in Tottenham’s 0-0 draw with Burnley, continuing the back-and-forth on social media.

Chelsea have made a formal bid for Yoshinori Muto, a 22-year-old forward from FC Tokyo, with the possibility of him joining Stamford Bridge and then being loaned to Vitesse Arnhem next season; the offer, announced by FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane, is not linked to Chelsea's sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, and Muto recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has 11 Japan caps and 1 goal, and had a standout season with FC Tokyo, though he has not decided whether to join Chelsea.

A large Finnish study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers, with higher odds for repeated prescriptions and a stronger effect in boys; while not proving causation, researchers suggest antibiotics may alter gut bacteria, increasing appetite or freeing more food for the body, and stress the prudent use of antibiotics in infancy as a potential factor in the rising childhood obesity epidemic.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped on a manhole cover and fell during the Changing of the Guard in front of hundreds of tourists; he dropped his rifle and bearskin, quickly got up blushful as colleagues continued marching, while footage captured the moment and described the incident as likely caused by the metal protectors on his boot soles; the Guard is part of two detachments under the Captain of The Queen's Guard, not purely ceremonial, and the Ministry of Defence declined to comment.

A&E networks are remaking the 1977 miniseries Roots as an original, contemporary version to air in 2016 on A&E, Lifetime, and History, drawing more from Alex Haley’s novel and consulting scholars for authenticity; LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte originally, will co-executive produce, and the project aims to reach new generations while honoring the legacy of the original.

Former royal footman Christopher Lawler alleges that in January 1978 at Clarence House, palace aides forced him into an orgy by two younger men and a senior staff member, after he was accosted on his first shift; he escaped, was followed and threatened to stay silent, and he left the job that day. He later reported the incident after inquiries into past child-abuse cases, but his complaint was rebuffed for months before being referred to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide denied involvement; the Palace says it will cooperate with investigations, while police say they cannot comment while inquiries continue.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a rap video set to the Fresh Prince of Bel-Air theme; the clip, produced to share news with far-flung friends and family, shows them rapping about conceiving quickly, ending with a shot of their unborn baby’s sonogram, and has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, with the couple noting the video’s surprising popularity and considering a follow-up after learning the baby’s gender.

A gray dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions sale in Beverly Hills, part of a collection from James Tumblin that included over 150 items from the film; the jacket and full skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray and faded to light gray, was worn in several key scenes and was almost discarded before Tumblin bought it for $20, later promoting Hollywood memorabilia. The auction also featured other Gone With The Wind items, including Leigh’s straw hat ($52,500), Clark Gable’s Rhett Butler suit trousers and jacket ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland as Melanie Wilkes ($30,000). The film, based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, stars Leigh and Gable and marked Hattie McDaniel’s historic Oscar win.

A two-year-old boy fell 10–12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the railing; he was rescued by his parents, received treatment for minor bumps and a leg injury, and was listed in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center. Zoo officials said the cheetahs did not attack and footage suggests the child was dangled over the railing; eyewitnesses described shock and concern about how the fall occurred. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, and the exhibit was closed.

A fixed speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been redirected to face a resident’s house after fixed cameras across the West Midlands were decommissioned in 2013 due to obsolete technology, with around 300 cameras turned off and enforcement now relying on mobile units, motorway cameras, and patrols; Birmingham City Council says an engineer will check the camera and it may be removed, and there are no plans to include this Wellington Road camera in a limited digital pilot.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2-3, as part of the Jamaican team; he asserts he is fit, ready, and happy to run, and emphasizes Jamaica’s strong relay tradition and his priority to make the country proud, with the full team list to be announced soon.

Neymar and Barcelona teammate Dani Alves supported the club’s basketball team by attending El Clasico in the EuroLeague, where Barcelona beat Real Madrid 85-80, while Neymar’s sister Rafaella also joined them; separately, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates Stadium as Barcelona prepared to resume La Liga, with Neymar and Barca aiming at a treble as they faced Celta Vigo after the international break.

Italy is coping with a surge of desperate migrants from Africa and the Middle East trying to reach Europe, with 8,480 rescued from Friday to Monday and SOS calls from 20 boats on Monday; survivors describing a 550-person ship capsizing about 80 miles off the Libyan coast have raised fears that 400 migrants could be missing, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed such an incident or found evidence of a 550-person capsizing or any survivors or bodies; overall, there has been a recent rise in migrant boats and rescues by the Italian Coast Guard, with over 10,000 migrants arriving in Italy in the first three months of 2015 and about 2,000 rescued in the Channel of Sicily during the first weekend of April, many from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria using Libya as a transit country, and at least 480 migrants dying crossing the Mediterranean since the start of the year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels, with smugglers sometimes abandoning ships.

Arsene Wenger expresses happiness that Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, noting he’s unsure why Sanchez picked them but impressed by his immediate impact and qualities; Wenger suggests Liverpool’s interest may have influenced Suarez’s transfer discussions and acknowledges Sanchez’s rapid adaptation, work rate, and ability to revitalise the team, while downplaying links to Raheem Sterling and praising Brendan Rodgers’ squad development after Suarez’s departure.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling’s hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark), aiming to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, with tickets going on sale April 19 and the event broadcast on Sky Sports, as he seeks a new mark after finishing his Team Sky career and pursuing a world hour-record challenge that current holder Rohan Dennis set at 52.491 km; the record has recently seen attempts by Jens Voigt, Matthias Brandle, and Jack Bobridge, while Alex Dowsett plans his own May 2 attempt in Manchester, and Wiggins hopes to inspire a large crowd and possibly secure a place among a British Olympic medal tally in the future.

Serena Williams fought back to defeat Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in the Fed Cup play-off, improving her 8-0 career head-to-head, but the US were edged 3-2 after a doubles loss to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, leaving them relegated to World Group II. Williams described the match as an eye-opener, recognizing she was not as prepared for the claycourt season as she thought and must adapt from hard court tactics. With Williams’ singles win and other close results, the US narrowly missed forcing a stronger result, and captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need to work harder to return to the World Group next year.

River Plate expressed interest in signing Radamel Falcao, stating they dream of him and that the doors are open, despite the deal being complicated by his loan at Manchester United; Falcao previously played for River Plate early in his career and had a notable spell there, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances, and is now on loan at United where he has struggled, though he has recently been in good form for Colombia.

Ella Henderson, the X Factor finalist who rose to fame in 2012, has become the face of Batiste’s 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features her in various hairstyles against a blurred city backdrop, including a half-ponytail and glamorous outfits, and includes a TV ad tied to her single Mirror Man. The partnership was arranged by the MILES agency, with Henderson expressing enthusiasm about using the product regularly, and CEO Mark Hargreaves noting this as her first endorsement and anticipating an exciting 2015.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres after a confrontation on March 14, are shocked by a billboard in Kenosha, Wisconsin featuring Torres and his dog, erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association to thank the community for support; Siler’s family calls the billboard disrespectful and asks for it to be taken down, while the police association says it meant no offense and simply expressed gratitude for community support. The investigation into Siler’s death is ongoing, and Torres is on leave pending its outcome; separately, Torres previously shot a man armed with knives in another incident, which was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed and three militants were killed in clashes near Iran’s border with Pakistan in Negur; militants crossed from Pakistan, and Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility, opposing Iranian influence in Pakistan and targeting Shiites. Iran has asked Pakistan to detain surviving attackers, while Pakistan condemned the attack and said security agencies are investigating and will apprehend militants if they entered Pakistan.

The passage reports that Japan’s Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told the Diet that the Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object, though it does scramble jets and observe any suspicious objects; the discussion was prompted by lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who has a history in wrestling and politics, and who has raised questions about UFOs and research into alien visitors, while Inoki himself claims to have seen a UFO; the article notes past debates on space-invasion legality and Inoki’s public persona and activities.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalised after a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport collapsed, causing deep cuts to his leg and buttocks; he had initially stood on the rim to avoid contact with the seat, but the toilet shattered and he was left bleeding on the floor, requiring many stitches. He told friends he was squatting, then changed his story to police, possibly to avoid compensation, while authorities consider it an accident and remind that toilets are for sitting, not standing on.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested on multiple charges after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera in her bathroom that led investigators to him; police say he had sexually abused the girl for years, beginning when she was nine, and filmed her and other juveniles in the bathroom, including close-up footage of genitalia, with 41 videos captured over three to four years and 34 showing victims while showering, some uploaded to his computer for later viewing. Rebbie admitted filming several victims and purchased the camera to record the now-15-year-old girl, and a preliminary hearing is set for May 1 with bail at $500,000.

Photographer Yûki Aoyama’s new book, roughly translating to Daughter and Salaryman, features po-faced daughters photographed with their fathers as the dads, dressed in sharp suits, leap energetically into the air beside them. The series captures fathers normally serious in pose expressing a fun, heroic side, with some older dads showing pained expressions, while the daughters maintain a calm, smiling or neutral gaze. The photographs are taken in front of various Japanese landmarks, and the project has generated online interest for its curious concept.

The passage centers on Kevin Pietersen's potential return to England's international side after his rejoining Surrey ahead of the County Championship season, sparked by the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director; it describes Pietersen's reflective yet jovial mood during a Surrey team photo at the Kia Oval, his aim to force a comeback to the Test team following England's Ashes whitewash in Australia, and Surrey's upcoming start to their campaign including a MCCU match.

Ceahlau Piatra Neamt sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani left them 16th, six points from safety; Ze Maria, a former Brazil full-back with 25 caps, had been reinstated briefly the previous day by owner Angelo Massone but was dismissed again and will be replaced by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic, marking Ceahlau’s third coach of the season.

Nabil Dirar says Radamel Falcao regrets his failed loan move to Manchester United, even though he was unhappy in France; Falcao struggled at United after a serious knee injury and, with a £46million option to buy unlikely to be exercised, Dirar suggests he would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he did not feel well and would have had a chance to play in the Champions League.

Police are seeking the public’s help to identify a tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Union St, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt, and who fled with the till drawer and up to $1,500 in cash after throwing the cash register to the ground; there were no weapons reported, and the incident occurred around 12:30 pm on Saturday, with the owner’s daughter alarmed and a customer describing the robber as wearing a mask, and authorities urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested initially on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student after admitting to kissing him and letting him touch her breasts the previous year; she was released on bail and placed on administrative leave. Shortly after, a second 15-year-old pupil alleged that Granado had sex with him in her car on two consecutive January nights, leading to a second arrest and her booking into Irving County Jail, from which she posted $50,000 bail. School officials state privacy laws prevent details but confirm she is on administrative leave and not on campus, while investigators indicated the second case was prompted by information from within the school.

A video from Puerto Vallarta, Mexico shows a large American crocodile swimming through a marina with a dead dog in its jaws, which was held for hours and viewed over 500,000 times; the dog belonged to a local bike shop owner, and witnesses noted the crocodile's proximity to a river sanctuary nearby as well as the area’s mangroves and frequent crocodile sightings along the resort—drawing horror and mixed reactions from social media.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid relegation from the Premier League after a 2-0 loss to Southampton left them two points above the drop zone and with six games to salvage their season; he cites injuries to key players and a tough remaining run of fixtures against top teams as the main reasons for their struggles, while insisting a positive mindset and a few results could push them over the line.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from teaching for at least two years after a conduct panel found that he encouraged pupils to change their SATs answers and had altered some of their papers himself, leading the Department for Education to annul the entire school’s SAT results for 2014. Although Guffick claimed he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible, the panel ruled that no changes to exam scripts should be made outside test conditions and noted his actions were dishonest, though not fraudulent. He expressed remorse, and the decision, announced by acting Education Secretary Paul Heathcote, allows for a 28-day appeal to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper who rarely plays, is enjoying a happy personal life with his Swedish model wife Misse Beqiri, whom he married in a Mauritius beach wedding last year and with whom he has a son; despite limited on-pitch success at United and being third-choice behind De Gea and Valdes, he has been active off the pitch, sharing images and updates on Instagram, while Beqiri remains active as a model with Albanian roots and a large following.

The Sotheby’s auction of the glowing blue letters that hung over Yankee Stadium failed to attract bidders, with estimates of $300,000–$600,000 but no bids; only a Sotheby’s employee bid $260,000 to start, and the current owner, Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who bought the 10-foot-tall letters after the stadium’s 2008 final game, attended the auction and later noted he may have overestimated their size, while he had previously vowed to visit the winner if the letters sold to a U.S. bidder. Additionally, a late-60s Mets bullpen car was auctioned for $112,500, well above its $20,000–$30,000 estimate.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe of their professional responsibilities after a troublesome week, noting that elite athletes must be mindful of what they are seen doing and that neither Sterling nor Ibe will be disciplined for the incidents; Rodgers emphasized drawing a line under the matter as the team prepares for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa with Steven Gerrard available after his suspension, and he reflected on the painful close of campaigns in the past while stressing the importance of learning from losses on the road to improvement.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil returned to London after the international break, posted a relaxed photo with his dog, and ahead of a Premier League match against Liverpool he has been in strong form since returning from injury, contributing four assists and three goals since January; he defended his adjustment to English football, saying he fits perfectly and thrives on the frequent matches and demanding schedule.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu says there are no plans to replace Luis Enrique, and they are very happy with him, praising his performance as he nears the end of the season with Barça still capable of winning three trophies; Enrique, who signed a two-year deal last summer, is focused on La Liga and upcoming matches, with the team recently defeating Valencia 2-0 thanks to goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Liverpool midfielder Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract worth around £100,000-a-week, extending his deal to 2020 after reaching resolution with the club; he is one of several players to sign extensions under Brendan Rodgers, has been highly influential this season with 13 assists and seven goals, and could potentially be captain after Steven Gerrard’s departure.

Filipe Luis says he wants to stay at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him; he moved there from Chelsea last July on a three-year deal but has not become a regular left back at Stamford Bridge, while Atletico hope to gain leverage, and Chelsea, led by Jose Mourinho, aim to stay focused and win nine upcoming difficult Premier League games as they pursue the title, with Luis having recently featured for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile.

Nathan Hughes’s three-match ban for a knee to George North’s head while scoring for Northampton was overturned on appeal after criticism from Wasps and others, with the panel ruling the incident was accidental and there was no foul play or intent. North, who was knocked unconscious, required hospital care and was advised to take at least a month off due to concussion symptoms. Hughes had originally been suspended for recklessness for failing to prevent the collision and missed Wasps’ Champions Cup defeat to Toulon, but the appeal restored him to play immediately, though he did not feature in the next match and was unlikely to until April 26.

A fiery red sunset over Seattle was caused by smoke from Siberian wildfires, which spread across the Pacific Ocean and lingered in the Pacific Northwest; the smoke filtered out shorter wavelengths, allowing reds and oranges to dominate during sunrise and sunset, and air quality is expected to improve as the smoke dissipates.

A Missouri mother, Becky Schoenig, had her brand-new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway, but the car was found and returned after a tip from a man who recognized it; thieves had pimped the car with red rims and detailing, spray-painted accents, and a changed steering wheel, which Schoenig reacted to with humor on Facebook, posting photos and thanking the thieves while arranging professional cleaning for the cigarette and marijuana smell and planning a celebratory smoothie at her restaurant in honor of the man who located the car.

Manchester City face a potential £500,000 bonus loss per player if they fail to reach the Champions League group stages, as their incentivised contracts are tied to European qualification to remain within financial fair play rules; with around £12 million riding on achieving the European target, the team currently sits in fourth place and risks dropping out after a poor run that included a loss to Manchester United, under manager Manuel Pellegrini who acknowledged the season has deteriorated.

United Under-18s beat City Under-18s 1-0 in the "mini-derby" at Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring a curling free-kick and Marcus Rashford missing two chances; the match featured 13 English players, 10 from Manchester, and reflected a closer-to-senior experience under coach Paul McGuinness, who aligned three at the back with wingbacks. The win leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City’s injury-plagued side have now lost both play-off matches; the event showcased local talent with high skill and potential for future first-team opportunities.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap, noting Buffon’s enduring excellence and serving as an inspiration as Hart, who earned his 50th cap, continues to learn and aim to add more appearances for club and country.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery of online and mobile orders in 67 cities, with a nine percent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5 depending on distance and demand; the move follows prior reluctance to work with third-party delivery services and aligns Chipotle with other brands like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald’s, and Burger King exploring delivery, while noting celebrity sightings of Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio at Chipotle.

The parents of 8-year-old Martin Richard, who was killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing and whose sister was injured, are pleading against the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. After Tsarnaev was found guilty on all 30 charges, the Richards wrote in The Boston Globe that, while they acknowledge the heinous nature of the crimes, they favor the Department of Justice seeking life imprisonment without parole instead of pursuing the death penalty, hoping to spare their surviving children from years of appeals and ongoing pain. They emphasize they are expressing their personal views and want to close this chapter for their family, Boston, and the country.

A custom-built Boeing 747-8 has been converted into a luxury private home for a mystery billionaire, costing about £400 million over three years, and designed to seat dozens of guests despite the jet normally carrying up to 600 passengers. The interior includes a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen and private chef, multiple lounge areas, a master bedroom with an armchair and sofa, an aeroloft with eight beds, a conference/meeting room, an executive office with porthole windows, and a hotel-style main suite and guest rooms, all arranged to resemble a luxury hotel rather than a standard airplane cabin.

SpaceX launched a two-stage Falcon 9 with the Dragon cargo ship to the International Space Station, delivering over 4,300 pounds of supplies and planning a five-week stay for unloading before returning more than 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash; the mission included an unsuccessful attempt to land the rocket on a floating droneship, with the rocket tipping over on impact, though the Dragon docked successfully with the station, marking SpaceX’s sixth ISS mission and its effort to reuse rockets to greatly reduce space access costs.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at a new Elvis Presleys Graceland Wedding Chapel at the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas, with NBC's Today launching a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the “ultimate wedding” and accompanying prizes such as a free reception and hotel stay, airfare, and Elvis concert tickets; the winning couple, announced next Monday, will wed on April 23, with Priscilla emphasizing there will be no impersonators and the project forming part of a permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes they can challenge Manchester City for the Premier League title after a tough season, as he and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both reached 47 games this campaign in the 2-0 win over Newcastle United, a result that keeps Liverpool four points behind City as they push for a late run of form; Raheem Sterling opened the scoring and Joe Allen added a second, with Allen noting the goal helped despite not his best game, and he also reflected on a disputed potential penalty for Newcastle as Liverpool secured another vital win.

Roma ended a four-month winless run at home by beating Napoli in Serie A, with Miralem Pjanic scoring from a swift counter-attack and Morgan de Sanctis making multiple crucial saves in the second half to secure the 1-0 victory. The win moved Roma provisionally four points clear of Lazio and halted Napoli’s five-game winless streak. The match was played amid tight security following prior violence involving Napoli fans, with Roma missing injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, and Napoli lingering in fifth.

Doncaster Rovers endured a dull season in League One, sitting mid-table as they hosted Fleetwood Town in a goalless 0-0 draw at the Keepmoat Stadium; the media team struggled to compile highlights, producing a 27-second video focused on the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle, in a match that offered little excitement for fans.

A man named Roland Giroux interacts with his pet blood parrot cichlid by placing his hand inside the tank to stroke and massage the fish, which stays calm and responsive, swimming around and returning for more contact. He initially separated the fish from two bullying tankmates, fed it by hand, and observed that it becomes more sociable and frustrated if daily interaction stops. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlids, first bred in Taiwan around 1986, and Giroux records these affectionate interactions for his YouTube channel.

Ben Stokes is a fiery, highly talented but sometimes volatile player whose aggression and natural exuberance must be managed to maximize his impact for England. He has faced ups and downs, returned to the team, and is encouraged to channel his intensity into runs and wickets without being pigeon-holed. England aims to keep him in the side as much as possible, balance his aggressiveness with guidance from coach Peter Moores, and pair him with Mad Adil Rashid or Chris Jordan as needed, to allow both he and fellow talents to grow and contribute to the team.

Wales’ Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at Cardiff City Stadium on June 12 is a 33,000 sell-out, with both teams on 11 points in Group B and Belgium top on goal difference, while Wales’ 3-0 win over Israel has boosted hopes of automatic qualification; the FAW cited overwhelming demand and noted that the Wales squad preferred Cardiff City Stadium to the Millennium Stadium, which UEFA rules prevented from being used due to timing.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, with England the defending champions after last year’s final win on penalties against Holland; they qualified with a 100% record and are in Group D with Holland, Italy and the Republic of Ireland, opening against Italy in Burgas on May 7. The squad includes Chelsea’s Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal’s Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi (first call-up), and recalls for Liverpool’s Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, who missed the Elite Round. Goalkeepers are Paul Woolston and Will Huffer; defenders include Danny Collinge, Reece Oxford, Easah Suliman, James Yates, Jay DaSilva, and Tayo Edun; midfielders are Trent Arnold, Daniel Wright, Herbie Kane, Tom Davies, Marcus Edwards, Nathan Holland, and Chris Willock; forwards are Layton Ndukwu, Stephy Mavididi, and Ike Ugbo.

Manchester City are pursuing Evangelos Patoulidis, a highly rated 14-year-old playmaker from Anderlecht, who has drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. He previously declined Barcelona’s La Masia offer to focus on his studies, and City have discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock as they look to secure his future development.

A man has been arrested and bailed in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort whose body, showing head and neck injuries, was found strangled at a Fulham flat in southwest London at the end of March; police are appealing for anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death, and a 23-year-old man was questioned and asked to return for further questioning. Santillan, who had moved from Mexico and worked in London, Paris, and Miami, described herself online as visiting from Miami and loving London; authorities are investigating whether her profession is relevant while they pursue leads about who knew her in London in the days prior to her death.

A woman named Dawn, who has had seven miscarriages, accused a long-time friend and housemate, Jamie, of stealing £207 saved for her baby's gravestone, part of a £500 stone, after she confronted him and his girlfriend Carol; a lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle Show indicated Jamie did take the money, and he later confessed in a message to Dawn, blaming Carol, while Dawn expressed deep heartbreak and betrayal over the loss and the belated realization.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis, mostly women and children, with some ill or elderly, after being detained during ISIS’s takeover of northern Iraq; Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release, and the freed Yazidis were received by the Peshmerga and sent to Irbil. The passage also notes the Yazidis’ Kurdish descent, their pre-Islamic religious roots, the historic persecution they’ve faced, the 2014 Sinjar crisis that led to mass displacement and atrocities, and prior humanitarian relief and airstrikes by the international coalition.

Harry Kane, a breakout Tottenham striker who has broken into Roy Hodgson’s England side, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year. A new Copa90 animation featuring his goals and celebrations from the season—including long-range strikes against Chelsea, a header against Arsenal, and his England debut goal—premiered ahead of the awards ceremony, where he competes with Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher publicly backs Brendan Rodgers to continue as Liverpool manager despite a trophy drought and a looming top-four miss, arguing the club should not judge the future by one season or game; he believes Rodgers, the players, and the staff will push to win a trophy and return to the top four next season, stressing the need for the right signings and squad improvements, while highlighting his own philanthropic community work and his commitment to helping youngsters in Merseyside.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security detected it on an X-ray; he was frisked and given a thorough pat-down, which his father criticized as over-zealous, though the airport argued safety regulations prohibit items resembling prohibited objects, with hand luggage rules set by the Department of Transport. The family returned from Lanzarote with plans to replace the toy, and the airport apologized while offering to post the item back home.

A man in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory posted an online ad on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife, detailing his desires and requirements, including lifestyle preferences, perks, and finances. The 31-year-old, who calls himself Rich, described himself as athletic, tattooed, non-drinker, non-smoker, successful, with property and money, and a love of outdoors, travel, sports, and vehicles, while seeking a partner who loves pets, is reliable and loyal, good at home, physically fit, and “a princess when need to be.” The ad promised benefits such as a potential job-like arrangement, free gym membership, phones, a car, and laptops, and stated that “all reasonable offers will be considered,” with former partners rejected. The Daily Mail Australia attempted to contact him but was unsuccessful.

Former England managers Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren have backed FA chairman Greg Dyke’s push for radical changes to increase the proportion of home-grown players in top-flight clubs, including raising the minimum from eight to 12 and redefining home-grown status as having trained in England for three years before age 18. They warn England’s game will fall behind if the proposals are blocked and acknowledge England’s talent pool is shrinking, but point to signs of progress with young players like Barkley, Sterling, and Kane, while arguing that they are not being given sufficient opportunities.

Demelza Poldark has given birth to a baby daughter in the show’s latest episode, with Ross Poldark shown adoringly watching her. The article notes the implausible jump in the timeline—from an eight-month pregnancy to birth within minutes—mirroring prior storyline rapidities. It also highlights fans’ fascination with Ross as a charming, desirable lead who appears unavailable due to marriage, while fans comment on the pregnancy pacing in Poldark’s world.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged the team to stay focused on their own games and not be influenced by relegation rivals, insisting their future is in their own hands as they chase safety in the Premier League after back-to-back wins, including an injury-time winner by Jamie Vardy at West Brom, while acknowledging that results elsewhere can help only if Leicester continue to win and avoid getting swept up in optimistic assessments.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara completed the longest mammal migration on record, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia’s Sakhalin Island through the Pacific to Baja California, Mexico, a journey that surpassed previous records and involved visiting three major eastern gray whale breeding areas, suggesting she may be from the eastern population and prompting questions about the genetic distinction and conservation status of western gray whales.

A new stretch of coastline appeared overnight on Japan’s Hokkaido island along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, with about 1,000 feet of seabed rising up to 50 feet above sea level. The emergent land, roughly 1,000–1,640 feet long and about 100 feet wide, is believed to have been caused by a landslide triggered by melting ice and snow, rather than an earthquake, and appeared with no prior warning or tremors detectable by locals. Marine life remains attached to the land mass, and officials do not expect continued expansion.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied reports he will leave Paris Saint-Germain, stating he is happy at the club, loves PSG, the city, and his teammates, and wants to sign a new contract, even though he recently had a dispute with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea; while Dani Alves is linked with a move to PSG, it remains unclear if van der Wiel will stay or be sold.

Carlos Tevez has told Juventus he wishes to leave this summer to return to Boca Juniors, with Boca close to completing a deal but requiring Tevez to terminate his Juventus contract first; Juventus, while reluctant to lose their top scorer, have begun seeking potential replacements, and Tevez has consistently stated his intention to finish his career at Boca, though his move would depend on contract termination.

Bayern Munich routed Porto 6-1 to reach the Champions League semi-finals, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski, overturning a 3-1 deficit from the first leg; in the excitement, Pep Guardiola accidentally ripped a hole in his trousers, exposing his underwear, and joked he would buy new ones for the next match.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale, with three cars colliding. The first patients, a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain, were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital for minor injuries or further assessment. A man suffered hand lacerations, while two females escaped injury. The affected highway stretch was closed with diversions south of Fernvale, and emergency crews used hydraulic cutting gear to free a trapped person before Rescue 500 airlifted several patients.

Arsenal host Chelsea in a high-stakes Premier League clash as Mesut Ozil shows off his new Apple Watch ahead of the match, while Ozil is expected to start for Arsenal, who trail Chelsea by 10 points with six games left; Jack Wilshere has returned from injury and could boost Arsenal, though former player Ray Parlour warns that Wilshere’s fitness is crucial to his potential, drawing comparisons to past injuries of Abou Diaby.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby at Old Trafford, despite having sent off three players from United and City this season; Vincent Kompany’s suspension for a Euro 2016 qualifier means he cannot play against Wales in June, and Clattenburg has notably only sent off two players this season, both from United (Luke Shaw and Tyler Blackett), with a history of controversy but standing as a top Premier League official.

Bob Katter, a federal MP of Lebanese descent, accused the Queensland Government of assuming embattled MP Billy Gordon would quit after domestic violence accusations and a disclosure of his criminal past, saying they treated him like “a little black puppet on a string.” He defended his controversial wording as reflecting personal experiences with racism and explained he used the term to critique the government’s alleged manipulation, while asserting Gordon would retain independence and not become a puppet, in contrast to examples where independents aligned with the government. Gordon had been forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party, announced he would sit as an independent, and his case disrupted the Government’s slim majority.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old with cerebral palsy from Downers Grove, Illinois, uses dancing and motivational speaking to challenge stereotypes and inspire others, sharing videos that show she can do things like driving, attending college, and living like a typical teen, despite bullying and stigma, in order to counteract judgments and encourage others to look beyond disability.

Orlando City have shown interest in signing Javier Hernandez, viewing him as a major commercial addition due to their Latin-American fanbase, and have discussed a potential deal with the Mexico striker who is amid a difficult loan spell at Real Madrid; eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, are also linked as potential destinations with United seeking about £8 million, while Manchester United have separately offered a revised contract to teenage midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from PSG, Juventus, PSV, and Feyenoord after rejecting United’s initial offer.

A group of at least three people poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger and set it on fire at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles around 12:15am, while two passengers were inside; the driver, who got into an earlier argument with the suspects, and the others were not injured, but the car was completely burned. The grandmother said the fire followed an attempted carjacking, with the suspects pulling a gun and spraying gas; surveillance video is being used in the investigation, and the case is being treated as arson with the suspects still at large.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel of Lamoni, surrendered his state license after admitting to swapping sex for services and performing exorcisms on patients, with an agreement to refrain from applying for reinstatement for at least 10 years; he must show that the circumstances of the revocation no longer exist before resuming practice, while noting that he had previously received highly positive patient-satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com despite the misconduct, and that his listed practice addresses appear to be a residential home with limited recent work at the former practice.

The Pentagon accused a Russian SU-27 of dangerous and unprofessional behavior when it intercepted a U.S. RC-135U over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. crew calling the actions unsafe due to close proximity and high speed; Russia claimed the U.S. plane approached the border with its transponder off, a claim the U.S. disputes, and the two sides said they would lodge a diplomatic protest with Moscow. The incident follows a prior near-mandoff a year ago near the Sea of Okhotsk and highlights ongoing frequent encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft in Europe and in the region between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle, kept in a hard case secured to a truck safe, was stolen from the agent’s parked car in the Marriott Springhill Suites hotel lot in Salt Lake City overnight, just days before President Obama’s Utah visit. Police believe the thief gained entry by breaking the rear right window, used rope or a cable lock to seize the rifle case, and leveraged momentum from another vehicle to break the case handle; the window frame was torn from the door, suggesting the large case was ripped through the window. The gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen, and the rifle has not been recovered, though the bags were found at a Residence Inn nearby. The hotel lacked surveillance cameras, the rifle’s serial number is in the national crime database, and it’s unclear if the theft targeted the agent specifically.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in July 2012 in Red Hill, Canberra, with a sequence of violent acts including stomping on the head, cutting the throat, and stabbing him; forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa’s mind was likely compromised by dementia and alcohol both leading up to and during the attack, with mood fluctuations and a confused state evident from the crime scene clues and Costa’s 000 calls, while prosecutors argued Costa may have feigned memory loss, a claim Mullin disputed; Costa’s state of mind is central to the case because a verdict of not guilty could be reached if his unstable mindset at the time is proven.

Everton defeated Burnley 1-0 at Goodison Park with Romelu Lukaku unavailable, as Ross Barkley, instructed by manager Roberto Martinez to take a penalty, missed the spot-kick in the 10th minute after Barkley’s shot was saved by Burnley’s Tom Heaton; Barkley had taken the kick despite Leighton Baines’ presence and his confidence to let multiple players take penalties, a policy Martinez defended, noting Barkley showed responsibility and that Mirallas later scored the winning goal in the 29th minute.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom aboard the ms Ryndam on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, with authorities including the FBI investigating; Holland America Line said it appears to be a murder-suicide, the cabin was secured, and the ship is in San Juan, Puerto Rico after leaving Tampa.

Former Holland forward Patrick Kluivert has begun his coaching tenure with Curacao by guiding them to the second qualifying round of 2018 World Cup qualification, as they edged Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate after a 2-2 draw in the second leg, following a 2-1 win in Willemstad, with Charlton Vicento scoring late to force extra time in the first round; Curacao will face Cuba in June, and Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, previously played in a World Cup semi-final in 1998 and served as an assistant to Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso emphasized that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would feel as rewarding as winning a trophy, expressing confidence they can still avoid relegation despite being seven points from safety with eight games left. He notes the objective is to save the club, compares the challenge to winning a cup, and remains hopeful and committed, believing his teammates can win matches and that Leicester has a chance to stay up. The piece also recalls Cambiasso’s illustrious career with Inter Milan, Real Madrid, and other clubs, his decision to join Leicester on a one-year deal, and his contentment with life in the East Midlands.

A 23-year-old mother of two is at risk of being barred from seeing her children by her mother, Debbie, who has been caring for the kids after social services intervened. Debbie accuses Gemma of frequent drinking, partying, using the legal high MKat, stealing (including an iPad and money in the past), and neglecting her children, which led Debbie to take over parenting. Gemma disputes some accusations but admits past theft from her mother. Debbie, who appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show, says she may ban Gemma from the home and from seeing the grandchildren, stating she cannot trust her to care for them and that the children, who call Gemma “mum,” deserve better.

Chelsea forward Eden Hazard scored to put Manchester United 1-0 at Stamford Bridge, with pundits convinced a foul occurred in the build-up as John Terry challenged Radamel Falcao from behind; the loose ball then led to Cesc Fabregas feeding Oscar and Hazard’s composed finish. Sky analysts Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp and Graeme Souness agreed at half-time that Terry’s rough tackle—described as a forearm/elbow in the back of Falcao’s head—should have been a foul and stopped play, with Souness and Redknapp noting it as a foul and that Falcao could have done more to stay up, while Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao.

Hillary Scott of Lady Antebellum was on a tour bus that caught fire on an Interstate 30 in Texas; everyone aboard evacuated safely after a rear tire blew out and the bus ignited, with the back lounge destroyed except for Scott’s Bible. The remaining band members were not traveling on that bus, and the group was scheduled to perform at the ACM Awards in Arlington, Texas.

A Scottish scientist, Dr Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University, envisions space-based lasers harvesting sunlight with orbiting mirrors to convert it into laser energy that can be transmitted to Earth to boost solar panels and power homes, potentially making solar power viable in places like Scotland and aiding disaster recovery; initial trials in Scotland were promising and aim to move to Portugal, though the beams would be far less powerful than in science fiction, and there is acknowledgment of potential weaponization concerns and the need to consider who controls the satellites.

A predatory convicted paedophile, Stephen Munden, 54, described as having a fanatical obsession with young girls, vanished from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, after being detained under a hospital order for sexually touching a three-year-old girl; he may have shaved his beard, is about 5ft 8in, heavy-built, with dark hair, and is being sought in a manhunt as he suffers from learning difficulties and autism, with authorities urging anyone seen since yesterday evening or who knows his whereabouts to come forward.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay more than $2.6 million in gifts to the Sterling family after Rochelle Sterling sued, alleging Stiviano targeted wealthy older men and that Donald Sterling used the couple’s money to lavish her with luxury cars and a $1.8 million duplex, among other items; Stiviano countered that gifts were not improper, while Shelly Sterling celebrated the decision as a recovery of ill-begotten funds and a precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from recipients.

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal’s transfer activity, urging them to sign four key players—a goalkeeper, a centre back, a holding midfielder, and a top-quality striker—to have a chance at winning the Premier League. Speaking as a Sky Sports pundit after a goalless draw with Chelsea, he highlighted Olivier Giroud as insufficient to lead the team to the title and compared Arsenal’s spines unfavorably with Chelsea’s recent signings (Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, Costa). He stressed the need for a strong competitive edge within the squad and stated Arsenal, currently third, must make significant additions to win the title.

A young woman describes the lasting, severe impact of years of abuse by Maurice Van Ryn, the Bega Cheese boss, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child. She explains she didn’t recognize the abuse as wrong, feared stigma and exposure after his arrest, has struggled with depression and self-harm since age 14, and has attempted suicide, while expressing fear about future relationships and how his actions will affect her with men.

Arsenal teenager Serge Gnabry is nearing a return from a serious knee injury that sidelined him for over a year, having recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under-21s against Reading and reporting that he is feeling better and progressing well as he eyes the next game.

A 23-year-old graduate accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after running from a taxi in Penarth, South Wales, to avoid paying the fare, leaping from a fence in the dark and falling about 70 feet to his death at the base of a cliff. The inquest heard he and two friends had insufficient money to pay the fare and attempted to reach Penarth by taxi, then fled when the plan failed; Phillips became disoriented in the dark and was unaware of the dangerous drop beyond the fence, with the coroner recording an accidental death.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer’s passport delays received little to no compensation, while HM Passport Office posted a £42.3 million surplus and paid managers up to £3,500 in bonuses; ministers refused a blanket refund for those who paid extra for fast-track services or missed trips. The backlog grew as 3.6 million Britons applied for documents, with over half a million passports stuck by mid-June, and only 2,191 compensation applications approved between April last year and January this year, totaling £203,066 (average £92.68). Ministers rejected broader compensation claims, citing potential precedents, despite widespread failure and individual stories of losses, such as holidaymakers who paid for upgrades or missed trips.

A timewarp three-bedroom semi-detached house in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s, is up for auction with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000. It retains original features and fixtures such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint-green and black bathroom, original kitchen cupboards, a wood-panelled hall, a brick open-fire, dated kitchen fittings, and even vintage tins on a hallway shelf, all alongside some upgrades like double glazing. The exterior is plain, but the interior is a collector’s paradise with period decor including ships-and-arms stained glass and armorial glass in living-room windows, and it’s seen as a potential family home for antiques enthusiasts, though renovation costs may deter developers. The auction is scheduled for April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers’ starter mid-2012 after Smith’s concussion, remained the starter for the rest of the season, and led the team to its first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before moving to Texas and later to San Francisco; Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to NY 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through the NBCUniversal division NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London and Essex, formed Blur with Graham Coxon after meeting in school, leading to the band's debut Leisure in 1991 and later global success with their self-titled 2001 album; drawing on diverse influences from alternative rock to hip hop and electronica, Albarn also released his solo debut Everyday Robots in 2014, co-produced by Richard Russell and featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and sampling rants by Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, and houses many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their debut EP, Broken (1992).
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter born on August 14, 1964, who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

The passage describes two adaptations of the Bob Lee Swagger story: the Shooter (2007 film), in which Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger is framed for murder by a rogue private military company unit, and the Shooter (TV series), in which Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile, is drawn back into action upon learning of a plot to kill the president.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that originally ran on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for seven deaths—Abigail Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Parent, Sharon Tate Polanski, Jay Sebring, and Leno and Rosemary LaBianca—carried out by his followers under his direction, and he also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea; after charges, recordings of songs written and performed by him were released commercially.

Sean Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist born on August 17, 1960. He began on television in Little House on the Prairie, directed by his father, then made his film debut in Taps (1981) and gained attention in 1980s crime dramas such as At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito’s Way. He rose to prominence as a leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Oscar nomination and a Berlin Best Actor win, followed by additional nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001). He won Best Actor Oscars for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George Bradman, known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer born in 1908 and considered the greatest batsman of all time; after retiring, he remained influential for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has held top executive roles in major record labels, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a division of Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007); he began his career with Greta in 1990, helped co-found Rage in 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha, and by 2016 was playing in Prophets of Rage with various artists.

The Millers is a multi-camera CBS sitcom that aired from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015, totaling 34 episodes over two seasons, and was canceled by CBS on November 14, 2014, four episodes into the second season.

Ann Richards was an American politician who served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995, having previously gained national attention as Texas state treasurer and delivering the keynote at the 1988 Democratic National Convention; a Democrat, she was the second female Texas governor, known for her outspoken feminism and memorable one-liners, and she lost re-election in 1994 to George W. Bush.
Drake Bell released an independent EP in 2011 titled A Reminder.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh (born Jeanette Helen Morrison; July 6, 1927 – October 3, 2004) was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a leading role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states independent of Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is a loosely defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where many aircraft and ships are said to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers’ starter in the 2012 season after Smith’s concussion, leading the team to its first Super Bowl appearance since 1994 (a loss to the Baltimore Ravens) and, in 2013, helping the 49ers reach the NFC Championship before losing to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a sponsored, nonpersonal form of marketing communication that promotes a product, service, or idea. It differs from personal selling because the message is not directed at a specific individual. It is conveyed through mass media, including traditional outlets like newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, outdoor ads, and direct mail, as well as newer platforms such as search results, blogs, websites, or text messages.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts written by Noël Coward, which was adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira, Chalkidice, who joined Plato’s Academy at age 17 or 18 and stayed until about 37. After Plato’s death, he left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, tutored Alexander the Great starting in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur born February 16, 1982. He invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and serves as the CEO of music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson was a point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, drafted first overall in 1979, won a championship and Finals MVP in his rookie year and four more titles in the 1980s, retired for four years after player protests and returned in 1996 to play 32 games at age 36 before retiring again; outside basketball, he has many business interests, was named one of America's most influential Black businessmen by Ebony in 2009, and he has been a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass, who have released three albums—Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012)—and first gained popularity in 1997 after starring in their eponymous TV series and touring with major rock acts.

James VI and I reigned as James VI of Scotland from 1567 and as James I of England and Ireland from 1603, ruling Scotland and England in a personal union while each remained sovereign with its own parliaments and laws; he advocated a single parliament for both kingdoms, achieved most in Scotland but faced major difficulties and conflicts with Parliament in England, including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605.

Big Brother 2017 (Big Brother 18) is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, a British actor and voice-over artist renowned for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since 2000 and known for his Geordie accent.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in eastern Germany, bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, and Poland and the Czech Republic. It covers 18,413 km2, is the tenth largest by area and sixth in population with about 4 million people. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is also a region known for quality wine, being one of Germany’s northernmost wine regions along with Saale-Unstrut, and the only two wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball park in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati, United States, and “In the End” is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career by releasing "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, featuring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah, with supporting roles by Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar. Released on 1 July 1994, it became the second highest grossing Indian film of 1994 and earned nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Initially Divya Bharti was considered for the female lead and completed many scenes, but after her death Raveena Tandon was cast as her replacement. The film is also remembered for its chart-topping songs.
Hourglass is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is from singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.
Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, best known for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and directing Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond spy film in the series and the seventh and final one to star Roger Moore as MI6 agent James Bond.

Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, comprising most of western New Guinea, and was formerly known as Irian Jaya (and before that West Irian or Irian Barat), encompassing all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though there were unconfirmed rumors that his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez started her music career in 1999 with On the 6 and the hit If You Had My Love, then in 2001 she released J.Lo while The Wedding Planner released, making her the first woman to have a number-one album and film in the same week. Her personal life, including a high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck after a second divorce, heavily influenced her 2002 album This Is Me... Then, which coincided with the underwhelming release of Gigli in 2003. She later married Marc Anthony, had twins in 2008, and after a quieter period returned to prominence in 2011 as a judge on American Idol, powered by her commercially successful single On the Floor, one of the best-selling singles of all time.

A working animal is a domesticated animal kept by humans and trained to perform tasks, including assistance animals like guide dogs, animals used for traction such as draft horses or logging elephants, and animals trained to milking or herding; occasionally wild animals are tamed and trained for work, but they are usually less trustworthy and reliable than true domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, while Top Latin Albums is a Billboard chart considered the leading music chart for Spanish-language full-length albums in the U.S., and Regional Mexican Albums is a weekly Billboard chart focusing on that genre in the United States.

Vedam (Chant) is a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring a ensemble cast including Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II (MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring stars such as Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.
Sancho Panza is a fictional squire in Cervantes’ 1605 novel Don Quixote, who comments throughout the work with humor, irony, and earthy wit, known as “sanchismos.”
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 science fiction action comedy film directed by Ron Underwood, a joint Australian-American production starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role.
Ibsen was present at the world premiere of Hedda Gabler, which took place on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., commonly known as Juve, is a professional Italian football club from Turin, Piedmont, founded in 1897 by young Torinese students including first president Eugenio Canfari and Enrico. It is the second oldest active club of its kind in Italy after Genoa's 1893 football section, traditionally wears black and white stripes since 1903, and has played home matches at several grounds, most recently the Juventus Stadium with a 41,507 capacity.

Viola Davis played supporting and minor roles in several films and TV series in the late 1990s and early 2000s, including Kate & Leopold (2001), Far from Heaven (2002), and Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress, widely regarded as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer and known as "The Queen of Porn." She began acting in erotic videos in 1993 after previously working as a stripper and glamor model.
The passage states that the New Orleans Pelicans are an NBA team that competes in the Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by JCP/NWA and later WCW, originally on closed-circuit TV and later on pay-per-view; from the 1960s to the 1980s JCP held major events on Thanksgiving and Christmas at Greensboro Coliseum, with Starrcade (1985) as the third annual event under the NWA banner, Starrcade (1987) the fifth annual under the NWA banner, and Starrcade (1997) the fifteenth annual Starrcade PPV event.
Jack Ryan Falahee is an American actor, born February 20, 1989, known for his roles as Connor Walsh on How to Get Away with Murder and Benjamin Stringfellow on Mercy Street.

Seohyun, a South Korean singer and actress born Seo Ju-hyun (June 28, 1991), debuted with Girls' Generation in 2007 (and later its subgroup TTS), becoming part of a highly popular and best-selling K-pop group; she has also pursued acting in stage musicals such as Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind, and Mamma Mia, and launched her solo career with the mini album Do n’t Say No on January 17, 2017, becoming the third Girls' Generation member to debut solo.

The passage describes the Apple II as an 8-bit home computer and one of the first highly successful mass-produced microcomputers, designed mainly by Steve Wozniak with Steve Jobs overseeing the case design and Rod Holt handling the power supply; the Apple II series, sometimes rendered as Apple ] [ or Apple / /, is a family of home computers introduced in 1977, also among the early successful text command microcomputers, manufactured by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). It also provides a brief note on Stephen Gary Wozniak, known as Woz, an American inventor, engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and co-founder of Apple Inc.

A&E (formerly Arts & Entertainment Network) is an American cable and satellite TV channel that serves as the flagship property of A&E Networks, a joint venture between the Hearst Corporation and Disney—ABC Television Group, each holding a 50% ownership stake.

L.A. Reid has held top leadership roles at multiple major labels, including chairman/CEO of Epic Records (Sony Music), president/CEO of Arista Records, and chairman/CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group; he also founded Hitco Music Publishing and co-founded LaFace Records.
Veeram is a 2014 Indian Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, while Veeram (Valour) is a 2016 Indian epic historical drama film written and directed by Jayaraj.

Home for the Holidays refers to two different American films: a 1972 made-for-television horror film directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling, and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan, which premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972; and a 1995 film featuring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam is an American actor, comedian, and writer, born on April 1, 1982.
The Sex Factor is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster in which eight men and eight women compete to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer, born on July 15, 1973.
Island Records is a British-American record label that operates as a division of Universal Music Group (UMG).
Sikkim is a northeastern state of India.
Christa McAuliffe became a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire in 1983.
Ronald Bilius "Ron" Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder, produced by his brother Jack Binder, and distributed by Columbia Pictures; it was released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick is an American football quarterback born on November 3, 1987, who is currently a free agent.

Anne Rice is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her writing career with Interview with the Vampire (1976) while in California and wrote sequels in the 1980s. Although her early reception was mixed, she gained greater critical and reader popularity in the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years, from 1961 until his death in 2002 at age 60.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 at the 2010 Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey; historically, its early 20th-century population consisted mainly of European immigrants, and a city is defined as a large and permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film The Canyons, an American erotic thriller-drama directed by Paul Schrader, and it was critically derided.

The Lincoln–Douglas Debates, also called The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic candidate, held in seven towns across Illinois.

Homer is the ancient Greek name given to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two central works of ancient Greek literature, while The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper born on April 8, 1974, was murdered on February 2, 2013, by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave is a four-piece rock band formed by Chris Cornell (ex-Soundgarden) with Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk; Wilk is also known for his roles in Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000, 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07), and later joined Prophets of Rage in 2016. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, features Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model who is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records; she released her first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, in 2010, a critically acclaimed concept album that serves as a sequel to her first EP and was released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. About 55% of its undergraduates and 60% of its students overall come from Mississippi, 23% are minorities, and international students come from 90 nations.
The series was renewed in July 2016 for a six-episode second season, which is scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr held multiple high offices: he was elected to the New York State Assembly twice (1784–1785, 1798–1799), served as New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), was a U.S. Senator from New York (1791–1797), and ultimately became vice president.

Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed for the Soviet space program by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s, intended to launch Soyuz spacecraft as part of the Soviet human spaceflight program; it started with eight unmanned test flights followed by the first 19 manned launches, succeeded the Voskhod program, and remains in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine broke up after tensions over the band's direction led to de la Rocha leaving, with he pursuing a solo career while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell; Audioslave released three albums before disbanding in 2007, the same year Rage reunited and performed at Coachella for the first time in seven years, and continuing their discography with Renegades, their fourth studio album released on December 5, 2000 by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float, market-weighted stock index of 30 well-established, financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange; Tata Motors is one such constituent and is listed on the BSE, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam is officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, located on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with about 92.7 million people making it the 14th-most-populous country and ninth in Asia. It is bordered by China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand (across the Gulf of Thailand), and across the South China Sea by the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, its economy has grown rapidly, and in 2011 it topped the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam remains one of the world’s four remaining one-party socialist states that officially espouse communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India and subsequent execution at age 23 made him a folk hero, and he became a popular folk hero after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut with Dangal, a 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film about wrestling, directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI of Scotland became James I of England and Ireland after the 1603 union of the crowns, ruling both kingdoms in personal union until his death in 1625. Although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, judiciary, and laws, he advocated a single parliament for both kingdoms and faced numerous parliamentary difficulties during his English reign.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand actress known for originating a core role on Shortland Street and for starring in UK/Australian productions, including Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, roles in The Cult, Legend of the Seeker, Separation City, Rake, Underbelly: Razor as Kate Leigh, and most recently Bea Smith in Wentworth, a role she played for four years until 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer renowned for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade stars in and co-stars with roles in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2; Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress, born on August 16, 1958.
