Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but was commercially successful, debuting at No. 1 on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week copies and totaling 757,000 copies sold in the US, becoming Gaga’s second consecutive US No. 1, and it sold 2.3 million copies worldwide in 2013.
John Frusciante released Stadium Arcadium in 2006 as the Chili Peppers' fifth and final album with him, and he left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism; she remains controversial but is lauded as one of Britain's greatest and most influential politicians, though debates about Thatcherism continue.

Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author, who has also established himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns on a variety of topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, in addition to acting roles, has narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the Valencian Community in Spain and the third largest city in the country, with about 800,000 residents in its administrative center and a metropolitan population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million.
Buffy Summers is portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
Make It or Break It was announced on April 26, 2012 that the series would end, with the third season serving as the final season; the series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is an interdisciplinary field combining linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to enable computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It encompasses methods for voice user interfaces, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and direct voice input for aircraft, and its progress is evidenced by a surge in academic research and widespread industry adoption of deep learning techniques by major companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and former comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International, serving as its chairman starting in 1970. The convention began in 1970 as the Golden State Comic Book Convention, founded by San Diegans including Shel Dorf, Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

Dubuisson shot 67 to tie for the lead at 16 under par, while McIlroy also shot 67 to reach 15 under, chasing his first title since May and aiming for a third Race to Dubai title with three events left; McIlroy, who had an eagle on the 12th and overcame earlier bogeys after two three-putts, described his rounds as consistently within himself, and noted a potential even lower round tomorrow. Also mentioned: Kiradech Aphibarnrat at 16 under with Dubuisson; McIlroy’s ankle injury history and recent comebacks; English players Chris Wood and Richard Bland sitting at -13 and -12 respectively in the standings.

Sheikh Ali Salman argues that meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government to offer concrete solutions and openness to reform, with Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa seen as a reformist in a divided court; hardliners prefer to oppose dialogue despite an agreement between the government and six opposition groups. He notes past moments when a seven-point plan for a constitutional monarchy was almost reached before GCC troops intervened, and stresses the need for public UK pressure and stronger US engagement under John Kerry. al-Wefaq urges peaceful demonstrations, calls for the release of 13 opposition leaders jailed on torture-tainted evidence, and contends that excluding these figures from dialogue would derail any potential process.

Christopher Hogwood died at his Cambridge home after a months-long illness; his funeral will be private with a memorial to follow. A leading figure in the early-music movement, he founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and led it for about 30 years, producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments. His notable recordings include Handel's Messiah (1980) with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, acclaimed by BBC Music Magazine. Educated at Cambridge and later studying with notable early-music figures, he began as a keyboardist and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and helped found the Early Music Consort of London. Hogwood also served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, taught at Harvard, was honorary professor at Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell. Colleagues praised his generosity, ambassadorial role for historically informed performance, and the enduring legacy he left for the AAM and the broader early-music movement.

In the year ending 31 March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims (murders and culpable homicides), down from the previous year and the lowest in a 12-month period since 1976, with only one 2015-16 case unresolved as of 31 March 2016. A sharp instrument was the most common method, causing 51% of homicides (29 cases), and 26 of these 29 involved a knife. Most accused had unknown alcohol/drugs status, but 31% (20 people) were identified as under the influence. The government emphasized ongoing efforts to reduce violence through education, enforcement, and support for communities, while noting the need for resources for law enforcement and the courts. Opposition figures cautioned against taking downward trends at face value due to past revisions, and pointed to contemporaneous concerns about rising sexual crime and a recent uptick in violent crime. The 2014-15 victim count was 59, later revised to 62 after reclassification.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 at Sunderland, becoming the first team this season to lose to the Black Cats in the Premier League; Dan Gosling gave Bournemouth the lead, but Sunderland replied with goals from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty, and Bournemouth failed to equalise despite numerous chances, even after Steven Pienaar was sent off, with Gary Howe noting the team had created plenty of chances but couldn’t convert.

The passage discusses Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott’s “stop the boats” policy to deter deaths at sea by detaining and offshore processing of migrants arriving by boat, a policy described by the New York Times as brutal and inhumane, with calls that it may be unlawful and contrary to Australia’s welcoming tradition; Abbott argued that stopping illegal boats has stopped drownings, mentioning the image of Alan Kurdi as a motivator, while also controversially comparing IS to Nazis, a remark that drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups who distinguished between terrorism and genocide, and Abbott later defended his stance but said he was not ranking evil.

The United States blamed Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks on civilians in Aleppo and suspended bilateral talks with Russia that aimed to sustain a ceasefire, after accusing Moscow of failing to ensure Syrian regime adherence and of targeting critical infrastructure and hindering humanitarian aid; Russia denied involvement and accused Washington of not fulfilling its humanitarian commitments and of failing to separate jihadist groups from the moderate opposition. As a result, the US withdrew personnel anticipated for a joint implementation center and scheduled talks in Geneva to coordinate air strikes against jihadists were called off, though the two sides would continue to discuss counter-terrorism operations to avoid clashes, amid heavy bombardment and a growing civilian catastrophe in eastern Aleppo where hundreds have died and about 250,000 people are trapped.

Downing Street backed Policy Exchange’s proposal that selling high-value, vacant social homes could raise about £4.5bn a year to fund 80,000–170,000 new social homes, potentially reducing the waiting list and boosting construction, while critics warn it would push poorer families out of expensive areas and fracture communities; Labour argues for more targeted use of housing stock and a broader build programme funded by other means.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his Swansea home amid a measles outbreak that has reached 942 cases; an examination could not determine if measles was the main cause of death, and an inquest will be opened and adjourned for further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma, developed a full-body rash after discharge, and sought care from an out-of-hours GP; he was found dead the next morning. Public Health Wales confirmed measles but said additional tests were needed to determine the cause of death, and the family, including his three-year-old vaccinated daughter, were unsure how he contracted measles as no close family member was affected.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Whitehaven, has been charged by Cumbria Police with a historical offence involving a boy under 16, alleged to have occurred in 2001. He is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 after a competitive match where Guiseley initially led through Jake Lawlor, Gateshead’s Wes York equalized in the second half, and both sides made substitutions; yellow cards were shown to Gus Mafuta and Simon Walton.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands to increase stadium capacity as an alternative to a delayed new stadium at Ashton Vale; majority shareholder Steve Lansdown said work would begin after approving the project and signing the section 106 agreement, with a six-week judicial review period, aiming to start redevelopment in May if there is no judicial review by March, and the plan has already been approved by Bristol City Council.

Cuadrilla paused fracking after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, and will review data from the British Geological Survey before deciding whether to resume. The BGS linked a similar April quake to Poulton-le-Fylde and noted that injecting pressurized fluids for shale gas can fracture rock and trigger earthquakes, with the latest event occurring about 2 km from the Preese Hall site at a depth around 2 km. Cuadrilla’s CEO said operations were halted for consultation with authorities and experts, with a multi-week analysis expected before actions are taken. The BGS is also monitoring fracking as a precaution, while debates continue over regulation and environmental concerns associated with shale gas.

Angus Carpenter, a Liverpool street performer with over 30 years in the city, was found guilty on one count of fraud out of three after a two-day Liverpool Crown Court trial, for using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015 to give the impression he was collecting money for the charity; he was cleared on the other two counts, he claimed he was busking and had previously piped for the charity, the banner was a tribute to the victims and he was a familiar match-day figure, with the Hillsborough Campaign's chairman saying Carpenter had permission to display the banner but not to collect funds, and he will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town beat Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with Grant Ward opening the scoring, Luke Varney setting up the second via a goalkeeping error, and Tom Lawrence adding a late third; Ipswich dominated after the early stages, while QPR offered little in attack, failed to capitalize on chances, and dropped to 15th as Ipswich rose to 14th.

Wells, 23, impressed in the T20 Blast last season with 373 runs at 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66, and he praised the club’s direction and elite-performance environment created by the coaches, which motivates the players to be part of it.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a 29-12 victory over third-placed Chinnor for their second consecutive win, led by Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, with the front row and front five making 70-plus tackles to drive the win; coach Churcher notes that the team has a favorable run of eight upcoming games against lower-ranked sides and the leaders, but emphasizes there is room for improvement and that the performance against Chinnor, while strong emotionally, was not complete, so they must build on last weekend to avoid it being a waste of time.

Police allege 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, raped a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat, with him identified as the man by five arrested suspects; he was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata after fleeing to Bangladesh following CCTV identification, and a tip led to his capture as authorities pursued eight identified suspects in the attack, during which money was stolen and the convent building ransacked, triggering widespread protests across India.

The passage describes an interactive video featuring Robert Opie from the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, which explains why consumer purchasing changes—highlighting the impact of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports on what is sold and what UK consumers prefer. It also notes shifts in ownership and ranking among major UK brands, mentions that the video may not work on older browsers, offers a non-interactive version, and provides links to additional information in non-interactive format.

Two recent scams targeted residents in Sandyhills and Stranraer, where callers claiming to be from BT technical support asked to remotely access victims’ computers and ultimately stole money; one incident occurred on September 15 and the other seven days later. PC Siobhan Pellett highlighted how easily attackers can access a victim’s computer and the substantial sums involved, urging people to avoid giving banking details or account numbers over the phone, noting that banks and reputable businesses never request this information.

Duffy, 37, has joined Featherstone, the third-placed Championship side, on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions and will coach them for their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers; Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell praised his coaching and noted his difficult but successful stint at Swinton, where he was replaced by former assistant Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, with a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, were dispatched to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday after a rider suffered head injuries and became very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand; she was treated at the scene and then flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference at Geneva and the ITU decided to allocate a radio frequency for satellite-based automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) to enable real-time global flight tracking, addressing gaps in the current system highlighted by the disappearance of MH370, which left about 70% of airspace uncovered; the ICAO plans to adopt new tracking guidelines by November 2016 requiring aircraft to report their position at least every 15 minutes (or more in emergencies).

A missing boy, Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five in 2002, has been found and is now 18, living with his father Bobby Hernandez (53) in Cleveland, Ohio. The FBI got a tip on 30 October that the teenager could be the long-missing child after difficulties applying for college; they, with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed his identity. His mother has been notified of his recovery. Bobby Hernandez is also charged with tampering with records in Ohio to obtain a driver’s license in 2012 and is jailed in Cuyahoga County with a $250,000 bail. Authorities had suspected around the time of the disappearance that the father might be involved; a missing persons database indicates Hernandez claimed he was taking his son to preschool in August 2002 before fleeing.

Firefighters spent days at a Duncan Street site after a blaze on 2 March that disrupted train services and travel. The Environment Agency revoked the environmental permit for Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited and will revoke its ability to operate from the site from 7 August, though the company can appeal. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited the site nine times in the past year, reporting the operators, Asset and Land Group, as broadly compliant with fire safety laws; concerns were raised in February about potential impacts on nearby residents, transport, and the environment, leading to joint visits with the EA. The EA stated it has decided to revoke the environmental permit, and the company must still remove all waste, with the cause of the fire remaining undetermined.

A Just Russia proposed two bills linked to Ukraine: one would loosen rules to allow Russia to absorb a disintegrating neighboring territory if its people express a clear will to join Russia, while the other would fast-track Russian citizenship for Ukrainians, removing tax, residency, financial, and Ukrainian-citizenship requirements and enabling passport applications at Russian missions before August 1, with citizenship in about two months. The bills reference Crimea, Sevastopol, and Crimea’s Russian-leaning populace, drawing on parallels to Russia’s actions in Abkhazia and South Ossetia after 2008, and note prominent Russian figures promoting the fast-track passport plan.

McLaren has fallen from its former dominance, now languishing in a lowly fourth or third place grid position despite its storied history of 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers’ and eight constructors’ titles, and world champions like Fernando Alonso; the slump began in 2013 due to chassis issues, with current problems centered on the Honda power unit, contrasting with its peak eras when Honda, then Mercedes, powered them to glory. The piece traces McLaren’s long cycle of triumph and decline, including legendary partnerships with Honda and Mercedes, scandals in 2007 and 2009, and leadership under Ron Dennis, who has steered the team through cycles of dominance and hardship; Dennis remains optimistic that improvement is imminent and that Alonso’s return signals a path back to championships, though for now the team’s fate hinges on restoring engine reliability and performance with Honda.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old from Everton, was shot in the head and chest and died in hospital after being found badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January; police have three men in custody and are continuing investigations, including searching for a silver VW Polo seen leaving the scene and reviewing CCTV footage from nearby areas as witnesses who may have information are urged to come forward.

The passage discusses how Christmas can be celebrated online and through digital media, highlighting five approaches: Everyday Church Online offering global virtual services with live sermons and chat; Guardians of Ancora, a free-to-play game for kids that embeds Bible stories and Christmas-themed quests; viral digital nativity stories and ads like The Digital Story of Nativity and Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle; Manga Messiah and other manga-based Bible storytelling reaching diverse languages and audiences; and the broader use of social media platforms (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) to share Gospel messages and connect with communities, with reassuring notes on accessibility and modern outreach.

The eight-day Ebbw Vale inquiry examines a bid to take over 250 hectares of common land, with backers offering about 320 hectares of replacement land. Experts give conflicting views on potential habitat and plant-life damage, while Natural Resources Wales finds it difficult to deem the replacement land equal in value but does not oppose the development overall. The developers’ ecology report claims a net biodiversity gain due to nearby habitat enhancements, a point opposed by the Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, and Welsh government ministers will have the final say on whether the plans proceed.

Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a report by Novaya Gazeta as insulting to Chechen faith and dignity, calling for retribution against journalists, while the paper defended its reporting on mass detentions, alleged killings, and widespread homophobia in Chechnya, where detainees—mostly openly or perceived gay men—reported torture near Grozny, a claim denied by Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman; the LGBT Network corroborated abuses and urged Russian authorities to act, with plans to pursue ICC action if prosecutions are not pursued, as the paper and rights groups warn of ongoing repression, state involvement, and threats against journalists and dissidents.

Investing Solutions, a company that rents properties to single homeless men, has since 2002 worked with Fresh Start Housing, a charity set up by Samir Patel in 2010, to place clients in private-sector housing across seven London boroughs. The arrangement, based in the same South London storage-unit building, reportedly passes most rents to private landlords while charging housing benefit for each person housed, inflating total benefits paid relative to rent. Critics say this benefits the agency financially and constitutes a problematic practice, though both entities deny illegality and assert clients are referred to private landlords and that Fresh StartHousing helps ex-offenders and aims to reduce poverty and distress. In one example, £2,114 monthly housing benefit was claimed for two tenants, while the landlord received £1,150, yielding significant gross profit; nearly half of Investing Solutions’ funding over two years came from Wandsworth Council. Fresh Start claims to have housed hundreds of homeless people since its founding, while authorities emphasize safeguarding public funds and private-sector housing inspections.

London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13 as GB led for most of the early game before the Netherlands overtook them in the final 10 minutes, with Worthy De Jong scoring 18 for the Dutch and Gordon hitting three early in the fourth to help restore GB’s lead before the Dutch pulled away 71-60. GB coach Joe Prunty emphasized finishing plays and balanced effort on both ends as they prepare for their Eurobasket qualifying campaign starting in Hungary, noting Gordon’s solid showing after joining the team and the need for improved intensity in the closing stages.

The passage describes Connor McGregor submitting a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission ahead of the 154-pound bout with Floyd Mayweather, with the NAC to debate allowing 8-ounce gloves (instead of the standard 10-ounce) on August 16 after considering safety and regulatory factors. It notes that lighter gloves could increase punch severity, that McGregor had previously used 4-ounce gloves in UFC, and that Mayweather had suggested 8-ounce gloves, though no waiver had been filed at that time. NAC executive director Bob Bennett explained their health-first policy and that any deviation requires decisive approval, highlighting McGregor’s advantages such as youth, height, chin, and sparring assessments including Nate Diaz’s sparring results. The piece also mentions McGregor’s boxing debut potential, the mixed reactions from boxing figures, and Bennett’s decision process supported by video evidence and the recommendation to hire a boxing referee, which led to Joe Cortez’s involvement.

The article reflects on the decline and closure of Fleet Street as the heart of British journalism, recounting its historic role as the hub of major newspapers, the iconic, alcohol-soaked culture, and the iconic figures who worked there; it notes the move of papers to Wapping in 1986, the end of the old printing era, and the gradual disappearance of the street’s newspaper offices, while highlighting personal memories of reporters from the Sunday Post and other outlets, the transition to freelance work, and the enduring sense of historical significance despite the industry’s transformation.

J.K. Rowling described how her social media experience as a famous woman includes facing abuse and bullying, but she believes in standing up to bullies and not silencing political critique. She noted her personal line had been crossed by abusive comments and that she had blocked some users she suspected supported the SNP. She referenced previous political donations—£1m to the Scottish independence No campaign and the same amount to the Labour Party—along with discussions with SNP supporters and being called a traitor for her views. The SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats, becoming the UK’s third largest party.

The Edinburgh study found that deprived children are twice as likely as their better-off peers to face police action for the same crime, poverty increases violence risk for both genders, and a police history is the strongest predictor of not being in education, employment, or training by age 18, with poorer youths about five times more likely to be placed under statutory supervision. Extreme poverty correlates with higher victimization and offending, and gender is a strong violence predictor, with boys more likely to commit violence and poorer girls more likely than affluent peers to be involved in violent crime. The research, tracking 4,300 youths since 1998, indicates that contact with the juvenile justice system can perpetuate poverty-related violence, and that crime remains highly concentrated in the most deprived communities despite overall crime declines, raising questions about inequality and policy effectiveness. Scotland’s government touts a 41-year low in recorded crime and increased policing, while maintaining investments alleged to counter poverty and welfare cuts.

Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm in connection with the stabbing death of Karl Haugh in Kilkee’s Marian Estate, where three men allegedly entered the estate looking for Haugh, a fight ensued among Walsh and others, during which Haugh was stabbed in the back and later died at Limerick University Hospital; weapons including a knife blade and handle were recovered at the scene, two other men were arrested but released without charge with files being prepared for the DPP, and Walsh was remanded in custody until 14 August.

Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted a claim alleging Tom Elliott harassed and shot people during his UDR service; the tweet was deleted within an hour, and Flanagan apologized admitting the tweet was untrue and without foundation, with a court case determining compensation pending while an insurer declined to cover costs; Elliott stated he was vindicated and disappointed by the delay.

Hawick Knitwear, with over 230 staff, has boosted production to 9,500 sweaters per week (from about 7,500) to meet rising demand for both its private-label clients and its own Hawick Knitwear-branded range, which launched in January and has exceeded expectations; the firm, dating back to 1874 and now led by Benny Hartop since last November, serves European markets (Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, Spain) and outside-Europe markets (USA, Canada, Mexico, Japan), and attributes the growth to strong sales and dedicated staff.

A man, Brian Wright, 55, from Kempston, told Luton Crown Court that he struck Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady, with his VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School and then failed to stop, while blaming the sun blinding him and claiming he cannot recall whether the traffic lights were red or green; Blackburn, who was escorting children across the road, suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care, and Wright expressed remorse as the trial continued.

The passage describes a NATO-led anti-submarine warfare exercise, Dynamic Mongoose, aimed at countering the growing threat of Russian submarines. A German U-boat, U33, with commander Kai Nicklesdorf, attempts to evade 10 NATO ships including HMS Portland while targeting the USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker, illustrating how elusive submarines can be. On the Vicksburg, crews monitor sonar and sensors, acknowledging the difficulty of detecting submarines, especially since Russian subs can remain hidden for extended periods and may operate quietly near shores. The exercise features anti-submarine aircraft, helicopters, and for the first time underwater drones deployed by a NATO research vessel to enhance tracking, highlighting advances in technology and persistent surveillance, though submarines remain a challenging unseen threat. The report emphasizes a significant UK vulnerability: Britain no longer operates maritime patrol aircraft, relying on allies for airborne ASW eyes, which could leave the UK exposed and underlines the need to address this gap in forthcoming defense reviews.

UN officials warn that South Sudan’s crisis could amount to genocide and ethnic cleansing as violence since July has driven about 340,000 people to flee across the border to Uganda, the fastest-growing refugee surge this year. The conflict, rooted in a Dinka–Nuer power struggle, has expanded to hit Equatoria civilians with killing, rape, and ethnic targeting, prompting families to cross on foot to Busia and refugee centers where aid agencies provide land, shelter, and crops within 36 hours. Uganda has taken in nearly a million refugees, including many children, and while the country is managing with aid support, authorities warn that the scale is straining resources such as water provision, and call on the international community to press South Sudan’s leaders to stop the massacre of civilians from both sides.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super-middleweight title; a former footballer turned professional boxer in 2013, he has eight wins and one draw in nine fights, is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie, and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage describes a £33m project funded as part of a £330m nationwide NHS facilities investment to replace Bridgwater Community Hospital with a new facility that will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray services, and space for mobile scanners. The current 1813-built hospital is cramped and aging, with maintenance and comfort issues, and the new build is expected to improve patient well-being and care. The project’s remaining balance will be covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust, with land at Bowers Lane (subject to planning permission) identified for the site, and completion aimed for autumn 2014. Other recent replacements of Somerset’s community hospitals and related developments, including the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital, are noted as context, along with endorsements from local clinicians about the benefits of integrated, one-stop-shop care.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city centre, where he had been in or near a black Mercedes; he was found with a chest wound, armed police sealed off the area, and he died later at Northern General Hospital. Local residents said he belonged to a nearby family whose relatives were gathering for a celebration when the attack occurred, and many neighbors tried to help after hearing the shot. The incident follows several recent shootings in Sheffield, primarily in the north of the city, including a 25-year-old man seriously injured in Shiregreen, an elderly couple targeted when shots were fired through their living room window in Southey Green (believed to be mistaken identity), and January shootings at houses on the same street in High Green.

The passage describes various hacker collectives involved in the Ukraine conflict, including Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International, who claim to act as independent activists. It details their tactics—DDoS attacks, hijacking CCTV and printers, targeting rebel funding, and leaking or exposing data from both sides. It notes Cyber Troops’ alleged data dumps and actions like hijacking networks used by Russian authorities, while Cyber Berkut conducts pro-Ukrainian propaganda, hacks Ukrainian government sites, and claims to have disrupted electronic systems and leaked materials. Anonymous International is portrayed as a Kremlin-focused group publishing leaked Russian documents, with unclear access methods. The piece also mentions officials’ denials of using hacker-gained data for artillery targeting and references media coverage and access restrictions on these groups.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick and veteran MSP Duncan McNeil shed tears as they bid farewell to the parliament, with former SNP leader and ex-first minister Alex Salmond also giving a valedictory address marking his departure ahead of the May election; Salmond reiterated Scotland’s diversity rather than division, welcomed the Scotland Bill’s transfer of powers to Holyrood while criticizing it for not meeting pledges from the referendum campaign, and urged public service with strong purpose, while McNeil urged Holyrood to learn from Westminster about accountability, scrutiny, and opposition. Former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also announced her departure, joking about missing interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is launching a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales, seeking input from pensioners, their families and friends, care providers, staff and public bodies to develop recommendations that address both good and poor care and reflect the day-to-day realities of living in care; the review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships and the environment, with the aim of ensuring accountability and delivering improved quality of life, though Care Forum Wales notes the advisory panel lacks a provider expert with direct care-home experience.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported pre-tax profit of £3.5m for the year to June 2016, up £800,000, despite turnover dipping to just over £100m; international sales rose in Europe and new markets, while the Turriff company continues to manufacture and supply feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry, and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland offering farming and rural products. The company cautions that agriculture faces unpredictable conditions, highlighting recent challenges and the uncertain impact of Brexit, though the board believes the group will be well positioned to meet future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon, and a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Detectives are treating the death as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker), warning the public not to approach him. Det Con Insp Martin Brunning said the inquiry is in its early stages and officers are appealing for information and all Crimestoppers contacts, with additional patrols in the area to reassure residents. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with greying collar-length hair, of average build, and believed to be wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or shorts, and a blue/white checked short-sleeved shirt; similar descriptions have been circulated to the public.

David Lipton of the IMF warned of a weakening global economy and a delicate juncture, following weaker-than-expected Chinese trade data (exports down 25% year-over-year). The IMF expects to downgrade its global growth forecast from 3.4% in its upcoming April update, noting ongoing negative implications for businesses that rely on China's growth.

Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July to acknowledge ongoing problems and gather feedback, as the council orders an auditors’ review of the project after a troubled start to the new vessel. Since its late launch on 14 May, the chain ferry has broken down, run aground, and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues, with cars damaged during boarding and alighting. Shopkeeper Angie Booth and other local businesses face about six months of lost trade, raising questions about compensation, which Transport councillor Ian Ward says is under discussion. He also noted the project is a prototype with teething problems, acknowledged electrical issues that have been fixed, that ramp extensions were approved to prevent vehicles from scraping concrete, and that groundings related to seamanship have been resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man who was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigations.

Matching Models in London, described as an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people, sparked controversy with ads seeking a personal assistant with a specific “classic look” and a “sexy female driver” for high salaries, prompting the EHRC to call the practices appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women. Campaigners argued the ads reflect sexism and likely violate equality law, with 2010 Equality Act protections against discrimination based on age, disability, race, religion, marital status, and other characteristics; employers must justify essential clothing size requirements. The agency defends its stance by noting first impressions matter, but EHRC and employment lawyers warn such language can constitute discrimination and invite complaints or tribunals, potentially leading to unlimited compensation. The agency’s founder insists client appearance matters, while EHRC and advocates urge moving away from sexist hiring practices; Matching Models’ clients reportedly include major brands like MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, Renault F1, and Harrods, with the founder noting a global placement history and MTV’s preference for models with tattoos or piercings.

A gunman named Mahesh, an office assistant at the Pragati Residential School’s hostel in Bangalore, barged into 18-year-old Gautami’s room and shot her in the head, then seriously injured another student, Sirisha, before being arrested after a manhunt; incidents of gun crime in Indian schools are rare, and while India has strict gun laws, feuds are sometimes settled with firearms, with a previous incident in 2007 of a 14-year-old shot dead by two peers near Delhi.

Glaad’s Where We Are on TV study covering June 2016 to May 2017 counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters across scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series, with transgender characters rising from seven to 16, but more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith; the report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast TV, driven by shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder, and while Glaad’s president acknowledged progress, she said the numbers are only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will step down as his candidacy faced opposition and widespread calls for deselection. The controversy centers on a substantial loan from the borough council to Northampton Town FC, issued when he was leader, to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land, with about £10.25m reportedly missing and a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. The BBC reported millions in public money loaned to the club appeared to have vanished, and Mackintosh denied wrongdoing. Meanwhile, a majority of his party’s local executive council indicated they would vote to deselect him, and although he previously intended to stand again, he stated it is the right time for constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, 37, was charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault after firing a rifle into a car full of teenagers leaving a Balch Springs party in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards; the officer was fired for policy violations, and four other teens, including Edwards’ brothers, were charged as well. The incident arose from responding to underage drinking, and body-camera footage later showed the car driving away, not toward the officer as initially claimed. A Dallas County DA spokesperson stated that justice is being pursued, and Oliver faces a potential 5 to 99 years in prison if convicted; he remains free on bail, and commentary from Edwards family’s lawyer noted the historical rarity of police murder convictions in Texas.

The passage discusses Melania Trump and Barron Trump potentially moving to the White House “very soon” and the mixed public reaction, noting that only two First Ladies in U.S. history did not reside in the White House with their presidents. It recalls historical precedents of First Ladies’ involvement and living arrangements, remarks that Barron’s schooling is a priority for Mrs. Trump, and outlines varying expectations of the First Lady’s role—from ceremonial hostess to active public advocate—highlighting past examples like Eleanor Roosevelt and Michelle Obama, and recent patterns in balancing family life with public duties, including examples from Chelsea Clinton and the Obama and Clinton administrations. It also mentions potential future involvement by Ivanka Trump and the ongoing idea that the White House can reflect a family's choices and privacy needs.

A 72-year-old man who was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness prompted an investigation into the initial police response to his call. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been instructed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to examine that response, with a report of the findings to be submitted to COPFS in due course. Police Scotland says it is fully engaging with the investigation. The man died on 27 October this year.

The weather service issued a yellow wind warning, with gusts up to 75 mph (120 km/h) possible, especially west of the mountains, and an unusual easterly direction expected to amplify impacts, likely causing travel disruption on roads and at sea across Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree felled by overnight winds closed a main route into Menai Bridge on Anglesey, and Telford Road was expected to remain closed for most of Monday for cleanup work.

The Giants opened with a short-handed goal from Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen tied the game for the Panthers; in the second period Mike Forney's powerplay breakaway gave Nottingham a 2-1 lead, Andy Bohmback equalised, Mike Radja added a goal from an acute angle, James Desmarais then made it 4-2, and David Ling pulled one back for Nottingham as the teams prepare for a rematch in their second game of the double-header, with Nottingham leading the league on 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers (27) and Belfast (25).

World champion Lewis Hamilton started from the back after a first-lap crash that damaged his car and forced five pit stops, while Nico Rosberg led early and later outpaced rivals to win as Hamilton fought back amid heavy Ferrari pressure. Ferrari’s Sebastian Vettel finished second after a first-lap collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to fifth behind Red Bulls Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo; Raikkonen passed Hamilton late aided by Ferrari choosing soft tires for the final stint. The race featured a dramatic first-lap incident cluster prompting a safety car, with Ricciardo briefly leading before a puncture and Rosberg then controlling proceedings after the restart. Hamilton’s progress was hampered by damage from the Nasr collision and aerodynamic losses, and despite attacking with different tire strategies, he could not overturn a significant points gap to Rosberg.

Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly came out as gay in an interview with Die Zeit, describing the move as advancing a topic long ignored in German football. The announcement drew widespread support from teammates, former players, football administrators, clubs (including Bayern Munich), politicians, and media, who called it courageous and a significant step toward reducing homophobia and breaking a long-standing taboo. While some, like Philipp Lahm in 2011, had previously suggested caution about coming out, others praised the gesture as progress, with optimism that sexuality will become less of an issue in football.

Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season as Brighton & Hove Albion secured promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years, and with his contract expiring this summer he hopes to sign a new deal to stay in the top flight; he notes his strong impact and consistent performances, reflects on his previous loan spell and subsequent permanent move, and says if an offer is on the table they can work it out, as the team eyes the Premier League title with a four-point lead over Newcastle and two matches remaining.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1 after Jamille Matt put Blackpool ahead early, Kurtis Guthrie equalised for Colchester before half-time, and a late red card for Sean Murray and multiple chances and saves throughout the second half kept the score level, with Blackpool failing to convert several opportunities and Colchester finishing with ten men.

A 29-year-old player (Reid) made 37 appearances for Colchester United (the Sky Blues) last season, during which they were relegated from League One; he has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston and could debut for Colchester in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa, while Colchester opened the season with a 3-1 loss at Accrington.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament spurred a push for a permanent memorial to police officers, with the UK Police Memorial Trust seeking £1.5m for construction at the National Memorial Arboretum to honour over 1,400 officers and staff who have died on duty; Sir Hugh Orde emphasized creating a national place for remembrance and recognition of policing sacrifices, while the memorial at Alrewas, Staffordshire, will feature a brass leaf-cutter screen with families receiving engraved leaf-shaped keepsakes, supported by £1m from the government toward a total £4m cost and expected completion by 2019.

Manchester United extended their lead to 15 points at the top with a 1-0 win at Sunderland, reaching 25 wins from 30 games and highlighting a strong run after 54 of 54 possible points from their last 18 Premier League matches; Ferguson stressed focusing on the next game, a derby against Manchester City, and noted potential changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and De Gea, with Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley not starting but Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez available, while he credited the victory to determined defending and courage amid a tough second half from Sunderland.

Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011 and, according to Mr Schmidt, they are paying what is legally required; he says taxes should not be considered optional and that if UK tax laws change, Google will comply, paying more if rates rise and less if they fall, leaving the political decision to the democracy. The piece notes criticism of multinational tax avoidance, mentions Margaret Hodge’s call for a new committee to oversee major firms’ tax affairs (potentially hearing evidence in secret), and references EU efforts for automatic tax information exchange; it also cites Google's chairman’s views that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity and risk occur, not where products are consumed, and his call for international tax reform and a clearer, simpler system.

NHS Improvement reported that the NHS needs faster progress in cutting agency staffing costs, aiming to reduce last year’s £3.6bn agency bill by £1bn in the current year, with a cap introduced in October limiting charges to no more than 55% above normal rates (except for senior managers). While the cap has saved about £600m, overall progress is only “promising” and still leaves the NHS short, with trusts about 10% behind target and uncertainty remaining about other pay-bill spending. The regulator will publish league tables of trusts’ agency spending and will collect data on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust amid concerns over inflated rates, including examples of doctors quoted at much higher rates than the cap. NHS Improvement emphasized the need to curb the costly reliance on agency staff, noting the NHS does not have funds to continue such expenditures.

The passage describes Longford Town Centre as a symbol of Ireland’s economic collapse, though local traders like Matt O’Brien report a tentative recovery driven by diversification into areas such as childrenswear and dress hire, after a heavy downturn with staff reductions; while Fianna Fáil criticizes the government’s handling of the midlands—arguing that funds should go to broadband rather than water meters—others claim government efforts, including a Center Parcs tourism development that could create about 1,000 jobs, will boost the area though it still awaits planning permission, and local voices call for further measures like free street parking to attract customers, reflecting a nascent recovery with more needed to sustain growth.

Eight teams compete in a double round-robin format, finishing on 29 May in the same stadium, with the top four advancing to the play-offs; up-to-date scores and fixtures are available on BBC Sport. Leading run-scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267), De Villiers (249); most sixes: Warner (12), De Villiers (12), Kohli (8); highest scores: De Kock (108), Warner (90*), Gambhir (90*); most wickets: McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8), Rahman (7). Four current or former England players participate: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The passage then lists match fixtures and timings from 25 April to 29 May, including qualifiers (25 May, 27 May) and the final (29 May).

The passage notes that plastic carrier bags have increased by 200 million since 2013 and pose environmental problems because many are not recyclable and end up in rubbish dumps or rivers; from October, England will charge 5p per bag to encourage reuse, a policy already implemented in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland where bag usage has decreased, and campaigners hope the English charge will reduce litter and benefit the environment.

Part of a school roof was ripped off in Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd, as hundreds of Welsh homes experienced power cuts amid strong winds that caused train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and several event and attraction closures; a yellow wind warning was in force, with Mona on Anglesey recording the highest gusts, Irish Ferries cancelling six Holyhead–Dublin sailings, Arriva Trains Wales warning of delays, and the National Trust closing Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle, with some restrictions later eased and Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip postponed to Tuesday.

The passage reports that an unnamed actor is "super excited" to join a film, aims to put a different spin on his role, but does not specify the part. He will reunite with director Ryan Coogler, and he looks forward to working with Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, who are notable for their Oscar and superhero roles, respectively. The article notes Jordan’s previous work as the Human Torch in Fantastic Four and Nyong'o’s role as Maz Kanata in Star Wars, and states that Black Panther will be released in February 2018.

The passage describes the restoration and planned use of the Alexandra Palace theatre and BBC studios, founded in 1875, with aims to host theatrical performances, cinema, comedy, and live music, and to reopen in 2018 if funds are raised. The project forms part of a larger east wing renovation to turn Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination, including the glazed east court for public exhibitions. Funding commitments include £18.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund and £6.8m from Haringey Council, with the entire east wing costing £26.6m and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust tasked with raising the final £1m by summer 2017. The theatre has been unused for decades but retains much of its original décor and stage machinery and was originally built to showcase opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player aged 30 at the time, earned 61 England caps after debuting in 2009, was part of two World Cups and two European Championships but played only three minutes at Euro 2016, and announced a decision in support of common sense for future success with Sam Allardyce, players, staff, and supporters; he also holds the England Under-21 cap record with 46 appearances since 2004, and scored his sole international goal in England's 5-0 win over Moldova during 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

A Newfoundland family escaped a house fire after 11-year-old David woke his mother and sister, with David being the only one awake and warning them as flames rapidly engulfed the home; the fire, started by rubbish burned in a wood stove, destroyed the house and claimed their dog and cats, while the smoke alarm did not go off, but the community has since donated clothing, shoes, and a bike for David and his family.

West Ham United, once valued at £105m when Sullivan and Gold acquired a majority stake in 2010, are now owned by the two businessmen who together hold over 85% of the club. Reports have linked the energy drinks company with a potential £200m offer and nearby takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups since the club’s move to London Stadium. Although Sullivan indicated last year that a minority share sale could help clear debts, he and Gold intend for the ownership to be passed on to their children.

The article covers Jillian Bell at an LA event noting its blend of fan-voted awards and film promotion, with The Fault in Our Stars winning best movie and Shailene Woodley sweeping multiple honors (best female performance, Trailblazer Award, best kiss) and paying tribute to John Green; other winners include Bradley Cooper (best male performance for American Sniper), Channing Tatum (best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street), Meryl Streep (best villain for Into the Woods), along with Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne; Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with a statement about his family, and Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award amid a high-energy moments and a preview of upcoming releases like Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Ultron.

St Mirren have loaned Cammy Smith from Dundee United to United (initially confusing in text, but context indicates St Mirren views him as a good acquisition), with Smith, 21, who has five goals this season and was Aberdeen-born, having previously made 89 appearances for Aberdeen since 2012 and earning Scotland Under-21 caps; boss Jack Ross said Smith is a mature, good player who will add attacking options, and St Mirren, the Championship bottom side, are set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council announced that the weather is warm enough for its Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes, aiming to fill about 145 potholes each day over the next four months. The plan also includes extra staff to repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and to clear debris from gutters.

The incident occurred on EnQuest’s Thistle platform near Shetland in December 2016, where six Wood Group workers removing pipework were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) without proper PPE, prompting concern over potential cancer risk; EnQuest says exposure was under 1% of the reportable level, they notified HSE, and thereafter implemented additional precautionary steps, while Wood Group conducted medical assessments and supported a joint investigation, stressing safety as a top priority; workers and unions criticized the handling and duty of care, with calls for openness and accountability, though HSE stated the incident was not reportable under current regulations and no separate investigation was undertaken.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a Hindu sculpture of Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted dealing in looted Indian antiquities; the piece was believed stolen from a Tamil Nadu Shiva temple, and the return followed a May official request from the Archaeological Survey of India after discussions with the Indian authorities, with ACM noting the manager’s confession of trafficking looted objects and stating it will seek compensation for fraud, though there is no conclusive proof the piece was stolen.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck Garfagnana, 35 km north of Lucca, at a depth of 15.5 km, felt in Milan, Florence, Bologna and Modena, with no immediate injuries or damage reported though power and phone lines were interrupted and some areas evacuated; aftershocks followed, and the region has experienced stronger quakes in May, including a 6.0 quake causing significant damage, while Italy continues recovery from the 2009 L’Aquila disaster and related judicial actions over assurances given before that quake.
A fruit remains on the plant and is not ripe yet; Austin Grant from Sheffield overcame doubts about South Yorkshire’s climate and is now seeing positive results, expressing his joy.

Rockstar has delayed GTA V’s release to 24 March from 27 January to allow extra testing and polish, stating the decision is in the game’s and fans’ best interests, while confirming online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC release; PC version will feature higher detail, with Los Santos and Blaine County in 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K, and support for up to triple monitor setups, and minimum PC specs have been published as anticipation builds for the launch.

A 76-year-old artist, who won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for Squint (19) at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery, was previously shortlisted in 1991 and has made the prize longlist on three other occasions; judge Ansel Krut praised Squint (19) as extraordinary yet difficult to view, noting its depiction of a leper squint—holes in medieval churches that allowed undesirables to glimpse services—within a broader series of works. The painting, about 7 feet tall, was entered partly due to its manageable size and familiarity to the artist, who plans to spend the prize money on materials like stretches, canvas, and high-quality paints. Krut described the piece as a tone-poem that reveals a subtle, minimal language and a broad, sympathetic field once engaged with, and both he and the prize’s establishment expressed strong satisfaction with the selection in Britain’s oldest art biennial, which has past winners such as Hockney and Doig, with Sir Peter Blake now its patron.

Two Turkish pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked with firearms early Thursday, causing shattered windows but no casualties; four masked assailants targeted the Yeni Safak building and police found numerous spent bullet casings at both sites, with firefighters extinguishing a blaze and authorities cordoning off the areas as they search for the attackers.

A 24-year-old, contracted with Stags, will join on a free transfer after Marcus Bignot reached an agreement; he spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances, and will officially join on 1 January as Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Wenger is focusing on his job while commenting on Gareth Southgate’s England role, noting Southgate’s experience and competency and that he has a chance to prove himself; Wenger also says Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract and is surprised by transfer speculation, Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury, and Arsenal’s club contract discussions and potential interest from Barcelona and Manchester City are mentioned.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday; Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement that ends the dispute over seafarers’ pay by transferring contracted services back to Serco Northlink from next month. The issue centered on some crew on two freight boats paid under £4 per hour, with Seatruck operating the vessels Hellier and Hildasay under contract to Serco Northlink but arguing minimum wage didn’t apply to non-UK residents. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge and backdate pay, but Seatruck declined. The new arrangement, pending final financial and regulatory details, will ensure all crew are paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink has held the six-year £243m Northern Isles contract since 2012, which covers three ferries and two cargo boats on a heavily subsidised route.

A man named Jamie Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault after intervening in a confrontation at Rockley Park in Poole between Ken Dickie and Mitchell’s mother, Samantha Mitchell; Dickie later died in hospital six days after the incident. Jamie Mitchell and his mother also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying to police about the events. The two had initially claimed Dickie pushed Samantha Mitchell, but Jamie later said he tried to separate them, describing it as a “tragic accident.” Jamie Mitchell and Samantha Mitchell were from Apple Close, and the verdict in Winchester Crown Court followed their involvement in a night of heavy drinking at the park’s bar; sentencing was set for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the prolific songwriter behind hits for Heatwave and Michael Jackson (including Off The Wall and Thriller tracks Rock With You, Burn This Disco Out, Baby Be Mine, The Lady in My Life), died in London at 66 after a brief cancer battle; he was known for his low profile, started in Heatwave, later wrote for Jackson’s albums with Quincy Jones, won a Grammy for Birdland, was nominated for Oscars for The Color Purple soundtrack, and his work was lauded by figures like Nile Rodgers, Michael Jackson’s sister LaToya, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan, and BBC figures for its enduring impact.

A research team, including Swansea University’s Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, has discovered more than 450 ancient geometric geoglyphs in Acre, western Brazilian Amazon, dating back up to about 2,000 years. The features, formed by long-vanished ditched enclosures and concealed beneath rainforest until deforestation, are unlikely to be villages or defensive sites and may have served sporadic ritual purposes, possibly akin to Stonehenge or Maya pyramids. Analyses of soil, phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon isotopes suggest the geoglyphs were built among taller vegetation and not visible above the canopy, raising questions about their function. The researchers challenge the view of pristine Amazonia before European contact, showing 6,000 years of human-influenced biodiversity and suggesting ancient people reshaped forests, rather than dramatically burning them, by cultivating economically valuable trees such as palms, effectively creating a prehistoric supermarket of forest products with lasting agroforestry impacts.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked world No. 12 after winning the Japan Open, defeated Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round in Shanghai. He said he was tired and a bit bored, explaining fatigue from recent travel and poor sleep after Japan, noting the long ride to the Qi Zhong Stadium and the burden of the trip. He had previously been fined for a foul-mouthed outburst at the Shanghai Masters last year, which he described as a “circus.”

The passage reports that scientists and charities advocate extending the HPV vaccine beyond girls to boys in Wales to help prevent head and neck cancers, noting rising cases and a demographic shift toward younger, often non-smokers, with about three-quarters being men and an average age of 55. It mentions that 85% of girls in Wales had been vaccinated in 2008, and that the Welsh government is awaiting recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before deciding on changes to the programme. Charities and groups are urging proactive rollout for boys and emphasizing the vaccine’s role in reducing cancer burden.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Lothian pupil, battled a rare gamma delta T-cell lymphoma and documented his cancer journey on a Facebook page, Jak’s Journey, which his family helped run; after his cancer spread in January, doctors stopped treatment, but he remained optimistic and continued sharing moments from his life, including meeting football stars, visits to hospitals, and his love of Rangers FC. He attended a school prom briefly before feeling unwell and later died, with his family honoring him at events and fundraising for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, as plans for a charity football match and further donations followed his passing.

Egypt beat Uganda 1-0 thanks to Abdallah El Said’s late goal after Mohamed Salah set him up, keeping Egypt in contention for top spot in Group D as Ghana had already qualified with a 1-0 win over Mali; Uganda were eliminated despite a spirited second-half display, with Joseph Ochaya’s offside goal disallowed and Egypt narrowly unable to break through until El Said’s stoppage-time finish following Salah’s composure and assist.

Lancashire County Council plans to use land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new site, following a Network Rail study of both locations and a site near the Concourse shopping centre; Skelmersdale’s original station closed in 1956, and the council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, envisions two direct trains to Liverpool per hour, with the preferred site chosen for its size, potential for expansion, and strong road connectivity, and the authority will begin acquiring the necessary land.
Police found plants in an "elaborate grow house" during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, and a man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old German woman of Kurdish origin was found severely injured, dragged by the neck through several streets in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, and transported to a specialist clinic after emergency surgery. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Münder, surrendered to authorities and is in custody. The motive for the attack is unclear. Police have secured the area and are seeking witnesses.

Women and men ask for pay rises at similar rates, but men are 25% more likely to receive one when they ask. The study analyzed full-time workers to remove part-time effects and found no evidence that women avoid asking due to fear of upsetting bosses or gender stereotypes. Results held after accounting for employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications, using 2013-14 Australian data, where Australia uniquely records such behavior. Age differences showed under-40 men and women both asking and receiving at similar rates, suggesting negotiating behavior may be changing, with young women negotiating more successfully.

Oxford City Council has spent most of the funding on ground investigations for possible burial sites, but none were found suitable. Two existing cemeteries (Wolvercote and Botley) still have space but are projected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively, and the council remains determined to find options, though identified council-owned sites have been discounted due to factors such as site size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenants. Once the two cemeteries are full, only reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes would be possible. The last expansion of burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.

HebCelt 2024 in Stornoway (Isle of Lewis, July 19–22) introduces an augmented reality app that lets festival visitors trigger online information from signs and posters, view videos and band interviews on phones and tablets, and access updates that enable ticket purchases and a taste of the festival from anywhere, while featuring acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham Trials Day, suffering a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, with the British Horseracing Authority noting there were no significant underlying health issues and vowing to investigate causes and prevention; the race also featured Thistlecrack overcoming Many Clouds, who had a history of post-race overheating and ataxia but had shown no prior collapse, and was described by his trainer as the horse of a lifetime.

A 15-year-old girl met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004. The defendant, now 34 and known as Davina, denied the charge and will be sentenced on 4 March; Judge Ian Pearson remanded her in custody, noting likely placement in a male prison in Winchester due to risks to herself and to attending court, and described the case as unusual and not easy. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, had attempted suicide the previous summer, and protocols were set for detention at the male prison. During trial, Ayrton discussed her sexuality, claimed she had not made physical changes or taken medication, and she had changed her name in 2012. The court heard she raped the teenager while two others slept in the garage; the victim yelled for her to stop, but her friends did not wake. Ayrton had apparently consumed one and a half cans of Foster’s and recalled the events, and in 2014 she told a care-home worker about the attack in Fordingbridge, Hampshire.

The Serbs were defeated 6-4 6-4 by Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, following Djokovic’s earlier exit from singles in the tournament after losing to Juan Martin del Potro; the world No. 1 had a surprising Wimbledon third-round exit to Sam Querrey, but later won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US are expected to participate in a chainsaw-only log carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, where entrants carve logs into animals and people; last year's winner Pete Bowsher of Moffat is returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy prize.

Webb, who hasn’t played since a serious foot injury in September, says he is close to a return and aiming to be fit for Wales’s Six Nations opener against Ireland on February 7, having asked to start a few weeks earlier and having his return timeline adjusted with physios. He is currently in a pre-season phase and will take each week as it comes. Webb has renewed his dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region, where he made his debut in 2007, and emphasizes his commitment to playing for Wales.

Border agents halted two men near the US-Canada border east of Sumas, Washington, as they attempted to smuggle MDMA (ecstasy) into the United States; one man fled after firing on agents while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was captured. The backpacks carried a total of 58 pounds (26 kg) of ecstasy, one containing a California driver’s license bearing William Nickerson’s name but Nathan Hall’s photo. Hall, a Canadian citizen, was arrested in British Columbia, and a woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were later arrested in connection with the operation and alleged plans to transport the drugs to San Francisco for a fee. The group face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges, and the area near the border is a known smuggling corridor.

The NSPCC’s Childline reports a steep rise in help for children, with over 4,500 counselled in the past year compared with about 2,400 in 2011-12, and notes that many more suffer online abuse, including seven-year-olds who are tormented and fearful of school; cyber-bullying now follows them home and can escalate if not addressed, prompting Dame Esther Rantzen to urge immediate intervention by adults, parents, and teachers, and calling on schools to take the problem seriously while encouraging children to seek help; the report, released during Anti-Bullying Week, highlights that bullying does not stop on its own and quotes a child describing emotional distress from online harassers, with suggested advice for dealing with bullying.

Israel moved to postpone a planned vote on authorizing 492 new settler homes in Jerusalem’s Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office, ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry’s forthcoming address on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict; the move comes after the US abstained on a UN Security Council resolution condemning settlements, which Israel criticized as undermining its capital status in East Jerusalem, while Netanyahu recalled US and other Security Council ambassadors and reduced ties with several countries in response. The Security Council resolution stated that settlements have no legal validity and hinder a two-state peace process, a stance Israel rejected; Kerry was expected to outline a peace vision, and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas said the resolution paves the way for a French-hosted conference on Jan. 15 seeking a mechanism and timetable to end the occupation.

A BBC interview saw Prince William praise the Queen as a guiding example of good monarchy, amid celebrations marking her 90th birthday, while a stamp collection featuring the Queen, Charles, William, and George was released and a Windsor visit included a walk to mark The Queen’s Walkway and a beacon lighting to begin UK-wide festivities. The event program, including a bandstand opening and school singing, coincided with tributes from political leaders like David Cameron, who called the Queen’s service dignified. William discussed duty and public life, acknowledging criticism but focusing on a normal life for his family while preparing for greater royal responsibility, and reflecting that his grandmother remains the best role model. Later celebrations included ten stamps, a royal family-focused sheet, and the anticipated official birthday events, with plans for a Windsor lunch with US President Obama, and debates about media coverage from republic groups.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in a League Cup third-round match, with Diafra Sakho opening the scoring before half-time and Andre Ayew doubling the lead shortly after; Cheltenham, a fourth-tier side, created several chances but were unable to test West Ham keeper Adrian, while West Ham made seven changes and later substituted Chicharito for Sakho.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died after Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, failed to spot him as Werner's VW Transporter turned right on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion, causing the crash. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim’s family viewed Werner's potential jail as inappropriate, noting it was a momentary lapse, and Werner expressed remorse with no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, traveled to Syria, joined the Rayat al Tawheed group allied with Islamic State, and became a prominent, online-presented British fighter involved in propaganda, fundraising, and touring fighters’ quarters; while MI5 monitored him, he secretly returned to the UK last year by faking his death with an obituary after his cousin Tahir Bhatti helped him travel via Bulgaria, was arrested at Dover, and is facing potential life imprisonment on multiple terrorism-related charges, including implications of involvement in a terrorist training camp and attempted murder solicitation, with Khawaja described by authorities as a dangerous individual.

Kayden Jackson, 22, who scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season as they finished eighth, is Barnsley’s third signing for next season. He is expected to fit Barnsley’s style, bringing pace and an attacking threat as they prepare for League One, with Jackson having turned down a contract offer from Wrexham for next season.

National Trust volunteers have been clearing bottles washed up at Poldhu Cove and other nearby Cornish beaches after a container from a ship reportedly leaked during stormy weather; the Maritime and Coastguard Agency notes there is no conclusive evidence that the bottles found on the coast come from the vessel's container, though it is believed the container was lost near Land’s End in May. Conservation groups warn of risks to marine life from the detergent, and authorities including Cornwall Council, the National Trust, the MCA, and Natural England will monitor beaches; the public should keep distance from the bottles and not attempt to recover them, with the National Trust arranging clearance.

An incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, causing several people to sustain minor injuries; the road was closed with diversions set via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, and Police Scotland said inquiries were ongoing.

Dervite, 28, contributed 14 appearances as Bolton Wanderers finished second in League One and earned promotion; the French centre-back, who joined from Charlton in 2014, has made 83 appearances in all competitions for Bolton, and despite being “a forgotten man” last year, he helped toward the end of the campaign, with manager Phil Parkinson noting his excellent contribution. He is among those who have signed new contracts after Bolton’s promotion to the Championship, joining David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of conceding everything as they joined forces to defeat the government on EU citizens’ rights and Brexit approval, but the coalition collapsed when MPs rejected the amendments, with Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons; Lib Dems accused Labour of grandstanding and aiding a hard Brexit, while Labour and Lib Dems have a history of cross-party defeats on issues from higher education to housing, and while Baroness Ludford remains willing to work with peers, a Labour source expects lingering tensions and a pragmatic, business-like relationship between their leaderships.

The passage argues that defence is a low-priority issue for most political parties in the current election and that public concern about defence is modest, while global instability persists.
