It outlines significant cuts and capability gaps in the UK’s armed forces—smaller Army, fewer Navy ships, reduced RAF squadrons, and loss of Maritime Patrol Aircraft—along with doubts about meeting NATO’s 2% GDP defence spending target and the financial pressures on the MoD. It notes political divergence on nuclear deterrence (Trident), with parties proposing varying levels of commitment and reform, and highlights looming budgetary constraints that will force further defence cuts, despite plans to replace carriers and maintain CASD. The piece concludes that achieving credible power projection is increasingly difficult given budgetary realities and manpower shortages.

Barcelona maintains it did not commit any offence in Neymar’s signing, arguing contracts could be interpreted in different ways and insisting the original tax payment was in line with their obligations. The club says Neymar cost £106.8m overall when including the initial fee, signing-on, wages, agent fees, and the latest tax payment, and notes that 57m euros (£48.6m) was the stated fee, though total costs may be higher. Former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid misappropriation accusations and is under investigation. A Spanish judge ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue the transfer-related investigation, while Barcelona has filed a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to defend its reputation, though it remains convinced the initial tax payment was correct. Neymar has per-season figures of seven league goals in 18 appearances and three Champions League goals in seven matches.

A fatal crash near Kegworth, Leicestershire occurred when a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way by Albert Kenneth Newman collided with a van carrying Michael Luciw, 27, who was killed along with Newman; Luciw’s family urged regular driving tests for older drivers, while some advocate continued driving for independence and slower reactions with possible testing. Andy Harrington, Luciw’s colleague, survived with serious injuries and called for medical checks for retired drivers. Current UK policy requires drivers over 70 to renew licenses every three years with a self-assessment, but no age-based licensing restriction is planned by the DVLA, which can revoke licenses if medical standards aren’t met; Age UK emphasizes supporting safe driving to preserve independence.

The passage describes concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse, amid debilitating side effects and protests by some patients. An independent review concluded that such procedures should not be offered routinely, recommended offering a range of treatments with informed patient choices, and called for mandatory reporting of adverse events; campaigners urged an all-out ban, which the government could not implement alone. Alison Britton was appointed to review the review process itself to identify lessons for the future. Tracey Gillies, who led the later stages of the independent review, apologized for failing to unite the panel, while some panel members, including Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, resigned in protest at the report, amid claims that parts of the final document were altered. Over two decades, more than 20,000 Scottish women have undergone mesh or tape implants, with accumulating painful complications and over 400 currently pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Muir, 23, set a new indoor 5K British record of 14:49.12 at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, breaking McColgan’s 25-year-old mark by 14 seconds; although McColgan questioned whether the race met all UK Athletics criteria and doping requirements, British Athletics indicated the time will be ratified as official. McColgan praised Muir’s potential for world medals and suggested Muir could reach around 14:30, noting the race’s similarity to her own past record with Muir lapping other runners. McColgan also highlighted the national significance of the feat, as Muir is a fellow Scot who previously set a British 1500m record and reached the Rio 2016 Olympic final.

Jung won aboard Sam, who was a late replacement due to Fischertakinou’s infection, while France’s Astier Nicolas took silver and American Phillip Dutton bronze as GB’s William Fox-Pitt finished 12th after an induced-coma setback; Fox-Pitt had led after dressage but dropped to 21st after penalties in the cross-country, with Jonty Evans finishing ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift, and the article mentions fan parks and a guide to getting into equestrian at Rio Olympics.

Andy Murray survived a tense four-set clash with Fabio Fognini to reach the fourth round at Wimbledon, edging the Italian 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 after 2 hours 39 minutes, sealing match point at 20:57 BST and saving three set points in the fourth as the roof considerations and fading light loomed. He improved to 11 appearances in the last 16 and will face Benoit Paire next, while fellow Briton Johanna Konta reached the second week with a straight-sets win over Maria Sakkari. Murray acknowledged the match’s ups and downs, noted the impact of darkness and possible roof changes, and said he was pleased to advance and break for rest before Monday’s game.

Paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, where police found alcohol being served after licensing hours; the judge ordered a three-month closure, and Colleen O'Neill (license holder) was fined £3,000 while James Thomas, facing a similar charge, was fined £1,000, with the court noting poor management and a poor licensing record.

Ulster Unionists, led by Mike Nesbitt, frame the election as a referendum on how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled, with Nesbitt defending his remarks and asserting his party’s stance: vote Ulster Unionists first, then support candidates who will act right in their communities, constituencies, and country, even as some colleagues distance themselves from his comments. He says if the party enters Stormont, it would be with a nationalist party, preferably the SDLP over Sinn Féin, and portrays the election as a contest against incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption, while the party’s manifesto Real Partnership promises action on waiting lists, boosting PSNI numbers to 7,500, improving York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is worse off due to Brexit, alongside a Cleaning Up Stormont section.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced that a motion will be submitted to the assembly to implement pardons for men convicted of abolished sexual offences in Northern Ireland, aligning with England and Wales' posthumous and living pardons under "Turing's Law." The motion is expected to allow posthumous pardons and pardons for living gay and bisexual men, with executive agreement secured to seek a legislative consent motion. Sugden said the arrangements aim for equal treatment with England and Wales and to address past wrongs more swiftly than a full assembly bill, and the motion will proceed to the assembly for consideration.

Laura Muir, the 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second to Faith Kipyegon in 4:19.12, breaking Yvonne Murray’s Scottish record and moving to second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd, as she also became the Scottish 1500m and mile record holder. She expressed pleasure at setting the Scottish mark and noted it was her first race of the season at this distance, while acknowledging Faith Kipyegon’s speed. Murray’s husband commented on the achievement, and Muir aims to secure Olympic selection for Great Britain at the British trials in Birmingham (June 24–26) after starting the season with an 800m win in Montbéliard and planning a 1500m in Stockholm next. She trains around her veterinary studies, having just completed her fourth year.
The passage lists some of your pictures from the 26 beaches that are ranked as Scotland's "most excellent" for water quality.

UK officials believe Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi poisoned Alexander Litvinenko in London in 2006 with polonium-210, dying weeks later; Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued the Russian state likely sponsored the plot and had reasons to harm Litvinenko, though he cautioned this does not mean President Putin ordered it. Litvinenko’s defection and criticisms of Putin were cited as possible motives, and Horwell noted the public health risk from polonium is unknown and that Litvinenko was poisoned twice, leaving a trail of polonium with no credible defense from the suspects. Extradition failed and the suspects remain in Russia, with Kovtun criticized for not testifying to the inquiry. The inquiry was adjourned.

Steve Smith, 26, is appointed captain of Australia’s one-day side and will also lead the Twenty20 team in the absence of injured Aaron Finch, with David Warner, 28, named as Smith’s vice-captain; national selector Rod Marsh praises Smith’s talent and readiness, while Clarke’s retirement after the Ashes loss to England paves the way for Smith’s succession, a move Marsh says was straightforward and fitting as Smith has already captained Tests in India last year and has strong career stats (32 Tests, 2,952 runs at 54.66); Warner earns the vice-captaincy despite past disciplinary issues, with Marsh noting his maturation and suitability for added leadership, and both Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs series after the final Ashes Test at the Oval beginning 20 August.

Tim Farron refused to say whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, but asserted his strong support for LGBT-plus rights and making equal marriage and transgender marriage rights a top agenda item; he stressed being a liberal who supports equality, and noted that the Lib Dems have sought to extend equal access under law to all people regardless of sexuality, while explaining he opposed the Equality Bill in 2007 after voting against it when amendments on individual liberties failed, and highlighting concerns about the spousal veto that currently prevents full equal access for transgender people in marriage.

Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015 with 450 job losses, and Accord Healthcare will use the plant for pharmaceutical production, aiming to hire many former Sanofi staff; officials say the investment will positively impact the area, boosting the local economy, and reinforcing Newcastle and the North East’s reputation in science and healthcare, as Accord Healthcare, a global pharma company, develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to about 60 countries.

The local authority announced that Richard Ellis will leave Friday at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are exiting through a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Opposition SNP leader Stephen Flynn suggested these departures show the council’s difficulty in retaining senior staff and predicted more exits in the near future. Ellis had served as interim director of corporate governance and has been acting deputy chief executive, Monaghan heads the chief executive’s office, and Sutherland leads human resources and customer services. Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the trio for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants linked to IS attacked Kabul’s Sardar Daud hospital, detonating at the gate and then firing on staff and patients; security forces, including roof-based commandos, killed all four attackers after hours of fighting, with over 50 people wounded. IS claimed the assault, while the Taliban denied involvement. The attack marked a shift for IS in Afghanistan, using a method typical of the Taliban by breaching gates to enter, signaling possible increased capabilities and more such assaults in the capital. The government says IS has been pushed from some eastern bases but remains active in mountainous areas; the attack follows recent Taliban suicide attacks in Kabul and IS’s broader regional expansion in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

Martin revealed he is not quitting racing overall but has no plans to race road races on Hondas this year, skipped the North West 200 after teammate McGuinness’s crash, and will not compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. He described the TT as a disaster, said he mainly served as a test rider, and after further testing at Cadwell he told the team the bike wouldn’t be competitive at Ulster, a decision they effectively made for him. He also expressed interest in racing classics and unusual events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts, marking a major defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which lost the presidency and many northern states, while retaining Rivers State and winning eight governorships mainly in the southeast; results showed the APC sweeping most of the north and Lagos, but failing to win in oil-producing states, raising concerns about oil revenue and militant disruption, as violence affected some polling, and the PDP faced internal defections and corruption accusations, leading to a need for introspection and rebuilding under a new leader as Buhari prepares to be inaugurated on May 29.

Mighty’s report accuses the agricultural trader Olam and its majority shareholder Temasek of enabling unsustainable palm oil practices that contribute to Indonesia’s haze, a claim both firms deny while highlighting their strict no-burn, no-peat, no-deforestation policy and Olam’s limited, vetted supplier base; Mighty alleges a hidden market for rogue suppliers and notes Olam disclosed 14 suppliers after pressure, with vetting requiring years. Temasek defends governance independence and support for no-burn policies, stating it does not direct Olam’s operations. The broader palm oil industry faces criticism for deforestation, labor issues, and environmental harm, with NGOs pushing for stricter government enforcement, while industry players argue the sector’s scale and regional employment complicate reform; Mighty also cites Gabon where Olam’s ventures are said to clear rainforest for monoculture plantations, which Olam says are conducted transparently and responsibly with public stakeholder engagement.

The passage reports that on 27 August 2016, the restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors, and ends with a remark about it looking like a right dog's dinner.

Derby County have injury and selection concerns ahead of their match: forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful with a knee issue and has only appeared as a substitute in recent games, striker David Nugent may return from a groin problem after missing the draw with Huddersfield, and midfielder Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after scoring as a late substitute against Huddersfield.

Pakistan’s telecoms regulator said the YouTube ban was lifted since Google launched a Pakistan-specific YouTube, with all ISPs directed to restore access; Google/YouTube will restrict access to offending content within Pakistan only after a review and government removal requests will be logged in YouTube’s Transparency Report, though YouTube says removal requests are not automatically granted and follow its community guidelines. The ban, imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 after the Innocence of Muslims video, had prompted debate over transparency of any deal with Google; Google has since launched localized YouTube versions for Pakistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA’s Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian like one of the five presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino, and previously recused himself in 2015 due to nationality similarities with Sepp Blatter; Musa Bility threatens to take Scala to CAS if Scala does not withdraw, arguing a conflict of interest under Article 7.4, while Scala’s spokesman argues nationality does not create a conflict and notes Scala withdrew previously as a precaution, with no incumbent president in this election; the Liberian FA, led by Bility, is pressing for Scala’s stepping down or face challenges, as the election to replace Blatter approaches in 18 days, with candidates Prince Ali, Infantino, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale, and the vote by FIFA’s 209 members is set for Zurich.

Two men, Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56), were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while likely working in a paint-spraying area, with their bodies removed the next day; a forensic search is underway after a flashover explosion, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes igniting to create a fire-ball effect, and investigators from the Health and Safety Executive are gathering evidence alongside electrical safety experts.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf but apologised, while Morocco had its Nations Cup ban overturned by Cas, which reduced its fine and allowed them to participate in the 2017 qualifiers; both nations expressed optimism for a positive future in African football, with Tunisia reaffirming that its row with Caf is resolved after meetings and apologies, and both teams preparing for the 2017 finals, with Tunisia in Group A and Morocco in Group F, pursuing a record thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance if successful.

In the Etihad Stadium clash that Chelsea won 3-1, Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off after a mass fracas in the 95th minute; Aguero received a four-match ban for a second violent conduct dismissal this season following a high and late challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz, while Fernandinho clashed with Cesc Fabregas and will serve a three-match ban; Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action, and Pep Guardiola apologized for Manchester City's part in the incident, with both clubs facing a deadline of 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

A pilot scheme in Cynon and Castell-nedd is focusing on patients who may have cancer but show no obvious symptoms, aiming to shorten diagnosis times by allowing GPs to immediately refer uncertain cases to a diagnostic clinic at Swansea NHS hospital within seven days, based on Danish model improvements where cancer survival rates are higher. Currently only about 35% of symptomatic cancer cases in the Cynon area are diagnosed promptly, so the plan seeks to diagnose and treat cancers earlier by centralizing rapid testing in one day and using streamlined referrals, potentially preventing overtreatment from late or uncertain diagnoses. If the six‑month Cynon trial succeeds, the approach will be rolled out to other health boards in the region.

England completed a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, declaring twice for 589-8 and 173-1 to secure their second-largest win by runs; Joe Root was man of the match with 254 and an unbeaten 71, plus four catches and a rare over wicket, while Alastair Cook praised his handling and Root reflected on assuming responsibility. England’s bowlers and fielding were disciplined as Pakistan were bowled out for 234, with Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq the only first two Tests to pass 50; Misbah expressed disappointment and urged mental resilience as Pakistan prepares for a two-day tour match and the third Test at Edgbaston.

Head coach Warren Gatland has named interim coach Rob Howley as part of the British and Irish Lions backroom in New Zealand, while forwards coach Gatland McBryde takes head coach responsibilities for the third time, with the Welsh Rugby Union planning to appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to support him; the WRU is in advanced discussions with others to complete the management team, and Welsh leaders believe the Lions involvement will benefit Welsh rugby by developing coaches in new environments and providing a demanding, inspiring test in New Zealand.

Hull City snapped a six-game league losing streak with a 2-1 comeback win over Southampton at the KCOM Stadium, after Charlie Austin’s early penalty gave Saints control and injuries to Abel Hernandez and Will Keane disrupted Hull. Snodgrass, who returned from injury, inspired Hull with a 61st-minute equaliser and then set up Michael Dawson for the second, as Hull seized momentum and produced a late goalline clearance from Clucas to preserve the win despite Southampton’s late pressure and several saves by David Marshall.

A motorcyclist was killed in a crash on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, around 14:15 BST. The tractor driver was not injured, and the local motorcyclist victim’s identity and further details have not been released. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses to come forward, and the B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, saying he wanted to end the agony before early elections, a move condemned by the opposition and EU officials. The recordings since 2015 have alleged vote-rigging, corruption, mismanagement, and cover-ups including killings, with opposition leader Zaev releasing them and accusing the government of wiretapping up to 20,000 people; the government denies the claims and accuses Zaev of destabilizing the country. Ivanov framed his action as defending national interests, while EU Enlargement Commissioner Hahn warned it undermined the rule of law and Macedonia’s EU ambitions. A protest gathered outside the prosecutor's office in Skopje.

Curtis and Paul Williams will lead Swansea for Saturday’s match with Bournemouth after Bob Bradley’s sacking, while the club seeks a new manager, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement as first choice; Curtis warns staying up will be tough if they are relegated, notes the championship will be stronger, and reflects that Swansea have lost their "Swansea Way" since Michael Laudrup’s departure, with frequent management changes and missing key players, though he believes the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and reminds new signings of the club’s rise and its importance to the area.

Dagenham & Redbridge needed a win to stay alive in League One but were defeated 2-1 by Leyton Orient, with Armand Gnanduillet’s late goal sealing Orient’s win and keeping their play-off hopes intact while Dagenham were relegated back to the National League; Jamie Cureton’s nine goals for Dagenham contrasted with a generally difficult season that saw the club's poor form, while Orient’s interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized professionalism and fan importance after the departure of player-manager Kevin Nolan, and Dagenham manager John Still lamented a lack of early discipline and organization as a key factor in their struggles.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain, will return to his boyhood club as a youth coach in February, marking his first role since retiring as a player. Jurgen Klopp described the appointment as wonderful news and noted Gerrard’s ambition to become a manager, stating he is ready to learn and has a bright future, combining his playing experience with new coaching lessons. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998 and left in 2015 after a 19-year career, recently retired from playing and had been linked with MK Dons’ manager job; he is also pursuing his UEFA A coaching licence, a requirement for managing in the Premier League.

McManus opened the scoring for Morton with a close-range finish around 15 minutes, followed by Ross Forbes’ deflected strike to extend the lead. Kyle McAusland pulled Alloa back before half-time, but McManus scored again and Denny Johnstone added a late goal to seal a comfortable victory for Morton.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions at three closed sites in Birmingham, with 18 unregulated schools visited so far and owners of the Birmingham sites investigated for running illegal schools; the cases, possibly the “tip of the iceberg,” raise concerns about abuse or radicalisation risks, as places teaching more than 20 hours weekly must register, while some so-called part-time centres or “flexi schools” may be operating illegally under the guise of home education. A government-funded team of six inspectors will investigate illegal schools across religious groups, and the education secretary is preparing prosecutions against identified unregistered schools, with prosecutions requiring consent from the Education Secretary and a consultation on further regulation ongoing until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, aims to contribute to the region’s distilling revival as plans progress for Scotland’s first new whisky distillery since 1837, with lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlighting the exciting potential to make the Scottish Borders a hub of distilling excellence; despite its small production scale and location in a cowshed, the gin emphasizes local Borders botanicals and terroir, drawing on abundant local resources in the Teviot valley, and is named after the legendary 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor figure Lilliard to reflect landscape and a female-led production ethos, while partnering with the nearby Scottish Borders Brewery as part of a local-sourcing ethos.

Harry Whitlam died after Gary Green reversed a tractor into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds, in August 2013, while Green was reportedly more than twice the legal drink-drive limit, with the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before bed. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting failure to ensure safety; the case was pursued under health and safety law because the incident occurred on private land, during which HSE inspectors found Green backing into a worker in a closed-off area. Harry’s family, particularly his mother Pam Whitlam, described the loss as life-changing and emphasised that drunk driving is unacceptable on any road or private land.

Cas-ruled Suarez can train and participate in all football-related activities and friendlies, attend matches, and engage in promotional duties, while still serving eight of the remaining nine-match Fifa ban in competitive internationals and likely making his Barcelona debut against Real Madrid on 26 October; the Cas decision upheld most Fifa sanctions but deemed total ban on football activity excessive, allowing training and friendlies, with a pending full explanation and ongoing restrictions, amidst reactions from Fifpro and others.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a 380-metre race that involved hurdling over haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and dodging water pistols, beating Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene; the win came after a week of hard training, with strong competition from Lithuanians, and the pair will compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond said the move to an electronic system to replace the paper car tax discs in October 2014 could change job roles at the DVLA, with a likely reduction in refunds and the tax disc withdrawal leading to changes in duties and new training; any resulting staff reductions would be managed through redeployment to other growth areas rather than redundancies, a reassurance echoed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges who welcomed the commitment to redeployment and noted the advantages of monthly direct debits and not showing a tax disc.

Hungary’s government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s Fidesz, rejects EU interference in its domestic issues, insisting three controversial laws—on asylum seeker controls, higher education, and NGOs—are domestically competent, while vowing not to backtrack, with Poland pledging to veto any EU sanctions that would strip Hungary of voting rights. The EU is pressuring Hungary, arguing the laws threaten EU values and institutions, including the potential closure of the Central European University (CEU) founded by George Soros, and concerns over asylum housing in containers. NGOs fear the NGO law would stigmatize them as foreign‑backed, and Frans Timmermans has warned of action if there is no positive development, as Hungary proceeds with these measures.

The passage describes the cast and production details for a Beauty and the Beast film: Angela Lansbury will voice Mrs. Potts; Kevin Kline is Maurice; Emma Watson is Belle; Dan Stevens is the Beast; Luke Evans is Gaston; Josh Gad is LeFou; Bill Condon directs; filming begins at Shepperton Studios in May, with a US release set for March 17, 2017.

Adrian Gill, a celebrated Sunday Times columnist known for his fearless, witty writing and distinctive dyslexia-fueled habit of dictating copy, announced he had the “full English” of cancers and underwent chemotherapy; he remained stoical about his illness and described his condition with graphic, humorous terms. He died suddenly after his final column about coming to terms with his diagnosis, drawing tributes from editors, colleagues, and journalists who praised him as a giant among writers, the heart and soul of the paper, and an influential, controversial figure whose work spanned decades from his starting at the Sunday Times in 1993 to becoming a defining voice; his life included a notable career arc, education in art and design, marriages (to Cressida Connolly and later Amber Rudd), children, and a long relationship with Nicola Formby.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was performing in Ulaan Bator when he was assaulted, allegedly hit with a bottle and repeatedly kicked; his father said he spent about 10 days in a coma with serious brain injuries while the performer, who often wears a swastika symbol on stage to reflect Mongolia’s history and culture (where the symbol predates Nazi use and is a traditional emblem), defended its cultural meaning. The assault was alleged to involve a Russian diplomatic officer, though no identification had been publicly confirmed; the Russian embassy said it was investigating press reports and that some details were distorted, while Mongolian authorities said the case is under investigation and that the suspect was not detained due to the reported injury not being serious, with officials denying claims that immunity or arrest status depended on diplomatic status.

Campaigners from Plane Stupid demonstrated on Monday against airport expansion plans, staging a protest on the northern runway at 03:30 BST. The activists were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome and will appear in court on 19 August. In response, the Metropolitan Police said security at the airport would be reviewed.

Glamorgan, led by Michael Hogan in Jacques Rudolph’s absence, posted a total anchored by Nick Selman’s mature 101 off 144 as Matt Taylor and Craig Miles struck at regular intervals with the ball in cloudy Cardiff conditions; Aneurin Donald contributed a quick 36, while Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten added a late scramble for a consolation bonus point, and Gloucestershire bowled well to threaten, though their innings was a fight for survival as the day ended evenly balanced.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee and later admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court, with sentencing scheduled next week; prosecutors said he planned to make a false police report to lure officers to the scene on the Dee Estuary and then shoot them, with the threats made while drunk on two occasions, and he has a prior firearm conviction from 2009 while on bail for firearms offences (for which he was later cleared); the case raised concerns for police ambush, and Hughes remained in custody until sentencing, as the Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling.

Surrey beat Yorkshire after a decisive middle spell from Stuart Meaker, which curtailed Yorkshire’s chase; Davies and Ben Foakes shared a 130-run stand for Surrey, with Davies contributing a crucial 54 and Foakes 90, while Waite’s 3-48 and early dropped chances helped swing the game. Yorkshire had posted 236 all out in reply to Surrey’s 255-7, with Bresnan top-scoring (68) but Meaker’s bowling collapse, including dismissals of Bairstow, Ballance, and Leaning, sealed their fate. Surrey’s Davies and Foakes were pivotal in setting up the win, while Durham’s loss in the prior T20 Blast semi-finals had left Yorkshire hoping to make up for it at Lord’s.

A 56-foot converted trawler, about 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST reporting flooding after a pump failed to cope with water ingress. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump on board and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

Muir has decided she will miss the Scotland team for next year’s Commonwealth Games in Australia to focus on completing her veterinary medicine degree, with exams in May and the Games in April making it incompatible; she recently finished 4th and 6th in the 1500m and 5000m at the World Athletics Championships and believes she has potential for future Olympics, while remaining open to targets like the World Indoor Championships in March and possibly competing in Birmingham, and she remains optimistic about her form despite the demanding schedule.

Robbie Savage argues that Liverpool are far from challenging for the title and may only aim for a top-four finish, citing poor forward options, decreased pressing and set-piece threat, ongoing defensive instability, and a lack of leadership at the back, despite similar possession and passing activity to last season. He critiques Brendan Rodgers’ transfer choices up front, suggests Balotelli, Lambert, and Borini are not enough, and notes Gerrard’s aging but essential role, outlining a tactical plan for facing Chelsea with a solid midfield and active full-backs, while acknowledging Chelsea remain on a higher level. He also reflects on Gerrard’s mental battle and enduring importance to the team.

A £45m campus project in Kilmarnock will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre at Sutherland Drive, with the council seeking the McIlvanney family’s permission to name it afterWilliam McIlvanney, the Kilmarnock-born writer who is celebrated for his education advocacy; he worked as a teacher before becoming a full-time writer in 1975, gaining fame with Remedy Is None and earning the title “Godfather of Tartan Noir” for works like the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty, and The Big Man, while also contributing as a poet, journalist, and broadcaster until his death at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area around a Gourock swimming pool was evacuated and nearby residents advised to stay indoors near walls while windows were opened, with a precautionary exclusion zone on the river and a sea exclusion of about half a mile as experts work to render safe a sea mine believed to be British from the 1940s/50s. The evacuation affected three streets, with broader safety guidance for those within 500 meters of the device, and small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation; ferry services were disrupted to Gourock and Rothesay. Local officials emphasized there was no immediate danger to the community, noting the mine’s deterioration prevented assessment of remaining explosive material and necessitating removal to a safer location before disposal. Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the cordon and procedures.

UK Sport has cut funding for several sports ahead of Tokyo 2020, including cycling and badminton, while judo sees a slight increase; overall investment for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports totals £345m, £2m less than the Rio allocation, with £9m still to be allocated, and the target for Team GB is 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Badminton England laments the withdrawal of funding despite recent podium success, and officials question how strong performance can be sustained without investment, as UK Sport prioritises medal potential to avoid underperformance; while others note historic Rio success and the government’s continued commitment to Tokyo, and new sports are added to the program with funding decisions pending.

Three Victorian hotels at East Cliff in Bournemouth will be demolished to make way for a six-story, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (a 90-room hotel plus 122 assisted-living units across nine- and seven-storey buildings). The plan, championed by councillors as benefiting tourism and elder care, faced opposition from English Heritage and local objectors who argued the scale would severely harm the designated conservation area and historic character. The project, by East Cliff Project LLP, received 246 letters of support but 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, though councillors approved the scheme seven to three, noting the need to move forward while preserving tourism and improving living for older people.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, of the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was punched and beaten outside a Brecon bar by Jake Vallely, and later died after being found unconscious; Vallely, who boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" during a seven-hour drinking binge, is to be sentenced on 8 December, while Vallely’s friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter for not being present during the attack. CCTV showed Boyd being punched, knocked to the ground, and beaten until motionless, after which Vallely dragged his body from the scene before fleeing; Evans had left before any violence occurred. Det Supt David Guiney described the attack as despicable, and a family tribute remembered Boyd as a loyal, life-filled individual with a promising career cut short, expressing grief over Vallely’s actions and the community’s response.

Barnet Council announced that chief executive Andrew Travers left by mutual agreement following an election day error where many voters were not on the register, causing long delays and prompting apologies and emergency proxy votes; an independent investigation was launched, with deputy chief executive John Hooton stepping in temporarily and a council review due to report findings by the end of May into the EU Referendum arrangements and overall electoral processes.

Gateshead came from behind to beat Wrexham 2-1, with Josh Gillies opening the scoring for Gateshead from a free-kick, Sean Newton equalising for Wrexham from another set-piece, and Ryan Bowman securing Gateshead’s victory with a late header from Craig Baxter’s cross; Gateshead’s Malcolm Crosby praised his side’s second-half improvement and noted they were disappointing in the first half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills admitted the second half was too open and that they created chances but failed to convert, as the match ended Gateshead 2, Wrexham 1.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses the social and economic welfare of people over 60 across 96 countries, with Norway ranking first and Afghanistan the worst, followed by Mozambique.

The passage describes OneWeb, a plan to create a global broadband constellation initially of at least 600 satellites, potentially over 2,000, to deliver orbit-to-ground links and connect every school worldwide, with a focus on high-volume, low-cost production. Airbus is partnering to build and scale new assembly lines (in Toulouse and Florida) using automated, car- and plane-like manufacturing methods to produce satellites at under a million dollars each, aiming for a rapid launch cadence starting with a first batch in 2020 and progressively larger deployments through the decade. The project requires a massive rocket campaign (primarily Soyuz launches) to deploy clusters of satellites into ~1,200 km orbits, with expected regulatory and financing activity, including UK involvement through Space Agency oversight and debris mitigation measures to de-orbit old satellites within five years and even capture debris with chase vehicles. Airbus and OneWeb aim to set new industry standards in manufacturing efficiency and debris control, while recognizing that some satellite platforms will remain bespoke for specialized missions.

Mr Swinney argued that UK austerity has created unprecedented pressure on Scotland’s budget, with real-terms spending cuts totaling about 12.5% by 2019-20 and more than £1bn still to come, despite Scotland being given £390m more next year (rising to £750m with underspend) as part of the block grant. He said Scotland would defend key priorities—schools, hospitals, and police—and deliver better outcomes (higher police numbers, lower crime, tuition-free university, and a record health budget) without sacrificing them to austerity. The UK government countered that Scotland’s block grant remains strong and urged focus on using new powers and improving Scotland’s position, while Labour criticized the SNP for pre-election giveaways and called for a long-term budget approach instead of austerity.

The passage discusses the need for Changing Places toilets—larger, fully equipped facilities with space and features beyond standard accessible toilets—to meet the needs of people who require two carers, hoists, or specialized changing areas, highlighting how the lack of such facilities restricts families’ ability to go out and participate in daily activities. It notes that current Building Standards guidelines recommend but do not require these toilets, creating barriers for designers and businesses due to space, cost, and regulatory ambiguity. Campaigners argue for making Changing Places mandatory in new large buildings and cite examples of positive impact in places like Cardiff and Arsenal’s stadium, while sharing personal experiences of families navigating inaccessible venues and the emotional toll of inadequate facilities.

A group of Italian consumer organisations filed a formal complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald's of coercing franchisees into paying excessive rents and high fees, while McDonald's says it shares risks and rewards with franchisees and supports their operations; unions support the complaint, arguing that McDonald’s dominant market position harms franchisees, workers, and consumers, and the Commission will study the submission to determine whether to launch an investigation, with allegations including long contracts restricting competitor switching and above-market lease rates leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices; franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald’s European restaurants, with $9.27 billion in franchised-revenue globally in 2014.

A social-media campaign began with a #prayforjosh hashtag from Bangor Elim Church supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin of Donaghadee, who was diagnosed with cancer after an operation revealed a primary cancer and five smaller growths; the hashtag spread from Facebook and Instagram to a global audience, with a mystery donor funding a large billboard in Holywood, and widespread online support, including from his classmates and communities worldwide, as his family and church share updates on his recovery.

Brecon barracks, with a long history and about 85 civilian and 90 military staff, faces closure as part of a UK military estate reorganisation, prompting Brecon MP Chris Davies to condemn the decision, launch a petition, and warn it could harm the town’s employment and military tourism; Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon explained Wales would gain a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, with Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire closing in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge closing in 2025, while Labour’s Nia Griffith supported restructuring but cautioned about livelihoods and uncertainty for those affected.

The House of Lords European Union Committee report warns that UK fishing communities, which heavily supported Brexit, risk being marginalised in negotiations, even as Brexit could allow the UK to regain control over its waters and pursue a leading fish-exporting role like Norway. It notes the complexity of shared stocks and the reliance on EU markets, with most UK fish exported to the EU and much of UK consumer fish imported from the EU, so continued market access is essential, potentially in exchange for concessions on access to UK waters. The CFP features, such as quotas based on scientific advice, should be retained post-Brexit, and the UK may face a shift to four separate fisheries regimes for England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland unless a coherent framework is maintained. Some industry voices see Brexit as offering opportunities, citing new quotas and the prospect of full control over a 200-mile exclusive economic zone, while the government emphasizes maximum freedom to trade with the single market alongside fisheries reforms for sustainable stocks and fair quota access.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technician, revealed himself as the source of leaks about US surveillance, which the US government says is harmful to national security while Snowden says he acted to expose what he describes as horrifying levels of monitoring; documents indicate the NSA can access vast amounts of data including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data, and that Verizon disclosed millions of phone records, with Prism allegedly providing backdoor access to servers of major tech companies to process private posts, chats, and searches, though companies deny involvement and details of Prism remain unclear; officials defend the program as necessary for security, while critics question its reach and legality under various data protection laws and international jurisdictions, noting that data may be stored abroad under US authority, cloud computing complicates privacy, and the EU and UK have voiced concern or uncertainty about broader access, with Snowden asserting his actions stem from a desire to protect privacy against pervasive monitoring.

OpenAI’s backers include Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, with the aim of advancing digital intelligence to benefit humanity without financial return; the venture emphasizes positive human impact and broad, safe distribution of AI, noting only a small portion of a $1 billion pledge will be spent soon, while acknowledging ongoing debate about AI risks and potential threats to humanity.

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch on June 26 with support after thousands of Facebook friend requests—though a 5,000 friend-limit prevented all acceptance. Surrounded by supporters, he walked nearly half an hour with assistance, despite brain injury affecting speech but not personality; he now speaks unaided, trains 12 hours daily, uses crutches, and spends rest of time fundraising for military charities and serving as Pilgrim Bandits’ patron. His mother highlighted overwhelming public support, with Ben’s pages and Pilgrim Bandits sites receiving massive traffic and hundreds of requests to visit locations with the torch. Facebook suggested he become a public figure with a page or use Subscribe; the flame will be carried by 8,000 people over 8,000 miles to the Olympic opening on July 27.

In 2011, the US poverty rate was 15%, affecting about 46.2 million people and remaining level after three prior increases, while real median household income declined by 1.5% and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6% in 2011—the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%, and poverty had reached a record high in 2010 at 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer who joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013 on a deal through 2019, is a short-format specialist who has scored England’s three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball hundred against Pakistan. Lancashire’s cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praises his talent, influence in last year’s T20 Blast final, and his positive dressing-room presence, noting that his international experience benefits the squad. Buttler, who has been playing in the IPL with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for Friday’s T20 Blast home game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall—are moored in Portsmouth Harbour with bids from interested parties due by 23 January; no preservation proposals have been submitted yet, and viewings are planned for late February and March with a spring decision anticipated. The Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to test domestic capacity, while supporters like Penny Mordaunt advocate saving at least one for a reef and diving attraction or other uses that could generate tourism revenue, all while ensuring the best financial return for taxpayers. The MoD has stated it will consider all options, and bids remain confidential due to commercial sensitivity. Type 22s were originally anti-submarine ships that evolved into capable multi-mission frigates with strong command and control and a typical crew of about 280; last year HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap.

Since 1987 Fiji has faced recurrent racial and political turmoil, including two coups (1987 and 2000) driven by indigenous Fijians and subsequent political instability, a 2006 bloodless military takeover, and a 2009 Commonwealth suspension over democratic progress, followed by elections in 2014 and restoration of full diplomatic ties and Commonwealth membership. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing and deep informal segregation; thousands of Indo-Fijians fled after the mid-2000s, leaving indigenous Fijians with a growing majority. The economy, reliant on sugar and tourism, is diverse but hampered by deficits, with mining (gold, silver, limestone), a strong services sector, light manufacturing, and large aid receipts.

Syria’s Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said Syria is trying to destroy its chemical weapons in line with the OPCW/UN timetable, though it missed the latest deadline to hand over the entire stockpile; he cited attacks on two shipments en route to Latakia and insisted Syria is fighting terrorists, accusing the US of supporting them and defending its people, while denying civilian bombardment claims in Aleppo. The government contested rebel control of Aleppo’s central prison as fighting continued, with conflicting reports on detainees; meanwhile, about 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons remain declared, only around 4% (30 tonnes) having left the country, and UN-backed destruction has slowed due to security concerns, though Damascus pledged to fulfill all obligations.

Mukherjee's The Lives Of Others leads a Booker Prize shortlist for the 46th edition, opening eligibility to all English-language authors; the list includes Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, Richard Flanagan, and others, with Jacobson's J and Fowler's We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves highlighted among top contenders. Fowler's novel is the best-seller on the list, followed by Ferris's To Rise Again at a Decent Hour, while The Lives of Others chronicles Calcutta in 1967 amid family secrets and political activism. The prize’s final six will be announced on 9 September at the Guildhall, with coverage on BBC, and shortlisted authors each receive £2,500 and a bound edition; the judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling. Last year, Eleanor Catton won for The Luminaries.

A celebrity referred to as PJS is appealing against an appeal court ruling that lifted a ban on naming him in the media in England and Wales, with the Supreme Court set to decide whether to grant an appeal and, if so, whether it should be allowed or dismissed; an interim injunction remains until the hearing's end. The Court of Appeal had previously prevented publication identifying him while he sought privacy, after revelations of occasional sexual encounters with AB beginning in 2009 and a December 2011 text about a three-way with AB and CD; the Sun on Sunday sought to publish an account, but PJS contested, and a High Court initially refused an injunction before the appeal allowed a ban. News Group Newspapers argued to lift the ban as stories had appeared elsewhere and online, while PJS maintained the restriction; judges later said PJS was unlikely to obtain a permanent injunction as the story had become so widespread that confidentiality was probably lost, despite efforts to suppress online breaches.

Fosse Park, opened in 1989 near the M1, was bought in August for £345.5m, and new owners plan to improve parking, traffic flow, and the overall appearance of the shopping park. Blaby District Council’s Ernie White says the owners see it as an investable gateway to the city and have met with the council to resolve planning questions, while Crown Estates’ Paul Clarke notes efforts to address parking, congestion, and the quality of common areas and facilities to revitalize the site.

The passage describes controversy over a live-action Beauty and the Beast film in Malaysia due to a planned "gay moment" involving LeFou, which led to a review and a minor edit before approval for a P13 classification; the Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film but noted screening dates and locations are not its jurisdiction, while local cinemas offered refunds and some criticism from netizens continued, with the tourism minister calling banning the film ridiculous and Disney and others commenting on the moment.

Landlords renting to more than three unrelated people in Southampton must obtain an HMO licence, which can cost around 1,000, with penalties up to 20,000, and the council estimates about 1,500 unlicensed HMOs; tenants report fears of eviction and poor maintenance, while nationally licensing targets HMOs with three storeys or more and five or more unrelated occupants; in Southampton, designated areas have specific licensing regimes since 2013 and 2015, with most landlords cooperating but a minority resisting, and the council has pursued prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Fine Gael's Enda Kenny and Fianna Fáil's Micheál Martin aim to avoid a second election, with Fianna Fáil willing to support a minority government but not a programme for government; water charges are a key hurdle, and a commission on Irish Water is being considered, as Fianna Fáil demand immediate removal of charges while Fine Gael supports a role for them. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, Labour 7, and no party could form a majority or elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, en route to Valencia, caught fire on a car deck and quickly became uncontrollable, prompting a full evacuation of passengers to lifeboats and later onto a ferry as rescuers arrived; several people were injured and airlifted to hospital, one seriously, with rescued passengers heading back to Palma de Mallorca while psychologists were arranged for support. The blaze occurred about 27 km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon, and although an initial assessment suggested abandonment might not be necessary, the fire intensified and the vessel may sink in its current position; multiple ships, including two ferries, assisted and the Puglia ferried the evacuees. The ship is owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, and distress signals were issued at 13:50 local time.

The Electoral Commission reported concerns about duplicate voter registrations after record-high turnout in the June 8 general election, with 46.8 million registered and 68.7% turnout; about 2.9 million registration applications were submitted, many online, yet the net increase in registers was only 1.4 million, suggesting a large number of duplicates due to a lack of cross-checking between separate local electoral registers and the online system. The watchdog highlighted systemic issues, including non-communicating databases, easy online registration compared with difficult verification, and potential duplicate entries ranging from 30% to 70% in some areas, which imposes administrative and financial burdens. It recommended clearer registration information and a possible verification function, plus advising those registered in two seats to pre-select a voting seat for future general elections. While acknowledging serious offences for voting twice in a general election, it urged caution against policies that would unduly hinder registration, especially for students and those with multiple residences. There were isolated reports of people claiming to vote twice, though evidence was not conclusive, and authorities emphasized the need for police involvement if such cases are found.

Lawrence Phillips, a once-promising Nebraska and NFL running back, is believed to have killed himself while serving a prison sentence for multiple offenses, including assault; his career with the Rams, Dolphins, and 49ers was marred by legal troubles, and he faced additional charges and a potential murder trial regarding his cellmate’s death, despite some peers noting his intelligence and personal demons he struggled to overcome.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially classed as a soldier, was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment, with the honour bestowed by Brigadier Andrew Williams, the regiment’s colonel. He is the 30th mascot ram in a lineage dating back to the Indian Mutiny War, with the first Private Derby acquired in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot and adopted as the Mercian Regiment’s mascot in 2007. Joining the regiment in February 2014, he has his own army number, is paid for his rations, and normally takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. Throughout his service, Lance Corporal Derby XXX has helped switch on Ashbourne’s Christmas lights and met Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool staged a dramatic comeback against Borussia Dortmund at Anfield, coming from 2-0 down to win 4-3 with Dejan Lovren’s late header, in a match defined by Klopp’s fiery leadership and Manchester United-esque belief, echoing the 2005 Istanbul spirit. The game showcased Origi’s growing stature, Coutinho’s brilliance, and a generally vulnerable but improving defense, while Klopp’s mantra of turning doubt into belief and his insistence on urgency and noise shaped the atmosphere and performance. The victory moved Liverpool closer to securing a Europa League semi-final and potentially a return to the Champions League, with the Klopp era reinforcing its identity and fan support, even as questions linger about defensive solidity and squad depth.

The article reports on a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London where UK ministers discussed involving devolved administrations—Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland—in shaping Brexit negotiations, with a plan for regular monthly briefings and a two-way information flow to reflect differing views and ensure a collectively best UK deal. While Mr Davis emphasized constructive cooperation and transparency to implement the decision to leave the EU, Mr Russell stressed the need for clear strategic intentions from the UK government, particularly regarding membership of the single market or customs union, which he says is essential for Scotland’s economic prosperity. The piece also notes the UK government’s expectation that a High Court judgment on triggering Article 50 will be appealed to the Supreme Court, a move the Scottish government plans to oppose, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe seeking to be heard in the case.

A University of Nottingham study examines 13 cloned sheep, including 4 clones of Dolly’s ewe, to determine if cloning accelerates aging or increases age-related diseases. Lead researcher Prof. Kevin Sinclair explains the aim is to see whether cloned animals age normally and stay healthy, given concerns that transferring age-memory from adult donor cells could cause premature aging and illnesses such as osteoarthritis. Dolly herself died at 6.5 years from a lung virus and arthritis, prompting further investigation into whether cloning elevates risks for age-related conditions. The dollies and other clones undergo extensive testing—joint exams, X-rays, MRI/functional imaging— focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis, to compare with the broader sheep population. The 9th- to 10th-year-old clones currently appear in good health, with results due to be published next week and potentially significant implications for the future of cloning.

Trainer John Gosden’s unbeaten filly, a 4-7 favourite, won after a walk of the course, defeating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters and will head to Chantilly for the Oaks rather than Epsom, where Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the stable; Tasleet, trained by William Haggas, won the Duke of York Stakes, beating Magical Memory with Comicas third; Shutter Speed, winner of a fifth Musidora for Gosden and Dettori, performed well in very soft ground and will race in France’s Oaks at a mile and a quarter, with Gosden planning a month of preparation before Chantilly and relying on Enable and Coronet for the longer Epsom Oaks, while Cracksman may skip the Dante Stakes given the tight 16-day gap before the Derby, as Gosden plans to walk the course again before deciding.

The passage describes a volatile reaction in financial markets to Brexit uncertainty: the pound initially fell against the dollar and euro, then recovered before slipping again; the volatility index reached levels seen during the 2008 crisis; the pound traded around $1.4226 and €1.2605, with a notable drop against the yen; polls and betting markets showed increasing likelihood of a Remain outcome as the referendum approached, though some polls suggested Leave ahead and volatility heightened; analysts and traders warned of further volatility if polls remain tight; hedge funds short-sold sterling and UK equities fell, including a retreat in Asian markets and a FTSE 100 decline led by Lloyds; Nigel Farage argued sterling had strengthened since March and that a weaker pound could aid exporters; official data showed a narrowed UK trade deficit in April due to higher exports.

The Iron sit sixth in the National League, just outside the playoff spots, as Barrow won to stretch their unbeaten league run to nine; Cowley praised Barrow and acknowledged the tough travel and early goal, remaining positive about Braintree’s performance as a part-time side facing their toughest challenge yet and embracing the journey.

The passage discusses a planned shift of planning decision power in Northern Ireland from the Planning Service to local councils starting April 2015, allowing elected councillors to approve or reject developments, which some see as a democratising move and a chance for councils to shape community plans, while others warn it could lead to unfair favoritism, less transparency, and close ties between developers and politicians; experts stress the need for strong codes of conduct and transparency, and there is debate about politicians’ competence and the implications for political donations and donor security.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times—twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, leading to amputation and a difficult recovery as she learns to walk again—sparking calls by the Scottish SPCA for urgent licensing of air weapons to restrict possession to those with a legitimate reason and to aid policing, especially after a majority of the public opposed such licensing in a government consultation; the incident is being investigated and the SPCA urged anyone with information to contact them.

Benteke became Liverpool’s second most expensive signing on a long-term contract, following Raheem Sterling’s sale, as part of multiple summer signings to bolster an underperforming attack after last season’s goal shortage. The 24-year-old Belgium international joined from Villa for £7m after Villa’s manager and pundits praised his scoring ability and fit for Klopp’s project, with expectations that he will lead the forward line alongside new signings Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi returning from loan. Past injuries, a 15-goal season at Villa, and voices from former managers and players supported his potential to provide a strong presence and goal threat, addressing the previous season’s limited goals and high pressure to win trophies at Anfield.

The study found no clear evidence that tablet use in schools improves academic results, though head teachers report positive impacts and increased pupil motivation, especially for disengaged learners, with tablets also boosting family involvement when taken home. Tablets are now used in about two-thirds of primary and secondary schools, with more intensive use in some, including one-to-one devices in 9% of schools and greater adoption in academies; demand is rising, and nearly half of non-users say they would likely introduce tablets soon. A separate study suggests touch-screen devices help poorer pupils and boys learn to read. The research shows widespread integration of online technology into daily life for young people, and advocates argue that schools must reflect the tech-oriented world students inhabit.

Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool presents 25 photographs spanning 1880s to the 1990s that depict childhood in Liverpool, illustrating both play and hardship across more than a century. Curated by Kay Jones from National Museums Liverpool collections, the exhibit highlights social history by showing how life for children has changed and how occasions were marked on streets, including images of a fancy-dress ball for local children and a portrait of a young maid reflecting child labor. The curator selected images that convey the range of experiences, aiming to balance happy memories with the realities of working children, and the exhibition runs at the Museum of Liverpool until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join a National League rival, with a potential reunion vs his former club on 18 February, while 21-year-old striker Keating has been recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams and is awaiting international clearance after spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps; Nicholson praised Myles as a leader and Ruairi as hungry and eager to prove himself, as the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six.

Bolivia approved a new law allowing 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, aiming to address poverty while balancing rights and international treaties; it imposes harsher punishments for child violence and sets a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide, with President Morales signing the bill in his absence. The government argues the law reflects Bolivia’s reality, where many children already work to support families, and hopes it helps eradicate extreme poverty, though the International Labour Organization notes under-15s should not work and is reviewing whether the law complies with international regulations.

O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress, fell ill at home and, after researching women's heart attack symptoms online, took aspirin and later visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. She experienced chest pain, nausea, and feverish feelings after helping a woman in her Nyack village home. In a blog entry titled "my heart attack," she revealed the attack was a "widow maker" and admitted she did not immediately call emergency services, but urged readers, especially women, to recognize symptoms and call 911. She has acted in various films and TV shows and hosted The Rosie Show on OWN, which was canceled earlier due to low ratings.

A 16-year-old boy, Che Labastide-Wellington from Harrow, was stabbed and died after a late-night scuffle at an alleyway near a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton; a separate 16-year-old was also stabbed and treated in hospital. Police say Che was invited to a well-run party and was not involved in an earlier altercation with those denied entry, but he appeared to be targeted later. Det Chief Insp Chris Jones urged witnesses near the alley between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate to come forward. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, along with two boys aged 15 and 16 who were also arrested and bailed until mid-December; a 14-year-old is detained on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

A team from Wales studied Denmark’s three-route model to improve cancer diagnosis: fast-track “alarm” symptom pathways with strict time targets for obvious cancers; diagnosis centres at existing hospitals to quickly test unclear cases and avoid GP–specialist delays; and “yes-no” centres for minor symptoms to rapidly rule out cancer, with quick tests or scans and only about 1% progressing to serious disease. The changes aimed to reduce long waiting times for difficult-to-diagnose cancers and to treat patients within existing resources more efficiently, improving overall survival rates and reducing delays from initial presentation to treatment.

Powys has won the bid to deliver a new service replacing the OFT, with the authority awarded £170,000 per year to issue warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents or breaches of estate agent laws. Local authority trading standards departments will still handle complaints and prosecute offenders if needed, but will refer cases to Powys if parts of the Estate Agents Act are breached; James Munro of Powys council leads the new team and hopes this demonstrates capacity for more contracts and outside work.

NHS Employers backed the plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong workforce after the Nuffield Trust highlighted opportunities for nurses, pharmacists, and other staff to cover doctor shortages and manage rising long-term care needs, though funding and training challenges remain; while proponents cite improved patient care and more rewarding roles, critics warn against lowering doctors’ training quality and against using workforce reshaping as a quick fix amid funding squeezes.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place following a crash at 03:00 GMT on the A36, with the road closure lifted at 14:00 GMT, causing disruption to commuters and bus services during rush hour while investigations into the collision proceed; First Bus reported some services resuming while it would take a few hours to restore full service, and its managing director James Freeman expressed hope for a full service by the evening commute and thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts.

NRW estimated that the Swansea tidal lagoon would cause around 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout deaths annually as they migrate, a claim Tidal Lagoon Power disputed as lacking a clear scientific basis and accused NRW of withholding its methodology; NRW insisted its figures used the best available evidence and had been reviewed by independent and NRW experts, while TLP’s consultants argued a worst-case impact of about 2% of all fish. The £1.3bn project is viewed as a test bed for larger schemes around the coast, with UK ministers weighing a six-month viability review, and Wales’ Environment Secretary expressing support but seeking clarity on the UK government’s near-term position; NRW stated it has shared extensive data and methodologies with the developer, conducted evaluations with independent input, and remains confident in its environmental assessment.

Stormont announced the creation of a new, industry-led agri-food marketing body to coordinate and lead marketing activities across government and private sector in Northern Ireland, modeled after Scotland Food and Drink, with the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) developing it. DETI Minister Arlene Foster emphasised the agri-food sector’s importance, safeguarding nearly 100,000 jobs, and the body is intended to provide strategic direction for marketing. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move as a step toward export-led growth, noting a need for better coordination of marketing, but also cautioning that the plans could affect other organisations, including her department, and she looked forward to further discussion with the AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is leading a four-year project to create Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, part of four new UK woods intended to plant millions of native trees to commemorate WW1 victims, with 40,000 trees planned for Brackfield Wood to honor roughly 40,000 people from Ireland who died in the conflict. The public is invited to participate in a tree-planting event, contributing to a living tribute that will include wildflowers and poppies, and the site will become a place for wildlife and for people to walk, relax and reflect. The charity provides the saplings and asks volunteers to wear sturdy footwear, noting Brackfield Wood is about seven miles from Derry and has limited parking.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for a tightly written, emotionally powerful book, with Judge Alison Graham praising its atmosphere and impact; Ann Cleeves noted the strong shortlist and highlighted Det Insp Marnie Rome’s first novel, Someone Else’s Skin, which deals with domestic violence and honour crime. Sara Paretsky received the outstanding contribution award for her 23-year portrayal of VI Warshawski, a trailblazing female detective who challenged perceptions of women writers, and Paretsky was commended for changing how readers view female protagonists and for founding Sisters In Crime.

Santner, who broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, vowed to return to the Rapids after the ICC Trophy in June 2017, expressing frustration at missing time last season but optimistic about making an impact with bat and ball; Worcestershire's director Steve Rhodes highlighted that losing him had hurt their qualification chances, and the club later signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their overseas player for 2017.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed in 2008 on a Kiev dual carriageway when a speeding, unlit car with stolen plates struck him as he tried to hail a taxi; the coroner in Exeter ruled his death unlawful killing, noting the driver did not brake and suggesting circumstantial evidence points to a deliberate act amid investigations that were difficult to conduct abroad. His wife, Anna Ziuzina, much younger and later accused of financial gain and an affair, moved assets, sold Pring’s belongings, and stood to inherit, with family claiming she was involved in a staged hit-and-run to obtain money and property; she defended herself as having given statements to Ukrainian police and not attending the inquest. The Ukrainian inquiry was relaunched in 2011 as a murder inquiry and remains active but not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, a Merseyside boy who has been ill since age three, needs a second T-Cell Therapy transplant at Seattle Children's Hospital after a UK treatment option failed; following an April relapse there is no remaining UK option. An anonymous donor fully funded the treatment, enabling financial clearance, and the family is grateful and hopeful as the date is set to begin soon.

The passage discusses how third-party software was used to steal intimate photos from iCloud and how Apple’s proposed safety measure—an extra verification step after sign-in with a new device—could block such intrusions, though it remains opt-in. It explains the two-step verification process, including a four-digit code sent to a trusted device or via Find My iPhone, and a recovery key for account access if devices are lost. It notes past gaps where backups could be downloaded using Elcomsoft’s forensic tool, that hackers on forums discuss pirated versions of this software, and that Apple’s changes aim to prevent these attacks. While experts praise the notification of backup downloads and advocate making two-factor authentication default, concerns remain about recovery keys being forgotten or stolen, and about strengthening overall security beyond optional two-factor use. Apple plans to more aggressively promote two-factor authentication and stronger passwords, with Tim Cook emphasizing awareness alongside engineering fixes.

Dan Groves says the details of a deal for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town are still pending, with reports that he may become a club director; the club sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, just outside a playoff spot. Wright, who was runner-up on I'm a Celebrity in 2011, has a background in non-league football with clubs such as Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club has been recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who stated he is comfortable investing around £10,000 a week, and they signed former England international Paul Konchesky at the start of March.

Mr Ashley was asked to give evidence about how his workers are treated following a BBC investigation into Derbyshire company's warehouse practices. He has until 21 March to respond after a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, which notes that the BIS select committee, chaired by Wright, invited him to a meeting at the company’s Shirebrook base and plans to scrutinize treatment of low-paid workers and minimum wage enforcement. The letter states the committee normally meets in public, offered several alternative dates, and warns that failure to attend could lead to further action, potentially with the House of Commons’ support for a contempt complaint. Sports Direct has not commented, and the company has previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr Ashley, who also owns Newcastle United.

The passage describes how, after the assassination of opposition figure Boris Nemtsov, his colleagues led by Ilya Yashin have been finishing a Russian-language report titled Putin. War, which compiles already-published facts to argue that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. It asserts that Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in the pro-Russian separatists’ gains in Donetsk and Luhansk, with veterans and volunteers admitting direct Russian direction and paid salaries, while Russia denies formal military involvement. The dossier documents military units, weaponry, and costs (about 53 billion roubles) and notes difficulty in verification and publishing hurdles, as relatives of dead soldiers fear reprisals. The piece also notes a public ambivalence in Russia, with some viewing involvement as support for Ukrainian independence from Kyiv, while the opposition claims Putin masterminded the war to bolster his popularity, a strategy that may mirror Nemtsov’s prior, influential but ultimately galvanizing works.

Craig Nelson (also known as Craig Preston), a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham, died from head injuries after being found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem confirmed the cause of death. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

The passage discusses disagreements over the Article 50 letter: Carwyn Jones says he did not see the letter before publication and that devolved administrations were not invited to contribute, which he calls unacceptable amid a stated aim to develop a UK-wide negotiating framework.
