Welsh politicians, including Alun Cairns, emphasize Wales is being considered and that the UK government must act in the interests of the whole UK, while May’s letter mentions devolved powers and greater decision-making for Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, raising questions about which powers will be devolved, whether funding will accompany them, and how money will follow those powers after 2020. The text notes some Whitehall debate on transferring EU-funded powers to Westminster, the potential impact of future governments, and the lack of clarity about which powers the government seeks to devolve, with further detail expected in a forthcoming white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed being appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community, noting officers were carrying out duties when attacked. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page urged parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr Charney was ousted from American Apparel amid employee complaints and alleged misuse of funds; the board stated he is not expected to return, while Charney’s lawyer disputed the allegations as false and claimed privacy invasion. Court filings reveal illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, with the company alleging he violated sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies; the board argues most boards would not hire him due to risk to the company and shareholders. A restraining order was issued prohibiting him from making negative statements to the press about the company or trying to remove directors.

Britain will have a home game against Greece at the Copper Box, broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app, as part of their EuroBasket 2017 preparation following a previous win by Greece in Patras. GB players will face a stronger Greek side missing three teammates, offering a chance for revenge, with guard Teddy Okereafor highlighting the London venue and the importance of playing at this level to be ready for EuroBasket. After this match, coach Joe Prunty’s team will head to a four-team warm-up tournament in Poland before EuroBasket begins in September, which will be held in Istanbul, Turkey.

The passage recounts witnessing the iPhone launch era, noting Steve Jobs’ unveiling and the initial reluctance to grant access, the author briefly obtaining a prototype from Phil Schiller, and the subsequent media coverage that sparked debate about the iPhone’s significance. It reflects on the iPhone as a transformative technology that put powerful computing in the hands of billions and disrupted various industries, using photography as an example of improved mobile capabilities. It contrasts pre-2007 camera phones with the later ability to instantly share iPhone photos, attributes the revolution to Apple's emphasis on an attractive user interface, and places the iPhone alongside other tech advances from Amazon and Google as part of the move toward intelligent, mobile-friendly innovations.

Tests confirmed that all the cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray ingested a toxic substance, with seven-month-old Meereen dying after showing symptoms such as shivering and foaming at the mouth; in total, four cats have died in the past week or two weeks, and it is unclear whether the poisonings are accidental or deliberate. The owner described Meereen’s distress after returning home and the vet confirmed antifreeze poisoning before her death three days later. The RSPCA inspector urged residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely and to clean up any antifreeze spills, noting this is a time of year when antifreeze use increases.

Greece’s Syriza government, though agreeing to further austerity and liberalisation demanded by creditors, faces continued hardship despite rising tourist arrivals and a popular leader who has conceded much to secure an €86bn third bailout; the country remains mired in fiscal and monetary tightening, with bank closures limiting credit, austerity measures hurting citizens, and creditors urged to consider substantial debt relief to enable any genuine recovery, while Tsipras’ popularity persists amid the expectation that relief must come in order to avoid a collapse of the economy and further impoverishment.

Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell in EastEnders for Barbara Windsor's final episodes, reuniting the Mitchell brothers as Peggy Mitchell’s cancer storyline concludes with her death. Kemp returns at Windsor’s request to film what are described as classic EastEnders episodes, allowing the family to come together one last time as Peggy’s illness is revealed to her son Phil and the broader Mitchell clan.

Alice Ruggles was stalked by Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon, who fatally attacked her last October; her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recounted the moment police informed them of her death and described signs they missed about the danger. Dhillon, who had become obsessed with Alice, was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years, while her parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking, aiming to honor her vibrant personality and prevent others from similar harm.

EDF approved the £18bn Hinkley Point C project funding, with one third of costs from Chinese investors, but the UK government immediately announced a further review and Finance Secretary/Business Secretary signals of caution, leading EDF to cancel a Hinkley trip. The move sparked uncertainty about Britain’s post-Brexit energy policy,  while EDF faces financial strains and internal concerns, including shareholder actions to raise funds, and a resignation from a board member citing risk. The project is poised to supply about 7% of UK electricity, but critics warn of environmental impact, higher costs, and the value for households, urging more investment in renewables instead.

The new England and Wales divorce application form now explicitly asks for the name of the person with whom a spouse has committed adultery, a change that could increase conflict and complexity by involving a third party in the case, though the Ministry of Justice says there is no obligation to name them; lawyers warn that naming the co-respondent can delay proceedings and raise costs, while some clients want to involve the new partner and have their input, though judges view such involvement unfavorably, and guidance notes that naming is not normally necessary even though the form presents it as an option.

Britain imports a large amount of wood and Wales aims to balance forestry with environmental concerns, promoting woodland creation while acknowledging that commercial conifer forests have supported the timber industry but require replanting after 16,000 hectares were lost since 2001. Half of Welsh woodland is state-managed and half private, with the industry valued at over £450m annually, yet tension exists between environmental goals—more native species and public access—and conservationists’ worries about wildlife, plus practical issues like reach, harvestability, and community impact. The Welsh government seeks a balance through schemes like Glastir and its Woodlands for Wales strategy to enhance landscapes, social benefits, and woodland-based industries, though Confor argues the system is bureaucratic and emphasizes environmental aims over commercial forestry, noting a need for far greater planting (roughly 20,000 hectares per year) to meet long-term targets and a ready timber market that could boost production if supply were available.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School around 16:40. He was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoys veterans, including 91-year-old Able Seaman Charles Lewis, who said he was honoured; the ceremony followed a long dispute over foreign medals, with the Foreign Office initially blocking recognition, but an exception was granted, allowing Russia to honor veterans who helped defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The Arctic convoys, sailing from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II, faced constant German attacks and extreme conditions, and by May 1945 the route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. Russian officials stressed the ceremony honored a long-awaited gesture of gratitude and highlighted the convoys as a symbol of wartime alliance, while the UK had created the Arctic Star in 2012 and Grand-scale recognition evolved amid debate over foreign decorations. The Ushakov medal recognizes sailors displaying courage in defending Russia or its interests.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays and high no-shows among offenders required to perform unpaid work (community payback), with some offenders only completing a small fraction of their hours, and noted organisation difficulties in getting chaotic individuals to attend on time. The report examined 100 cases and 86 offenders, identifying 15 recommendations, including reducing turnaways when offenders arrive on time and tailoring objectives to individual circumstances, while praising some high-quality work and positive attitude from offenders who felt they benefited. The Ministry of Justice said it is acting on the report, aiming for more effective rehabilitation and enforcing attendance, and accepted all recommendations.

The passage discusses comedian Russell Brand being labeled a hypocrite for advocating economic and political revolution to aid the poor while living in a luxury home, noting his public criticisms of wealth inequality and his vlog coverage; it recounts a tense exchange outside Downing Street over his housing and finances, mentions his lack of response to a potential legal action from The Sun, and includes Brand’s past explanations admitting personal wealth and fame complicate his ability to drive change, emphasizing his view that systemic change is needed beyond individual effort.

Dr. Venter, a biologist-entrepreneur, turned human genome research into a competitive race, earning both criticism and wealth as he advanced genomics, founded private and later institutional ventures, and published landmark genome results; after pioneering speedier gene sequencing by focusing on RNA rather than the entire genome, he led Celera Genomics to rival the public project, faced accusations of bypassing open data, and subsequently formed the J. Craig Venter Institute to pursue a synthetic life form, Synthia, while also conducting ocean-based genomic exploration with the Sorcerer II, and he envisions synthetic biology driving an industrial revolution that could reduce oil dependence and mitigate environmental damage.

A survey of about 1,000 English parents found that four in five children who ate school lunches had tried foods there that they hadn’t at home, and half of the parents reported their child had asked for school foods to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were among the least popular; 628 parents had children who ate school lunches. The research was commissioned by England’s School Food Trust after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents sent packed lunches because their children were fussy, and the trust’s chair noted school meals can help broaden kids’ diets and reduce mealtime battles. Mumsnet highlighted that school meals may encourage peer influence toward trying a wider variety of foods, and that meals have improved in healthiness and variety. England’s school meals must meet strict nutritional guidelines, with about four in ten primary-aged children and somewhat more in secondary schools eating them, and roughly 46% of children in Scotland using school lunches. The online survey ran Feb 26–Mar 5 among parents with at least one child aged 4–17.

Alvaro Morata, 23, a Spain striker at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid after four seasons with Real, with a Real buy-back option reportedly up to 30 million euros. He had been linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, and has scored three Spain goals in France. At Juventus, he scored 27 goals over two years, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italia trophies, and played in back-to-back Champions League finals, scoring in Juventus’ 2015 semifinal/Final context after appearing as a substitute in Real’s 2014 win. He came through Real Madrid’s youth system, debuted for the first team at 18, and scored 10 goals for Real.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 and, after being released in May, has been without a team. He made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having spent four seasons with Forest before moving to Celtic, and he has also previously played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco is exiting its loss-making US chain Fresh & Easy, transferring about 4,000 of its 5,000 employees to a new buyer, Yucaipa, in a deal that includes Tesco lending around £80m and an £150m disposal cost for the Fresh & Easy brand (with some of that loan potentially repayable). Fresh & Easy operates 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona and has lost money since its 2007 launch; the remaining 50 stores are expected to close, while Tesco retains an option to buy a stake if the business becomes profitable. Yucaipa, led by Ron Burkle, is a Los Angeles-based private equity firm focused on supermarkets and restaurants.
He describes facing racial abuse, explains how he overcame it, briefly considered representing France, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

The French Alps have experienced significant glacier retreat from the late 1960s/early 1970s to the late 2000s, shrinking from about 375 sq km to 275 sq km (an average loss of ~26% over 40 years), with the retreat uneven across regions—most pronounced in the southern belts like Belledonne and Ecrins, while the northern Alps, including La Mer de Glace, show less dramatic loss. A new inventory by Marie Gardent and colleagues used map archives, past satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, verified by manual delineation to account for debris and shadow effects, updating the previous World Glacier Inventory figure and confirming ongoing regional glacier decline alongside similar trends observed across the broader Alpine range. The findings were presented at the AGU Fall Meeting.

Scotland’s women’s team have won all five of their qualifiers and host Iceland at Falkirk on Friday, aiming to seal a place at next summer’s finals; captain/career spark Evans stresses avoiding another play-off heartbreak after past losses, with Iceland, ranked one place higher, also unbeaten and likely to decide who tops the group, though Scotland sit in a strong position to reach the finals without a play-off if they perform well as they eye a big crowd and the support behind them.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England after a complaint from a south London woman alleging online harassment over two years; he was later released on bail to a date in mid-September. Campbell, a blogger and Scottish independence campaigner known for Wings Over Scotland, urged that the arrest concerns tweets that he says were not threatening and were publicly visible. A Metropolitan Police spokesman confirmed an investigation into online harassment, with the complaint made by a woman in her 30s at a south London police station. Campbell stated (via Wings Over Scotland) that the press report was fueled by innuendo and that only tweets, none of which were deleted or non-public, were involved, stressing that nothing sinister or serious beyond some tweets has occurred.

Peta proposes replacing Skegness’ Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish-themed, animal-friendly alternative, suggesting “Skegness – A Happy Plaice” to rebrand the seaside town as progressive and cruelty-free, while the mayor says there may be little support for removing Jolly and notes the poster is beloved by residents; he emphasizes that Jolly is not seen as cruel and that the idea will go to council but only acted on if warranted.

Scotland dominated the match with a rapid start, scoring early tries through Seymour, a penalty try, Maitland, and Hogg before half-time, stretched further by Hamish Watson and a second try from Lobzhanidze’s mistakeless Georgian scrums, while Hogg added a late counter-attack try as Scotland built a big lead. Georgia briefly troubled them with a late first-half penalty and a second-half scrum score, but Scotland extended their advantage with another Hogg strike and a fifth try by Watson, followed by a late surge that produced Scotland’s sixth try from Ali Price’s debut-driven breakout to seal a dominant 38-? victory; coach Vern Cotter praised pragmatism, ball retention, and improvement, as Scotland held on to outscore Georgia despite specific scrum troubles and a yellow card to Moray Low.

Widnes led 14-6 at halftime thanks to tries from Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, with Paddy Flynn scoring for Castleford against his parent club; Flynn added another early in the second half, but Widnes pulled away with further scores from Ah Van, Lloyd White (two) and Joe Mellor to make it 38-12. Castleford staged a late surge with three tries in four minutes by Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn (his hat-trick) to threaten a comeback, but Widnes held on as Castleford’s early-season home form continued to falter. The result moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh, while Castleford remained sixth, one point ahead of Widnes.

Fawzi al-Odah, a Kuwaiti detainee at Guantanamo since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, was released after a US Periodic Review Board concluded he no longer posed a continuing significant threat, and he left on a Kuwaiti government plane; his release requires at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait, and it brings Guantanamo’s inmate total to 148 as Obama’s pledge to close the facility remains unfulfilled.

The passage describes the viral rise of the infectious earworm "PPAP" (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen) performed by the fictional character Piko-Taro, created and portrayed by Kazuhiko Kosaka, whose goofy song about fusing a pen with an apple and a pineapple, simple dance, and catchy beat quickly spread from YouTube to Facebook, garnering millions of views, numerous tributes, and international attention, while triggering mixed reactions—from amusement and obsession to annoyance—yet gaining comparisons to Psy and prompting widespread cultural buzz, including various covers and fan-made imitations.

Thousands attended an Anzac Day dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, followed by a parade and wreath-laying at the Cenotaph, with a Westminster Abbey service and a ceremony that included the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia. The day marks the first major WWI battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces at Gallipoli, with the first commemoration in London in 1916 when King George V attended at Westminster Abbey. Since then, the observances have become important for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders to honor wartime sacrifices. Australian high commissioner Alexander Downer spoke at the dawn service, reflecting on Gallipoli and the heroism of the Anzac troops, as veterans, service and ex-service members and families joined the parade. The ceremony included prayers by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK, recalling the eight-month Gallipoli campaign and its aim to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

Clarkson, 30, joined St Mirren for a second spell in July and could debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday; he scored nine goals for Dundee last season, has mainly been used as a substitute this term, and says he is fit, match-ready, and eager to start, having played for the U20s to maintain fitness. He has two Scotland caps (2008) with one international goal and nearly 400 senior club appearances, with previous clubs including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren sit eighth in the Championship, seven points above bottom side Alloa, and Clarkson hopes to help the team win more games to build confidence and move up the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan, who assured that all current agreements, including the existing pension arrangements, would be honoured after the takeover. Unite stated that the Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme had closed in 2004 and members now have an unaffected alternative scheme, and Boparan’s office confirmed that pension arrangements would continue under new ownership. The new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability through greater investment, cost savings, and by using spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkey, as discussed with Unite representatives at the company’s Great Witchingham headquarters.

The council discussed problems with the new Cowes crossing vessel, announcing it would be free until 2 July to gather feedback while a review by auditors is ordered; the ferry has faced a troubled start since its late May launch, including breakdowns, grounding, and an MCA suspension over training issues, with damage to vehicles and concern for local businesses, while the council notes teething problems are being addressed, including ramp extensions to prevent vehicle scrapes and resolved seamanship groundings.

The House of Lords EU Committee report warns that UK fishing communities, which heavily supported Brexit, could be marginalised in negotiations unless the industry is protected, noting that most UK fish stocks are in waters shared with EU states and that continued market access to the EU is essential even if Britain regains control of its waters; it highlights the risk of diverging management regimes across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland if the CFP framework falls away, while acknowledging potential opportunities from Brexit, such as greater control over a 200-mile exclusive economic zone and the possibility of better quota access and sustainable management, though any gains may come with trade-offs like additional access concessions to the EU; recent EU quota increases are seen by industry representatives as a positive sign for a post-EU Britain, and the government says negotiations should maximize trade freedom while reforming fisheries management for fair access, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney admitted downloading images between 2004 and 2014 of young boys in erotic poses and was placed on a community payback order and sex offenders register, with a special programme for offenders; a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing subsequently found his conduct incompatible with being a registered teacher, removed him from the teaching register, noted a prolonged pattern of offending with no remedial action, and barred him from re-registering for two years.

Firefighters spent days at the Duncan Street site after a 2 March blaze that disrupted train services and travel. The Environment Agency revoked the environmental permit of Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited (run by Asset and Land Group) and suspended its waste acceptance; the firm can appeal by 7 August, after which it will be unable to operate from the site, though it must still remove all waste. GMFRS noted the site operators were broadly compliant with fire safety laws over the past year, while raising concerns in February about impacts on residents, transport, and the environment, which led to joint fire service and EA visits and enforcement action. The fire’s exact cause remains undetermined.

Syria’s deputy foreign minister said the country is trying to meet its timetable to destroy chemical weapons, noting missed deadlines and that shipments faced attacks en route to the coast; he defended Syria’s actions amid ongoing war, accusing the US of supporting terrorists, and claimed Damascus is defending civilian areas while rejecting claims of burning civilians in Aleppo and asserting government control over Aleppo’s prison against rebels, as international bodies like OPCW and the UN press for timely destruction of Syria’s declared stockpile of about 1,300 tonnes with only a small portion shipped so far.

England won the series-clinching fourth Test at Old Trafford by a large margin, with England declaring 589-8 and 173-1 and Pakistan bowled out for 234 in the first innings and 198 in the second; Joe Root starred, scoring 254 and 71*, taking four catches and a wicket, and being praised for moving to number three and delivering a dominant all-round performance, while Alastair Cook lauded his leadership and form. England’s bowlers and fielding were disciplined as Pakistan struggled on a pitch offering little assistance, leading to Pakistan’s low totals; Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq were the only Pakistan players to reach 50 in the early tests, and Misbah rued the missed chances and lack of confidence, with plans to regroup ahead of the third Test at Edgbaston.

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, plans to gather experiences from pensioners, their friends and families about residential care in Wales to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies as part of her review of quality of life and care in residential settings; the review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and care home environment, listen to care providers and public bodies, and aim to ensure high-quality life for older residents, though Care Forum Wales notes the advisory panel lacks a provider expert with direct residential care experience.

Former Dons midfielder Paul Sheerin, 39, who has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, is set to become Aberdeen’s new manager after being selected by Derek McInnes in a comprehensive process; Aberdeen’s chief executive noted Sheerin’s departure comes despite the club’s desire to retain him, with Arbroath chairman appreciating his wish to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has played for multiple Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s, and led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011; Arbroath had been relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season.

Curtis and Paul Williams will oversee Swansea’s Saturday match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley’s departure, while ex-Derby manager Paul Clement is the leading candidate to be appointed soon; Curtis stresses the need for a manager who can help the club avoid relegation, notes the Championship’s strength and the challenge of returning to the top flight, and argues Swansea has lost its best era and the “Swansea Way” due to frequent management changes and missing key players, though he believes the current squad is capable of staying up and reminds new signings of the club’s rise and history to motivate them.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, turned human genome mapping into a competitive race, earning criticism from the scientific community yet accelerating genomics progress; after the genome's publication, he shifted to creating a synthetic life form, Synthia, through the J. Craig Venter Institute he founded, following a career that began with NIH work, a pivotal move to private research, and the 1998 launch of Celera Genomics to crack the human genome faster than public efforts, a venture that alongside his open-data debates, brought both acclaim and controversy, and later led to ambitious projects such as sequencing marine microbes and pursuing synthetic biology’s potential to transform industry and energy use.

The Sutton Trust, citing a Boston Consulting Group study, warns that many English apprenticeships are low quality, short, and skew toward older workers, with only a small share at level three or higher; compared with Germany, England offers fewer apprenticeships, more low-level and 25+ targeted programs, and a sprawling 18,000 qualifications versus Germany’s 330. The report calls for radical expansion to up to 300,000 starts annually, emphasizing that most should be level three for at least three years (with some level four), while limiting two-year level-two roles to under 10%; it argues that without high-quality, well-valued vocational routes, social mobility and economic competitiveness suffer. The Association of Colleges and employers acknowledge some respected apprenticeships but warn expansion is challenging amid current shortages, and the Department for Education maintains ongoing reforms to raise standards, rigour, and employer relevance, including a minimum one-year duration, more English and maths, and broader reform plans forthcoming.

The Briton, Storey, won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska, as she looks to claim a 17th title in Saturday's road race and chase further Paralympic success at Rio 2016; she is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals (11 gold, eight silver, three bronze) across six Games in cycling and swimming, having won 21 world titles to date, and began in swimming, switching to cycling in 2005 after winning six swimming medals at the 1992 Paralympics.

Hereford United faced severe financial problems that led to their expulsion from the Conference Premier after failing to meet a debt payment deadline, despite late-season efforts that had kept them up on the final day; Chester City were expelled and reformed as Chester FC, taking Hereford’s spot, while Chester’s Kingsley James moved to Hereford’s former ground amid the drama. The club’s debts totaled around £148,000 to football creditors and roughly £225,000 overall, with more than £70,000 owed to HMRC, and escalating ownership turmoil culminated in London businessman Tommy Agombar taking over and the Conference ultimately expelling Hereford after extended payment deadlines; fan efforts and offers, including the Hereford United Supporters' Trust bid, were not chosen, and attendance had fallen sharply from previous years.

James Milner, a former Manchester City midfielder, earned 61 England caps after debuting in 2009 and was part of squads for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016; he also holds the England Under-21 record with 46 caps, debuted in 2004, and scored his only international goal in England’s 5-0 World Cup qualifier win over Moldova in 2014, with Milner expressing a wish for success for Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters.

Christopher Hogwood died at his Cambridge home after a months-long illness; his funeral will be private with a memorial service planned later. He was a leading figure in the early-music movement, founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed it for about 30 years, contributing to over 200 CDs including a complete Mozart symphonies cycle on period instruments. His notable recordings include Handel's Messiah (1980) with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, acclaimed by BBC Music Magazine. He studied keyboard at Cambridge, worked with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, and helped found the Early Music Consort of London; he held roles as artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston Handel and Haydn Society, and served as tutor at Harvard, honorary professor at Cambridge, and professor-at-large at Cornell. Colleagues described him as generous, a great ambassador for historically informed music, and his legacy continues in the AAM and its musicians.

A Northern Ireland family must continuously fight to secure a place for their non-verbal child with special needs at a local special school, after removing him from mainstream schooling due to coping difficulties; all South Eastern Education Board area special schools are full with no time frame for a vacancy, despite a temporary classroom assistant being added in hopes of starting soon, while the Education Authority notes it is reviewing needs to provide nearby, available places and cannot discuss individual cases.

Newport Gwent Dragons are facing a takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union, which aims to view Rodney Parade as a rugby venue, with existing leaseholders County FC retaining primacy on fixtures until 2023; the WRU’s proposal will be voted on May 9, while Newport RFC chairman notes both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under current agreements, and the WRU has signalled plans to install an artificial surface that violates Football League rules. County currently sit two points above the League Two relegation zone with two games left, and Newport, promoted to the Football League in 2013, warn that relegation would be devastating for fans and the city of Newport.

A Sierra Leonean man describes surviving the civil war (kidnapped by RUF in 1991, brutal indoctrination, drug use, killing and atrocities) and eventually escaping to Freetown, where he reinvented himself with the help of a preacher who encouraged leadership and service. During the 2014 Ebola outbreak, he helped transform a community clinic into an Ebola response effort, focusing on education (reaching over 10,000 people in multiple languages), providing food and supplies to around 11,000 people, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit with others, which saved many lives. He reflects on personal transformation, regrets past actions, and emphasizes investing in and leading youth to rebuild Sierra Leone and influence the world.

A public fundraising campaign raised the target in a month to avert selling about 80,000 items from the Wedgwood collection to pay the firm’s pension debt; the collection will stay on display at the museum in Barlaston and is being gifted by the Art Fund to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. Administrators noted the outcome as highly satisfactory, crediting goodwill and negotiations, and Alison Wedgwood emphasized the collection’s importance for Staffordshire, warning that without the funds it could have been sold and scattered globally; Tristram Hunt welcomed the news, saying the items reflect Britain’s cultural development and national identity.

Dan Groves indicated the finer points of a deal for Wright to buy a 20% stake are still to be released, with reports that he could become a club director; the club, Billericay, are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points from a playoff spot. Wright, known for being runner-up on I’m a Celebrity in 2011, has a background in non-league football with clubs such as Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club has been taken over by Glenn Tamplin, who described his £10,000-a-week investment as “comfortable,” and they also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in early March.

Mark Carney surprised by proposing a one-year extension as Bank of England governor instead of staying to 2021 or leaving in 2018, driven by a combination of Brexit timing and personal family considerations. He faced a choice between continuing through the Brexit negotiations or returning to Canada; his private discussions indicated a “third way” would be a short extension to provide market certainty while his daughters complete important exams, with plans to return to Canada afterward. Theresa May supported extending to 2021, but Carney emphasized the decision was personal and not a signal of policy shifts, noting 2018 departure would align with the Article 50 process, after which a new Governor would take over.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1 after Jamille Matt gave Blackpool an early lead with a close-range finish, while Kurtis Guthrie equalised for Colchester from a corner. The hosts spurned a chance to retake the lead when Tom Aldred headed wide from eight yards late in the game, and Colchester finished with ten men after Sean Murray was sent off for violent conduct in stoppage time, following a foul on Jim McAlister.

Healthy Me, a programme by Action Mental Health, helps P6/P7 pupils cope with change and stress related to transferring to secondary school through interactive workshops that raise awareness of emotional wellbeing, encourage seeking help, and identify support sources; the initiative also trains teachers and was piloted in five schools, with Carrick Primary launching it locally to ease anxiety around transition, reinforce coping techniques like breathing and relaxation, and support parents, while recognizing the broader need to build resilience in Northern Ireland’s education system amid changing social contexts and rising transfer test numbers.

Developers plan to convert the disused Fawley power station chimney into the centerpiece of a £1bn “merchant city” development at Fawley Waterside, featuring a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth, with outline planning permission expected later this year and construction possible from 2018. The oil-fired station, commissioned in 1971 on Southampton Water’s western shore, powered up to one million homes and had a 300-acre site sold to the developers in 2016, with the 197-metre chimney proposed to remain as a signature landmark and the project likened to other iconic towers like the i360 or Spinnaker Tower.

GB secured a bronze via Latham in the men's scratch at the Hong Kong championships, with Teklinski (Poland) taking gold and Liss (Germany) silver; Latham praised his late sprint after following Felix English. In other events, Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-finals, GB finished fifth in the women's team pursuit heats, and Olympic medallist Elinor Barker joined a young GB quartet who did not medal but remain optimistic about future improvements. Katy Marchant was eliminated in the women's sprint, with two events remaining; she expressed disappointment but emphasized ongoing preparation toward Tokyo.

Ross Kemp reprises Grant Mitchell for a brief return to EastEnders to reunite with his brother Phil and say goodbye to their mother, Peggy Mitchell, whose cancer storyline led to her death in the spring; Kemp cites the opportunity to bring the Mitchell brothers together and reflect on their family history, noting his pride in returning for classic moments with old loves and confronting their mother’s loss.

Sadio Mane scored twice as Spurs, who have struggled on the road and away from big opponents, were outplayed at Anfield, prompting Mauricio Pochettino to criticize a lack of fight and desire to win; he warns that slipping further behind Chelsea could become a major problem, while pundits noted Spurs’ inconsistent defensive structure and mindset against top-six sides.

The APC won 19 of 28 governorships, marking a major defeat for the PDP, which won eight governorships and retained Lagos; Buhari will be inaugurated on May 29, after defeating Jonathan. APC made historic gains, dominating the north and Lagos, but failing to win in any of the five oil-producing states, raising concerns about oil revenue and militancy. The PDP’s decline followed defections and corruption allegations, with violence marred elections in some areas, though overall the vote suggested a maturing democracy.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis (July 19–22) will offer an augmented reality app that triggers online information from signs and posters, with videos and band interviews available to view on phones and tablets, expanding access to the festival’s atmosphere worldwide by updating messages during the event to allow instant information access, interviews, and ticket purchases alongside performances by acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.

Several Birmingham academies and schools, including Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School, were rated inadequate by Ofsted and face termination of their funding agreements or warnings to address concerns; Park View and Nansen’s funding is under threat with directives to address breaches such as discriminatory practices, segregation, and weak safeguarding, while Oldknow and Golden Hillock received similar warnings and required actions by a July deadline. The Ofsted reports describe a “culture of fear and intimidation,” targeted attempts to impose a narrow faith-based ideology, and inadequate management of extremism and external speakers, prompting responses from the Department for Education, local authorities, and school leaders who express hopes to improve and, for some, to challenge the findings.

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was sentenced to five years in Tehran for alleged plotting to topple the government; her husband Richard criticizes UK action and says the appeal is being held in secret, with the hearing uncertain and potentially held in Tehran, while Nazanin has faced solitary confinement, hunger strikes, and a deteriorating family situation including their two-year-old daughter Gabriella, who remains in Iran with grandparents after Nazanin’s arrest at the airport; her appeal could result in a quashing, reduction, or increase of the sentence, and supporters, including Amnesty International UK, call for her immediate release as a prisoner of conscience.

Vinnie Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich; the prosecution claims eye specialist Honey Rose’s conduct was so far below standard it was criminal, alleging she failed to detect swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation, a preventable death caused by increased brain pressure from a buildup of fluid, while Rose denies gross negligence manslaughter, with the court hearing that her alleged professional failings were central to the case.

Clive Weatherhogg arranged meetings between a woman and a man he found via an adult website and filmed them having sex; he sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim’s sister on Christmas Day and was placed on the sex offenders register. He was found guilty of coercing the woman into sexual activity with the man between September 2013 and September 2014, and of causing the woman’s sister and father to view sexual images and of threatening or abusive behavior on December 25, 2014. He denied the charges but was convicted after a trial at Dundee Sheriff Court, with the case remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing, as it has greater sentencing powers. He was described as a first offender assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending, and his remand ahead of sentencing was called a dramatic shock by defence counsel. The judge emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting society’s abhorrence.

Ireland scored 165-5 led by Stuart Thompson’s 56, with Gary Wilson (41*) and captain William Porterfield (39); Afghanistan chased 171-4, powered by Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) to win with two overs to spare, as Amir Hamza took 2-23 for Afghanistan. Ireland’s early setback included Paul Stirling’s duck, and Boyd Rankin’s back issue further hampered them; Porterfield lamented not reaching 180, while Afghanistan’s bats dominated as they cruised to victory.

Barcelona defended its Neymar transfer, arguing it did not commit any offence while acknowledging complex contract interpretations and potential tax responsibilities. The club stated Neymar cost £106.8m when including initial fee, signing-on, wages, agents’ fees, and a recent tax payment, with Neymar’s parents receiving £34m of the fee. Despite this, there are ongoing investigations and a judge ruled there is sufficient evidence to continue probing the transfer; former president Sandro Rosell resigned amid related accusations of misappropriation. Barcelona has made a voluntary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover possible divergent tax interpretations, while insisting the original tax payment aligned with their fiscal obligations, and it remains unclear if the case will be dropped. Neymar had seven league goals in 18 appearances and three Champions League goals in seven matches.

UK detectives reviewing the Koh Tao murders of Hannah Witheridge and David Miller, who died on 15 September, completed their on-site work in Thailand with Thai police and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families; two Burmese (Myanmar) migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21, are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery, and have allegedly confessed, though Thai police have denied inconsistent reports of retractions, while DNA evidence linked to the suspects and post-mortem findings show Miller drowned with a head blow and Witheridge died from head wounds; the UK Foreign Office has raised concerns about the investigation, including DNA verification and mistreatment allegations, and the visit followed a request for British assistance after discussions between UK PM Cameron and Thai leadership.

VR is increasingly used to enhance understanding of the world by embedding it in reality for journalism, education, healthcare, and retail. Examples include autism and dementia outreach via VR films in the UK, virtual tours for real estate and shopping, Ikea’s VR kitchen app, and healthcare uses like live virtual surgeries and PTSD treatment. Google Expeditions and classroom trials aim to broaden learning experiences, while researchers and industry leaders see VR as a powerful educational tool, though cost and accessibility remain barriers for widespread adoption.

The black box from the Su-24 was opened in Moscow to examine missing flight data that could clarify where the jet was hit; an analysis is expected next week. The incident worsened Russia-Turkey relations, with Russia sanctioning Turkey and Turkey claiming the jet violated its airspace, while Russia says it was shot down in Syria. The downing occurred on 24 November, after which both crew members ejected; the pilot was killed and the navigator was rescued, a Russian rescue marine was killed, and a ground-based helicopter was destroyed. Russia has demanded an apology and has imposed sanctions, including a ban on package holidays.

Scotland’s women’s team has won all five qualifiers and will host Iceland at Falkirk with victory likely securing a major finals spot, as they aim to avoid the devastating heartbreak of previous play-off losses; Iceland sit one place higher and are unbeaten after four wins, making the upcoming Friday match and a return in September pivotal to who tops the group, while the best six of eight runners-up may also reach the finals in the Netherlands, with Evans and Gemma Fay emphasizing the emotional milestone and stepping-stone progress, and noting the role of a strong foreign-based cohort (five in England, four in Sweden, two in the NWSL) and the benefits of playing in top leagues like Bayern Munich to raise Scotland’s competitiveness.

The commission evaluating local tax reform in Scotland states there is no single fix for the council tax’s flaws, acknowledging that the system has structural problems since day one and that delaying reforms has increased policy challenges. Prof. Kenneth Gibb’s review of international tax systems notes that property taxes are common and seen as stable and hard to evade but can confuse taxpayers about whether they are a wealth tax or a service charge, and can be unfair if not linked to income; a local income tax is often seen as fairer but creates revenue volatility for local authorities and limits ability to adjust rates locally. The report emphasizes that reform is complex and linked to past reforms, and that changing the council tax would be a major undertaking. The commission plans public consultation across Scotland and aims to publish its autumn report, while the Scottish government regards the current system as unfair and continues to pursue fairer alternatives with local government partners.

The passage discusses how third-party tools were used to access iCloud backups and intimate photos, and describes Apple's two-step/now two-factor authentication (2FA) as a defensive measure that can block access if the code is not entered or a trusted device is not used; it notes the system remains opt-in, with recovery keys as a backup, and that recent changes now require notification when a backup starts. It mentions Elcomsoft’s software as a potential risk and acknowledges that experts differ on whether 2FA should be default, with calls for default 2FA and stronger passwords across companies, while Apple aims to encourage broader 2FA use and awareness.

UKIP spent £2,956,737 on the campaign (68p per vote for 4,376,635 votes), the Conservatives £2,980,815 (79p per vote for their 3,764,? votes), Labour £1,027,339 (26p per vote), the Lib Dems £1,580,575 (lost 11 of 12 MEPs), and the Green Party £534,249 (43p per vote for 1,255,573 votes), with SNP adding £267,372; together the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087, and all parties except Labour spent more than in the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join another National League side, with potential to face his former club on 18 February, while striker Keating, 21, was recommended to boss Kevin Nicholson and has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps; Nicholson described Myles as a leader-type and Ruairi as hungry but raw, as the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham, suffering a severe pulmonary haemorrhage; the BHA stated such episodes are rare and can occur even without underlying health issues, and while questions exist about whether prior overheating episodes were related, the report concludes the death was due to a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick and veteran MSPs Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Annabel Goldie are stepping down ahead of the 5 May election; Salmond, a former first minister, delivered a valedictory address stressing Scotland’s diversity rather than division, the parliament’s growing responsibility and the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill, while joking about Cheltenham and wishing colleagues luck. Marwick thanked Salmond and was moved to tears by McNeil’s farewell, whose speech urged Holyrood to learn from Westminster’s committee system to ensure accountability, scrutiny, and opposition when needed. Goldie also bowed out, joking about missing dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage announces casting details for a live-action Beauty and the Beast film: Mrs Potts will be played by the star who voiced her in the 1991 animated version, Dame Angela Lansbury; Kevin Kline joins as Maurice; Emma Watson is cast as Belle; Dan Stevens as the Beast; Luke Evans as Gaston; Josh Gad as LeFou; and Bill Condon will direct, with filming starting at Shepperton Studios in May, ahead of a US release on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service will announce its intentions in a private Warrington meeting with Hillsborough victims’ relatives, following new inquests that concluded the fans were unlawfully killed; 23 suspects’ evidence has been referred to the CPS for potential charges—15 connected to the Operation Resolve inquiry into the disaster and 8 to an IPCC probe into police conduct—while families, including Margaret Aspinall, express cautious anticipation and insist on accountability as they continue their long struggle.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of contraband being hurled over its wall, with residents and a former inmate alleging the facility is flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis and that drones were used to deliver items, though the Ministry of Justice says there is no evidence of drone use and notes staff work hard to stop contraband; authorities acknowledge the problem and say new laws can jail smugglers for up to two years, while the Justice Secretary has asked for tools to better tackle this issue.

A 72-year-old lollipop lady, Sylvia Blackburn, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a VW Golf that failed to stop at a red light; the driver, Brian Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, while expressing remorse as the case continues in Luton Crown Court.

Eilidh Muir will miss the Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast due to exams in her final year of veterinary studies, choosing academics over the April event despite her commitment to Scotland; she finished 4th and 6th in the 1500m and 5000m at the World Athletics Championships with a personal best outdoor time of 14:52.07, expressing optimism for future Olympics and considering the World Indoor Championships as a potential target, while aiming to compete in Birmingham and balancing a demanding upcoming schedule.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared after leaving a Christmas party in December 2000; a weeks-long search began in a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, with planned excavations and a Garda review of his case ongoing. CCTV from the night he went missing shows him talking to a man in black outside Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, and detectives believe this man may have followed Deely to Haddington Road shortly after; the man has not yet been identified and investigators renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Del Potro fought back to beat Stan Wawrinka 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 in a Wimbledon match, securing his first Grand Slam victory since 2014 after multiple wrist surgeries and bringing his ranking to 165; he is in the same half as Andy Murray and could face Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next. Nick Kyrgios also advanced, overcoming Dustin Brown in five sets to reach the third round, with Feliciano Lopez next up to play Kyrgios and potentially Murray or John Millman in the last 16; other seeds Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga won their matches, while Del Potro expressed joy and relief after overcoming years of injury.

The passage covers Tunisia’s apologies to Caf to resolve a dispute over its 2017 Nations Cup participation after a contentious episode involving a late penalty against Equatorial Guinea in 2015, as well as Equatorial Guinea stepping in to host that year and Cas’s overturning of a Caf ruling against Morocco, reducing its fine and allowing its return to the 2017 qualifying draw. It notes Morocco’s return after a brief break and prior punishment for refusing to host in 2015, and Tunisia’s ongoing bid for a 13th consecutive Nations Cup appearance, with group placements announced for the 2017 finals in Gabon and reflections from Tunisian officials that the dispute has been ironed out.

McLaren, once dominant with 182 wins, 12 drivers’ titles, and eight constructors’ titles, has fallen from grace, currently languishing in the lower rows despite having two world champions (including Alonso) and a car that shows signs of mojo; the slump since 2013 stems from chassis issues and now Honda power-unit problems, marking a stark contrast to their golden era with Senna-Prost, Hakkinen and Mercedes, and despite Dennis’s optimism that McLaren will break Mercedes’ hegemony and win championships again, at present belief is all they have as they navigate a challenging period amid past scandals and a history of cycles of triumph and decline.

Paraters attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014; police found alcohol being served as late as 04:49 BST, leading to the judge ordering the bar’s closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours; both admitted the licensing laws were not strictly adhered to, with the judge noting an appalling record and poor management. O'Neill received a £3,000 fine and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry eclipsed his own NBA single-season 3-point record by making eight triples to reach 272, finishing with 45 points as the Golden State Warriors rallied from 13 down to beat the Portland Trail Blazers 116-105, aided by Klay Thompson's 26 points; the win helped Golden State avoid a three-game skid, while LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 for Portland. In other games, Pau Gasol posted 16 points and 15 rebounds as the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, overcoming a 19-point halftime deficit, with Derrick Rose contributing 12 points as he continued his comeback and the Bulls moved to No. 3 in the East; Hassan Whiteside had 19 and 16 for the Heat, who were outscored 57-27 after halftime.

YouTube free-kick sensation Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at Melwood, initially believed to be a fan competition winner, but soon impressed them with his dead-ball skills, scoring a top-corner free-kick and showcasing why he has become a viral sensation; the experience was described as amazing by van Velzen, who enjoyed meeting the players and joking about Balotelli’s infamous slogan from his 6-1 win over United in 2011.

A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations found that undergoing oophorectomy after diagnosis significantly lowered death from breast cancer—by about 62% for BRCA1 carriers and with a total death reduction of 65% from all causes—particularly benefiting BRCA1 carriers and those with estrogen-receptor negative cancers, with the protective effect lasting up to 15 years and often completed around six years after diagnosis; Angelina Jolie, a BRCA1 carrier who had both mastectomy and oophorectomy, exemplifies this approach, which may improve survival and is suggested as part of treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers.

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, both 38 and 33, were killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina, as they lingered on or near the tracks; the northbound Amtrak Carolinian (train no. 80) from Charlotte to New York City struck them on property owned by Norfolk Southern, and 166 passengers on board were not injured, though one man who fell ill during a two hour and 45 minute delay received treatment. The couple, who may have lived in a homeless camp, were seen with a grocery cart and few items, and a bystander urged kindness toward those in dire straits; the train continued on its route after the delay.

An informant who spent 27 years working for the DEA as an undercover operative, originally a former Medellín cartel member who fled Colombia, helped the DEA arrest major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega and carried out worldwide undercover stings, but after retiring due to health issues he faces deportation and remains in limbo without citizenship or social security benefits, despite promises of U.S. citizenship and repeated pleas for relief; his former handler and colleagues defend him as having paid his dues, while Toro fears returning to Colombia and contends the government has effectively sentenced him to death.

The passage explains that a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., is launching the ".sucks" top-level domain to host domains featuring names of celebrities and major brands, which has led to calls for regulatory scrutiny. ICANN and industry advisory groups warned this could be a coercive, predatory “shakedown” scheme, as the service charges around $2,499 per year for ownership of a name (with resellers often selling near that price) and plans to offer the option to secure a ".sucks" address for about $10 per year starting September; high-profile individuals like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have spent money to remove their names from such domains, while others like YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have been targeted. ICANN indicated regulators could deem Vox Populi’s actions illegal and potentially breach its contract, prompting possible remedies.

A mother, who had concealed a stillbirth from her family, was arrested 27 years after her baby boy’s body was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, after DNA matched a possible relative leading to her identification; the baby, initially unnamed, was later named Peter by a local group, the charge of infanticide was dropped, and authorities concluded no foul play occurred, with the baby reburied in St Peter’s Church and a new headstone placed.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was found to have unlawfully imprisoned passenger Kristopher Hicks after driving him back to the taxi rank to “teach him a lesson,” causing Hicks to jump from the moving car at over 20 mph and suffer severe brain injuries. In the High Court, judge Mr Justice Edis ruled Hicks is entitled to damages, with liability established against Young, though the exact amount will be decided later and is expected to be about half of Hicks’ initial claim (plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment). Hicks now requires round-the-clock care for life, has post-traumatic epilepsy and other ongoing health issues, and his family seeks compensation to fund rehabilitation and care. Both sides have appealed, awaiting a further hearing to determine the final damages.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as several storms produced reported tornadoes, including a sighting about 6 miles northwest of Goddard near Wichita and additional sightings near Aetna, Kansas, with storms moving northeast and posing risk to other communities; overnight storms were warned as dangerous, with the potential for more storms across the Midwest, Mississippi River valley, Tennessee River valley, and near the southern Great Lakes, alongside reports of wind damage, flooding, and hail from Missouri to nearby areas.

Luke Rockhold prepares to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey, aiming for a fourth straight win and a potential title shot. He says he will be the bull to Machida’s matador, plan to cut off Machida, push the pace, exploit holes he’s noticed, and rely on a complete mixed martial arts game including takedowns, kicks, and punches. Rockhold believes Machida is strong on the feet with limited ground options, and asserts he will operate at a higher frequency, disrupt Machida’s rhythm, and dominate the fight, while maintaining mutual respect for Machida’s skills. Machida, confident he can upset Rockhold and earn a title shot, believes applying his style and technique could stop Rockhold, and notes he trained for eight weeks with a calm, well-prepared camp.

A light general aviation Aerostar aircraft touched down on a Florida runway without its landing gear, scraping along the tarmac on its belly while its propellers hit the surface and appeared damaged; the pilot briefly regained control, re-engaged engines, and managed a high-angle takeoff before continuing to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely about 100 miles away, with the incident prompting FAA investigation and described as likely caused by human error or a mechanical fault.

Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment with Yaya Toure’s performances but said he will back the midfielder until the end of the season, as City consider overhauling an aging squad and may listen to offers for Toure in the summer; Toure, on a £220,000-a-week contract at 31, has faced criticism amid City’s defensive collapse, while captain Vincent Kompany misses time with injury, Joe Hart asserted the squad must take responsibility for underwhelming results, and Hart noted Pellegrini has the dressing-room backing, though Pellegrini insists choices rest with him; in related transfer chatter, Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cresswell against following other English players to City, given homegrown quotas, as City explore potential signings from West Ham.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the godfather of Uxbridge, has lived in the UK for over 20 years and was sentenced in absentia in Italy in 1999 to seven years for mafia association. Although an extradition to serve that sentence was pursued, the sentence expired in October 2014 because Italian law extinguishes a sentence after more than double its term, and the European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn; the case still may go to the Italian supreme court. The CPS initially erred in proceedings and serving papers on time, but Italian authorities have indicated the warrant will be withdrawn, allowing Rancadore to remain in the UK with his family.

Mr Mole, trained by AP McCoy’s trainer Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson’s Sacre, to be ridden by Nico de Boinville in the absence of injured Barry Geraghty; the race will be McCoy’s final Grade One appearance, with his rides for the day not finalised until Friday morning, following his February victory at Newbury that led to his decision to retire, and other contenders include Mick Channon’s Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, mother of Marcia who was raped and strangled in 1975, recounts the horror of finally viewing crime scene photos of her daughter after decades of denial; Marcia’s body was found 33 days after she disappeared, in a cluttered, windowless Nashville garage, with signs of sexual assault, strangulation, and other injuries, and cookies scattered around. Jerome Sidney Barrett was later convicted of Marcia’s second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years; he had also been implicated in other offenses and was found via DNA on Marcia’s clothing, after being arrested in connection with another 1975 murder. Ritter had discouraged viewing the photos but decided to see them, expressing anger and a desire for revenge.

Rory McIlroy says winning the Masters to complete the career Grand Slam is an unthinkable, career-long goal and a milestone that would place him among golf’s all-time greats; he reflects on his 2011 Augusta collapse as the pivotal learning moment that shaped his approach, notes his past Masters struggles and recent major successes, and emphasizes Augusta as a sanctuary where he hopes to handle pressure and achieve multiple majors, starting with a first green jacket this year.

A roundup of this week’s top trending stories includes: four rainbows over the New York area photographed by Amanda Curtis after heavy rainfall; rural China’s increasing use of exotic dancers at wakes as part of a crackdown on vice; RDJ’s frustration during a Channel 4 interview about his private life; the ongoing rise of trends, notably lip plumping using a jar to imitate Kylie Jenner; 102-year-old Alice Barker’s time-travel inspiration with filmmakers; a prom-posal controversy over a bomb reference and accusations of racism; news that Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp’s near-unrecognizable look in the Black Mass trailer; announcing pregnancy by referencing The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air; and a military dad’s photobomb with his son—these were all popular on social media this week.

The passage reports alarming figures on foetal alcohol syndrome in the UK: 272 children who were disabled by foetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England over the past year, with experts warning the true number is likely higher; WHO research suggests about 1 in 100 UK babies could suffer alcohol-related learning, behavioral, and physical problems, equating to around 7,500 affected annually; cases are under-diagnosed and not improving, as illustrated by 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who requires assistance and will not live independently; the Foetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder Trust was founded to help others, and associated medical issues include liver, kidney, heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy; while government guidance advises pregnant women not to drink, with a maximum of up to two units twice a week, there is a call from experts to advise no alcohol at all during pregnancy.

An axe-wielding robber named Shaun Andrew McKerry was jailed for six years after a failed attempt to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15, when shop owner Sab Dhillon tackled him and his wife Sam Dhillon hit McKerry twice with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him; McKerry, previously an ex-juvenile offender known as “boomerang boy” or “homing pigeon boy,” has a long history of shoplifting and other crimes dating back to his teens, earning him notorious nicknames for returning to crime and repeatedly evading long prison terms in the past.

Four Royal Navy sailors were charged with sexual assault and group sexual assault in Nova Scotia after an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks; they appeared in Dartmouth court, were granted bail with strict conditions including surrendering passports and living at Stadacona base, and must remain employed by the Navy while awaiting trial, which could carry up to 14 years in prison, with potential additional charges as forensic tests proceed.

A Las Vegas mother, Valerie Jackson, cares for her four-year-old son RJ, one of about 70 people worldwide with Netherton's syndrome, a rare congenital skin disease causing red, scaly, painful skin and other issues. Misunderstandings about the condition led a member of the public to report her to police for child abuse, resulting in armed officers surrounding them in a store; the incident highlights widespread ignorance and social stigma, including taunts and denial of entry to play centers. Despite intense caregiving—regularly applying creams, baths, and Vaseline—RJ faces bullying and misperceptions, though his mother remains proud and hopeful that greater awareness will improve his life, while noting there is no cure and that symptoms may improve with time.

The London Underground pulled down Protein World's controversial “Are you beach body ready?” posters featuring a bikini-clad model after public outcry from feminists, body-image campaigners, and thousands of online complaints, though the company defended the campaign as promoting fitness and confidence; the ad period ended, TFL noted, and they would consider future requests, while the ASA investigates and protests and counter-reactions, including a planned Hyde Park rally, continued across social media amid broader concerns about unrealistic body standards and potential threats to the company.

Rail firms planned fare hikes of up to 87% on routes including London to the Cotswolds, angering Prime Minister David Cameron who urged First Great Western to urgently review the decision as it would affect his Witney constituency; despite pledges by Cameron and Labour to freeze or cap prices, unregulated fares—affecting about half of revenue—are set to rise across several routes, with some cheaper advance-purchase options available, while Virgin notes most increases apply to Virgin Trains-only fares and industry-wide average fare increases remain modest; the controversy centers on a clash between announced price rises and party commitments to freezes.

A 66-year-old former soldier, John Young, and his 54-year-old wife Elaine were at home in Oldham when vandals threw bricks at their living room window and then directly at John as he opened the front door to confront them; he was struck in the left eye by a brick, suffered a forehead wound, and despite emergency surgery, lost the sight in one eye, leaving him blind in that eye and fearing for his safety at home. The attack, which occurred three weeks after their wedding, appeared to have no stated motive and police described it as potentially yobs messing around; they are seeking witnesses and information to identify those involved. The couple, who had recently married, are now fearing to remain in their neighbourhood and plan to move.

Tom Poynton, Derbyshire's wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension through 2016 after a successful return from a leg injury that kept him out for the 2014 season following his father's death in a road accident; he made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi, has shown good form since returning to training, and the club hopes the new deal will boost his confidence and allow him to express himself this summer.

A five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw of Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma affecting his kidney, neck, lungs and bones, underwent extensive treatment including chemotherapy, kidney tumor removal, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, and decorated his protective radiotherapy mask with a ninja turtle theme to cope; after a year of treatment, he has been declared cancer-free and now faces regular check-ups, with his bravery earning him recognition and support from Nickelodeon and Cancer Research UK.

Tim Sherwood urges Jack Grealish to focus on his Aston Villa career first and secure regular first-team appearances before considering his international future, emphasizing that the decision about whether to play for Ireland or England should come from Grealish’s heart and personal choice after he has proven himself more for Villa; Grealish has been impressive in Villa’s FA Cup win over Liverpool and faces a potential tug-of-war between Ireland and England, with his father and Sherwood advising him to keep prioritizing club football as he develops.

The passage explains that landing fees at airports for private jets vary widely and can be very high, reflecting a luxury industry frequented by the wealthy. It notes growing private-jet travel, large market values in the US and Europe, and peak periods around major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix. It provides specific fee examples from various airports, with Tokyo Haneda being the most expensive, followed by Narita and Kansai, and lists other top airports in Europe, Canada, Australia, and the US, including Dublin, Bristol, LaGuardia, Salzburg, and Darwin. It also mentions popular routes and the use of the 767-400 for fee comparisons.

Katie Gallegos took her dog Cooper and his friend Daisy to McDonald’s for ice cream; while Daisy licks politely, Cooper eats the entire cone in one bite, a habit Gallegos says is normal for him and keeps Daisy fed first. The video of Cooper’s fast-eating outings has garnered over seven million views, and a separate clip shows the pair at Starbucks where Cooper similarly gulps a pup-uccino, which Gallegos explains is just whipped cream without coffee. Some viewers call it cute or hilarious, while others criticize the feeding; Gallegos defends it, noting Cooper is healthy and that Daisy is smaller and gets only occasional bites.

Gary Locke has been appointed permanently as Kilmarnock's manager on a three-year deal after an successful interim spell, during which he has lost only one of seven games since taking over from Allan Johnston; he joined the club as assistant last summer and took control in February, with a press conference planned for Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, says teachers at Seminole County Elementary threatened to remove her five-year-old autistic son Logan from class because the essential-oils he wears (lavender, chamomile, sandalwood) to help him stay calm and focused have a smell that distracts other students; she applies the oils to his head and neck, and despite a school board letter calling the oils a “problem,” the school district later stated they would not suspend Logan, citing a health issue, while Kemp plans to continue advocating for the use of the oils.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, the Sandpiper, which operates between May and November, was obliterated by a blaze that spread through 90 condos, caused smoke to pour toward the ocean, and melted paint on nearby buildings, with flames visible from miles away as twelve fire crews and cranes battled the fire but could not enter the summer homes; the cause is under investigation, and residents and the building manager who lived there lost everything.

The passage describes the Queen riding a black Fell pony named Carltonlima Emma in Windsor Great Park, continuing her lifelong love of horses despite knee issues and a history of not wearing riding helmets in favor of silk scarves; it notes her long association with horses, including breeding Fell ponies and Highland ponies at Hampton Court and Balmoral, her early start with a Shetland pony named Peggy at age four, and her role in a family tradition where grandchildren also ride some horses, while providing background on the Fell pony breed’s history from Neolithic times through Roman, Viking, and Norman influences to its modern use as a riding pony popular with families.

A Brisbane neighbour dispute over noise ended with 55-year-old Leon Yeaman dead and 28-year-old Phillip Pama charged with manslaughter after Yeaman was punched once; Pama, who works a 3 am shift and was allegedly provoked by Yeaman’s loud behavior, fled the scene but later appeared in Brisbane Magistrates Court where he was granted conditional bail with restrictions, as the case proceeds to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old Russian music teacher, Yulia Simonova, who had lavished gifts on her teenage pupil Damian Vanya, sought to hire a hitman to torture and kill him after he ended their relationship; police set up a sting, with an undercover officer posing as a killer, and filmed Simonova arranging a brutal assault and asking to bleed him out and finish him, after which she paid some expenses and was arrested. She now faces up to 15 years in prison for attempted murder.

Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho says he talks to God every day but never about football or with his wife, prays for personal life things only, and separates his professional and family life; he believes in God, goes to church only when he feels the need and mainly in Portugal, and has supported the World Food Programme as an ambassador against hunger, while acknowledging his competitive and emotional professional life and describing himself as a good family person and friend.

Bob Barker returned to The Price Is Right for an episode on April 1, stepping in to host the first game, Lucky Seven, before handing duties back to current host Drew Carey; at 91, Barker appeared energized and quickly handled the show’s opening despite eight years away from the program.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington, D.C., around 12:30 a.m. on a residential street after allegedly attempting to break into a house, facing felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property; his security clearance was revoked and he was placed on leave, and he was to be arraigned on Friday. Baldwin is assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which supports the State Department’s diplomatic activities. The arrest follows a separate misconduct accusation against a high-ranking supervisor and ongoing investigations by the Homeland Security Department’s inspector general into multiple incidents, including a separate White House security breach involving two officials.
