A freelance photographer from Lahore, Atif Saeed, risked his life at a safari park to photograph a hungry male lion from about 10 feet away, exiting his car and lying on the ground with only a camera for protection to capture a couple of frames before retreating as the camera shutter drew the lion’s attention; he managed to scramble back into his car as the lion lunged, reflecting on the near-death experience and saying he wouldn’t likely do it again.

The NYPD released a photo of a distinctive tattoo found on an unnamed woman who died in Brooklyn, believed to be 25–45 years old, discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend; the tattoo is a heart with a ribbon and rose bearing the name “Monique,” which investigators hope will help identify her since she had no ID, and they are awaiting the medical examiner’s report to determine the cause of death, with contact information for tips.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom, wood-lined home on the bed of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK because they couldn’t afford property. Over about a year and a half, they welded a steel frame and gradually added wood, then moved the solar-powered, near self-sufficient home to a Nelson lot surrounded by trees and a brook. The house features a wood-fired stove, stained glass, a loft used as a spare room, and water sourced from a nearby spring, with most electricity from solar panels; their first power bill was $25. They plan to build another similar truck-home someday, and the project cost around $25,000.

Research at Northwestern University found that kindergartners who share iPads in class scored about 30 points higher on early literacy tests over an academic year than peers with no iPads or with individual devices, suggesting that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than individual use, drives the gains; the findings imply schools should consider how tablets are used in early grades to maximize effectiveness, and the researcher plans to present the results at the International Communication Association conference.

A piglet born with no hind legs has become an internet sensation for learning to walk on its two front trotters, balancing while foraging with its snout to the ground; despite near-tips, it repeatedly regains balance and mingles with its siblings, under the care of farmer Ms. Duan in Qionglai, Sichuan, China, and its story follows a Chinese pattern of two-legged animals drawing public attention, similar to a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo and others in Guangxi.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone’s car after Dracone spun while exiting the pit box on lap 25 during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, received stitches for a leg cut and was released from the infield care center. The race featured many cars struggling with traction due to rain earlier in the day, and Dracone did not finish, finishing 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, killed his dancer wife Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno) in Rio de Janeiro after a four-day marriage, severely beating her with 11 head smashes into concrete, then shooting her five times at close range, reportedly because he was jealous of men looking at her. Neighbours reported a violent argument, and after the murder he stole a neighbor’s car, which police later recovered along with four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest; Severiano confessed and now faces life in jail. Sena belonged to the dance group Jaula das Gostozuedas.

Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author of I Quit Sugar, reveals in a candid interview that she nearly took her own life due to a combination of mounting stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and family distance, feeling increasingly isolated and unable to see a way forward; she now says she has found some peace, emphasizes the intrinsic link between depression and anxiety, notes that anxiety is becoming the new depression, and highlights the rising impact of stress and anxiety on Australian women, urging support resources like Beyond Blue and Lifeline.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months-pregnant Portland, Oregon woman, was charged with second-degree assault after beating her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend with a crowbar when she found her allegedly shooting heroin in Curtin’s bathroom; prosecutors dropped the charge because Curtin was considered completely justified in her outrage, under Oregon law allowing force against an intruder who won’t leave, and testimony described the ex as harassing Curtin and contributing to an abusive relationship; if convicted she faced nearly six years, but the ex-girlfriend’s past harassment and the couple’s reconciliation are noted, with Curtin now living with her parents.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, is shown being fed treats by her owner, who tries to trick her with a broccoli spear; the dog reacts with disgust, chomps on the vegetable, and then spits it out on the floor, while other clips depict her sleeping and spending time with her human family, highlighting concern that the youngsters she cares for should not imitate her dislike of greens.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website redirected visitors to a pornographic page; the link appeared on the page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which had been shut down, and the porn site had taken over the URL since 2011 after the awards were scrapped, with HSBC removing the hyperlink and denying any association while assuring the public that its site remained secure.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, calmly directed rescuers during an 11-minute 911 call as a fire trapped him and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, on a second-floor bedroom after the fire started on the first floor. He kept his sister calm, instructed her to stay low and breathe, and guided them toward an upstairs exit route. Firefighters eventually entered through the home, broke a window, and Marcus was handed out to a rescuer who then gave his gas mask to the girl; both siblings were taken to Children’s Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other three family members escaped and were treated at MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae lights up Australia’s east coast, with stunning images captured in Jervis Bay on the NSW south coast as millions of plankton emit a neon glow; photographer Andy Hutchinson calls the scene a beautiful supernatural sight, while a similar display was seen at Manly Beach in August 2014. The glow is produced by noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn and typically occurs due to natural causes, and its luminous glow is a defensive light emitted as it prey on diatoms.

Breast cancer patients may avoid chemotherapy thanks to new tests that analyze tumor genetics and predict recurrence risk; after surgery, tumor samples are tested to determine if the risk of cancer returning is high or low, with some results showing a five percent risk, potentially obviating chemotherapy which has harsh side effects; the EndoPredict test can indicate a low score and guide patients to skip chemotherapy, though most tests are privately funded and cost around £2,500, with hopes they will become NHS-supported; experts argue the tests help patients make informed choices and could save costs by reducing unnecessary chemotherapy, as illustrated by Becca Cornford, who learned her low-risk score meant chemotherapy was unlikely to improve her ten-year recurrence odds.

More than 25 pregnant women have been evacuated from Royal Navy ships, including at least five from HMS Ocean and one from HMS Illustrious (nicknamed “HMS Lusty”), with eighteen other ships also evacuating pregnant personnel; a strict no-touching rule at sea suggests pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave, while military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones and many evacuations occurred on flights reserved for injured troops, with pregnancy-related evacuations also noted among British servicewomen in Afghanistan and Iraq in previous years.

A drone carrying traces of cesium, a radioactive material linked to nuclear plants, was found on the rooftop of Japan’s prime minister’s residence in Tokyo, prompting police investigations and fresh concerns about potential drone-related terrorism ahead of events like the Olympics and G7 summit; the incident coincides with a Japanese court approving a plan to restart two Sendai reactors, a move unpopular with many who view nuclear energy as risky, and authorities say the cesium amount is not immediately harmful to humans while pledging to strengthen measures against drone-terrorism.

A security guard in Zhejiang, China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer’s-suffering mother to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike because he fears she’ll get lost if left at home; he ties a sash around both of them to prevent her from falling off, travels about four kilometers slowly to ensure she feels safe, and their one-hour daily journey includes checking on her at work, where she has a room provided by the bank where he works. He started this after his father’s death to ensure she isn’t left alone, explaining that he feels obliged to care for her as she once cared for him. The story highlights his devotion and how he and his mother share a close, protective bond.

A major study from the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2% from 2005 to 2012, driven largely by increased drinking among women, with binge drinking among women increasing far faster than among men; in 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers, while overall alcohol consumption among those who drink remained stable. The rise is linked to changing social norms that make it more acceptable for women to drink like men, demographic and economic factors (including more affluent, urban professionals and greater availability/advertising), and weakened alcohol control policies, though some areas still reported high or low rates of heavy or binge drinking. The study analyzed data from about 3.7 million adults using the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System.

The passage reports that UN officials warn doctors in England are performing caesarean sections too readily, suggesting the procedure should be medically necessary due to risks of infections, disability, or death, and to avoid diverting NHS funds; despite NICE guidelines allowing some nonmedical reasons (e.g., tokophobia, prior complicated birth, age, or medical conditions), the WHO believes the rate—over a quarter of births and rising since the 1990s—should ideally be 10–15% and that many caesareans are done without medical need, with infections occurring in up to about one in ten cases.

A woman, Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham was arrested in Edgartown after allegedly breaking into a Martha’s Vineyard home, living there for about a week, and selling or distributing the owners’ belongings via a yard sale; she is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, following the homeowner finding her in the living room on April 17, with a broken window and items missing including furniture, lamps, and a painting, and police are seeking the return of stolen items and information from the public.

Police in Albury, on the NSW-Victoria border, reunited Bella Crooke of Melbourne with her lost iPhone after realizing the phone was unlocked and using it to post humorous selfies and captions on her Facebook page while it was at the station; the officers posted jokes and puns, including a “cell” and “ready to be released” theme, to track her down and reassure her, and she eventually reclaimed the phone, having her friends amused and praising the officers’ lighthearted approach.

Two adult male hippos fighting in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa led to a five-day-old baby hippo being caught in the melee; the mother stayed with her herd, hoping to stay safe, but one sub-adult hippo grabbed the calf, causing it to be flung into the air and dragged under the water. The mother attempted to intervene, but the calf could not be saved, dying hours later from its injuries.

A Knightsbridge three-bedroom flat is for sale at £575,000 despite only three years left on its lease, effectively costing about £191,000 annually or £15,000 per month, similar to local rents, with the potential to be worth over £6 million if the lease is extended; a nearby 1,990 sq ft unmodernised maisonette with three bedrooms and two bathrooms is also listed at £575,000 (and a larger one at £595,000), both requiring modernization and sharing the short lease, while the next cheapest three-bedroom in the area is about £1.5 million with a 28-year lease; lease extension could cost £3.35–£4.5 million for a 90-year lease, and experts warn the apparent bargain hides a significant premium to extend, with potential value rising to £6–7.5 million after modernization or with a longer lease.

Starbucks faced a nationwide computer outage that disrupted point-of-sale systems across about 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, prompting some locations to give away free drinks and baked goods while staff processed cash purchases; the outage began in the late afternoon/evening, was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, and stores remained open as they worked to resolve it, with the issue also affecting Evolution Fresh and Teavana, before being resolved and normal operations resuming the next day; the event followed strong quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion in net revenues and a stock rise.

The passage reports that terrorists are undergoing radicalisation training in rural west Wales, with locations in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire used to recruit and train Muslims, while participants appear to engage in ordinary community activities; it notes that terrorism issues in Wales date back to 1998, cites past incidents and links to training sites used by the British military, and emphasizes the importance of community intelligence in identifying and countering such activities.

A rare Omura’s whale, previously thought nearly extinct, was found washed up on Exmouth Beach in Western Australia, the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia, after tropical cyclone Olwyn. The 5.68 m juvenile female was identified by DNA profiling, a process that initially confused authorities. Environment Minister Albert Jacob called the find highly significant for whale scientists because little is known about the species, which was first described in 2003 and typically inhabits tropical and subtropical waters; its usual range includes Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The discovery could improve field identification guides and understanding of the whale’s regional distribution. Omura’s whales have a sleek body and distinctive skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass was buried, with the skeleton to be recovered later for further study and potential museum display.

The article critiques claims that a candidate’s hormones determine presidential suitability, noting a Texas businesswoman’s belief that Hillary Clinton’s hormones could trigger irrational war decisions, while arguing that male hormones have also impaired leaders and that women generally take fewer unnecessary risks; it highlights broader gender bias and the pervasive bias against women in the workplace, citing studies, Time’s framing of Clinton as biologically primed to lead, and Wharton and Sandberg’s work on bias, arguing that equality benefits society and that Clinton’s candidacy faces a steeper path due to bias rather than biochemistry, urging the message that women can overcome such bias to lead.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, famed for All Creatures Great and Small and multiple Churchill portrayals, is downsizing by selling over 200 antiques in a £100,000 Dominic Winter auction in Gloucestershire, including a 3D limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a yew longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and a substantial library; the 89-year-old historian who studied under Tolkien and Leavis at Oxford, and who has written on the longbow and advised on the Mary Rose, expresses sadness at parting with his collection but hopes buyers will derive the same joy he did.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man on parole for battery on a law enforcement officer with a history of bipolar disorder and prior involuntary psychiatric commitment, is wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, found dead at their Winter Garden home; he failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son, prompting a manhunt after authorities learned of his involvement, with neighbors suggesting divorce stress and his mother’s involvement in preventing the visit may have contributed to his alleged actions. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not publicly identified it or disclosed the cause of death, and Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot from the Winter Garden RV Resort area, reportedly asking for water at the trailer park office, with his estranged wife preparing to take precautions if he comes to her home; anyone with information is urged to contact police.

The International Association of Athletics Federations council awarded Eugene, United States, the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a perceived unique strategic opportunity involving strong local support from public authorities, private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and an enthusiastic public; Eugene had previously failed to secure the 2019 host bid, which went to Doha, but a persuasive presentation convinced the council of Eugene’s capability to stage the event, marking a departure from standard procedure similar to the 2007 Osaka decision.

An aspiring model, Leonie Granger, lured professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death in a “pitiless and wicked” plan to steal his winnings, using her looks to befriend him and then betraying him to her boyfriend and an accomplice who killed him during a home robbery; Granger was found guilty of manslaughter and jailed for 16 years, while her co-defendants Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler were convicted of murder and given life sentences with minimum terms of 36 years. The case details describe how Hassan, a high-roller who kept large sums at home, was manipulated, robbed of about £3,000 plus property, and left battered in his flat, with CCTV showing the trio’s exploitative and violent actions.

Cesc Fabregas, after a brilliant start to the season with Chelsea, has seen a late-season slump that mirrors his past post-Christmas declines, continuing to struggle for Spain and Chelsea as fatigue and a demanding schedule take their toll; his diminished form has raised questions about his durability and impact in midfield, though he remains a key playmaker for Chelsea as they push to secure the Premier League title with potential late-season resurgence and more goals-assist contributions.

West Ham are negotiating a deal with Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old who impressed during a two-week academy trial after training with West Ham’s academy; he has offers from Belgium and is cited as one of the Caribbean’s hottest prospects, while West Ham also announced season tickets at the Olympic Stadium starting as low as £289 to attract fans to fill the 54,000-seat venue for the 2016-17 season.

Police have dropped the investigation into a January assault on huntsman Mike Lane, despite evidence including a video and car registrations, leaving supporters angry as Lane suffers injuries and memory loss; authorities say the inquiry is on hold due to insufficient evidence, with the case recorded as undetected but potentially resumable if new information emerges.

Adam Gadahn, an American-born member and prominent English-language propagandist for al Qaeda, was killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation along with Ahmed Farouq in what the White House described as likely separate strikes. Born in 1978 and formerly known as Azzam the American, he grew up in California, converted to Islam, joined al Qaeda in the late 1990s, and became its chief English-language spokesman, issuing videos and writings urging attacks against the U.S., Western, and Jewish targets, condemning U.S. presidents, praising extremist acts, and influencing al Qaeda’s media strategy; he remained a key figure despite not being among its top leaders. The operation also resulted in the deaths of Warren Weinstein and Italian hostage Giovanni Lo Porto in the attack that killed Farouq.

Five-year-old Mai Zizhuo, who has been shooting hoops since age two and a half, is featured in a viral video showcasing his extraordinary basketball skills—dribbling two balls, scoring multiple hoops, and maintaining rhythm while focusing on the camera—which has earned him a large following in China, a country where prodigy-raising is common; comparisons are drawn to Shanghai-born Yao Ming as China’s biggest basketball star, and netizens express astonishment and admiration, with some questioning his parentage or imagining his potential.

Tom O’Carroll, a former leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) known for campaigns to legalise child sex and incest, has joined the supporters of the media-pressure group Hacked Off. He attended a Hacked Off rally in the House of Commons on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation, a stance that aligns with Hacked Off’s push for a statutory press regulator as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. PIE historically advocated reducing the age of consent and other related aims, and O’Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for “corrupting public morals,” has now publicly backed Hacked Off, which is critical of the proposed independent press standards organisation.

Bondi’s Icebergs Club pool was drained to serve as a catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, where ten pieces, a unisex capsule collection designed to be worn in 20 ways, were showcased by models walking through the empty pool and along the break wall with an ocean backdrop. The event drew crowds from beachgoers and passers-by who watched from above, with guests enjoying nibbles from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria on a sunny, unseasonably warm day. The collection is monochrome, and features androgynous designs suitable for day-to-night wear, with models styled in scarves and hoodies as seasons shift.

Amir Khan enjoyed a family day at a Northern California safari park and Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, posing with a giraffe and feeding a rare white tiger with his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa. Separately, he announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, despite speculation about a bout with Kell Brook, with negotiations for other potential opponents having been ongoing.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, whose name appeared on the wall of Jerusalem’s Mount Herzl memorial, had his name removed after his family and anti-terror groups objected, with his father saying he would not permit his son’s name to be listed among soldiers of the occupation. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive in July by three Israelis. Almagor, a victims’ group, disputed calling him a terror victim and demanded removal, threatening to remove other names in response. The National Insurance Institute of Israel announced it would remove his name, and it had already been removed from the memorial website; a panel was hearing evidence against the three suspects in his killing.

A California-based YouTube user filmed his young son chasing the family cat around the garden to rest, with the cat licking its fur before the boy plonks on top as a pillow; after brief stillness the cat gets up and moves to a new spot, and the boy follows, repeating the sequence until the cat decides to wander indoors, after which a later video shows them making up and the boy feeding the cat treats.

A Philadelphia police corruption trial is ongoing, and at least one witness, Robert Kushner, has already faced a losing verdict in a separate matter after testifying about years of selling marijuana and alleging undercover officers stole money and drugs during a 2007 arrest; Kushner, who later coached at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy and says the 2007 charges were expunged, also faced a 2011 arrest and a 2008 DUI plea, and maintains his innocence while expressing remorse and a desire for the best for the students, as the defense for six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering argues the government case rests on statements from 19 drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

Six people were injured and a large fire was sparked by an explosion at a controversial paraxylene plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian, China, caused by an oil leak at an oil storage facility; five victims were hurt by broken glass and hospitalized, over 600 firefighters battled the blaze which is now under control, and residents reported the blast on social media. The plant, which faced protests over pollution in the past and was relocated from Xiamen due to concerns, produces a carcinogenic chemical used in polyester films and fabrics.

Jack Grealish says he will not change his superstition of wearing socks low with children's shin pads, despite referees telling him otherwise; he explains he has worn them this way all his life and plans to keep it, even after making his first Premier League start for Aston Villa, a tough 3-3 draw with QPR, where he appreciated the faith shown in him and hopes for more starts before the season’s end.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, remains in a state of global and irreversible brain damage and unresponsiveness, with a tracheostomy, after coming out of a medically induced coma; while her father claimed she had awakened and was watching him, medical sources and her grandmother Cissy Houston described her as non-responsive and in the same neurological state for nearly three months, with doctors indicating she could live a long life but requiring a prolonged rehabilitation and an uncertain quality of life.

Russia took a 2-0 lead in the Fed Cup tie after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3, following Svetlana Kuznetsova’s straight-sets win over Julia Goerges; both players struggled on serve, with Pavlyuchenkova recording 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors, and Lisicki lamenting a poor tiebreak. The result left Russia needing one win from Sunday’s three matches to reach the final and claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales face more floods as another east coast low is predicted to bring heavy rainfall and strong winds later this week, potentially hampering clean-up efforts after last week’s severe weather. The SES has more than 4,000 jobs still to complete (4,409 of 24,196), with particular concern for the Hunter region, which was hard-hit previously. Meteorologists expect the system to affect coastal northern and southeastern areas, with rain peaking between Thursday and Saturday, though Sydney may see less impact than last time. Authorities urge residents to prepare homes and families to prevent further loss, while the SES mobilizes over 1,000 personnel (including 200 from other states) to address ongoing needs.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in a video for Ricky Martin’s La Vida Loca, denied claims that she attempted suicide, stating she was hospitalized after a domestic accident caused by low blood pressure and later recovered at home; she shared photos of bruises on Instagram, explained she fell and injured herself, and refuted tabloids’ reports, while noting her boyfriend was away in Naples at the time, and she had previously been married to Fabrizio Corona.

A YouGov poll for the Sunday Times shows Brits hope the next royal baby will be a girl and favor the name Diana as the top choice for a girl, with Alice and Charlotte next, while for a boy Diana is not preferred; 13% would name a son James and Alexander is second, and 25% of 2,200 respondents want a female baby with only 3% hoping for a younger brother for George. The article notes social media support for naming the baby Diana after William’s mother, and reports 68% approval for William taking six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 people and wounding dozens, including 64 wounded such as a Afghan lawmaker taking part in the protests; the attackers struck as they were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor, and Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied involvement with no other group claiming responsibility.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club’s final contract offer; after seven successful years—including four Spanish titles and two Champions Leagues—he could not agree to a new deal, with agent and ex-wife Dinorah Santana revealing he rejected a three-year extension contingent on playing in 60% of matches, effectively ending negotiations.

Pablo Osvaldo has urged Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to move from Europe to Boca Juniors, praising them as ideal fits who could be loved by Boca fans and energize La Bombonera, noting that their South American–style play would suit the club well; Osvaldo, who joined Boca on loan from Southampton and has scored three goals in six games, says Pirlo and Totti would be his two picks among former teammates to join him at Boca.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, who became an internet sensation after a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square at Wincanton, suffered only a cut on his nose, returned to ride out at Paul Nicholls's yard, described the fall as a blur and unavoidably dramatic, received some abuse and gained many Twitter followers, and humorously considered a future gymnastics career after racing.

James Haskell, captain of London Wasps, dressed as Iron Man and posted an Instagram photo to celebrate the Avengers: Age of Ultron release, joining the hype around the A-list cast at the London premiere. The article traces his career path: starting at Wasps in 2002, stints with Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams, and the Highlanders, returning to Wasps in 2012, where he has since surpassed 100 appearances and earned 57 England caps. He linked his post to Under Armour with the hashtag campaign.

The passage discusses the rising popularity of wide-leg trousers for SS15, highlighting their appeal as a relaxed alternative to skinny jeans and noting denim as the easiest way to wear the trend. It mentions various styles (denim, cropped, printed, striped) and references celebrities like Louise Redknapp and Poppy Delevingne, as well as fashion houses such as Gucci and Celine, who showcased wide-leg or flared designs. Practical styling tips are given: pair with high heels to elongate the leg, keep the top simple, choose high-waisted, long cuts for added length, and balance volume with a simple knit, shirt, or tee. The trend appears on multiple catwalks and is accessible through high-street pieces like Topshop’s Miller jean, with fashion guidance to maintain proportion and avoid a costume-like look.

The University of Michigan decided to screen the film American Sniper as part of its UMix social events, despite a petition from over 200 students urging them not to show it; concerns centered on its portrayal of the Iraq War and the Middle East, given Detroit’s large Arab-American community, while a counter-petition urged the school to reconsider. University officials later stated that canceling the screening was a mistake and affirmed that the show would proceed, emphasizing freedom of expression and students’ right to make their own choices, and UMix will also offer the family-friendly Paddington for those who prefer not to attend American Sniper. The decision received praise from football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly ignited an aerosol can with a lighter on Rottnest Island, causing a large flame to contact a quokka; the animal survived but was singed, and the men were questioned, evicted from the island, and charged with animal cruelty, with court appearances set for April 17.

A 102-year-old dancer, Alice Barker, who performed in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, was long unable to see herself in motion as her photographs and memorabilia had been lost. Filmmakers and volunteers created a video of early music videos called Soundies and screened it for her at her nursing home, allowing her to finally see herself dancing, which she found simply fabulous.

New figures indicate that washing one's own car is declining in Britain, with a third of men and three-quarters of women never washing their cars themselves, as many drivers now prefer car washes or automated options. The study of 1,100 adults found 31% of men have never washed their own car, and only 12% who do so do it regularly, while just 5% have asked children to wash the car for pocket money. Reasons for the decline include shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and the larger size of modern cars like 4x4s making cleaning harder. Brits tend to wash cars more during holidays but often only to get out of the house, with weekly washing more common in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield and less so in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs are most often washed by owners, while Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes are least. The OSV spokesman notes that Sunday street cleaning was once a national tradition, but time constraints, bigger cars, less interest from kids in earning money, and the availability of cheaper automated or group car washes have contributed to the shift.

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard’s impact at Liverpool since 2008 and says the club will be different without him, but believes Liverpool can replace the iconic captain with suitable teammates. Gerrard aims to reach and win the FA Cup to sign off at Anfield on his birthday before moving to LA Galaxy, potentially retiring after the final against Arsenal. Skrtel notes Gerrard helped him settle when he joined and remains one of the world’s best, while asserting Liverpool will continue with new players who can fill Gerrard’s void with the right support. Both players could return for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after bans.

At age 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one on the 130-yard fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, celebrating a memorable Masters Week moment alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw; he noted he aimed to win the par-3 and make an ace, marking his first Augusta hole-in-one and adding to his storied career, though the day also saw Camilo Villegas achieve multiple holes-in-one and Kevin Streelman win the title after a playoff, while Nicklaus remains one of the few to complete the career Grand Slam, a feat Rory McIlroy could also attain with consecutive major wins.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas as storms spawned multiple tornado sightings near Goddard (west of Wichita) and in southwestern Kansas, with potential risks to other areas as the storms moved northeast; nighttime tornadoes are noted as especially dangerous, and reports of damage include wind, flooding, and hail in Missouri (Potosi) and surrounding areas, with additional storm activity expected across the Midwest and nearby regions on Thursday.

Oklahoma reserve deputy Robert Bates pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during a weapons sting, claiming he intended to stun Harris with a taser but shot him by mistake; Bates is free to travel to the Bahamas on a family vacation while preliminary hearings are set for July 2, amid family and officials criticizing the vacation timing and ongoing disputes over his qualifications and training, with some supervisors allegedly reassigned and training records released by Bates’ lawyers to support proper training, while two deputies involved have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas and has unveiled a fearsome new tiger tattoo on his stomach, adding to his existing gorilla-eating-a-heart tattoo, with the caption “if you see the tiger, it’s too late, you’re food.” Ahead of the bout, he claims Aldo lacks the same motivation as him, saying Aldo does not want the belt as much, and notes a fractious relationship between them, including McGregor grabbing Aldo’s belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Tony Abbott drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners for skollying a beer at an Australian rules event, with critics arguing the act glorifies binge drinking and links masculinity to heavy drinking; supporters like Health Minister Sussan Ley defended it as promoting fitness and normal behavior, while commentators noted changing attitudes toward drinking and warned that such demonstrations risk normalizing irresponsible behavior and the stereotype of the “true blue” Aussie bloke.

Indiana has seen a significant rise in HIV cases linked to Scott County, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positives, up from 106 the previous week, amid a short-term needle-exchange program approved by Gov. Mike Pence to address an outbreak primarily among intravenous drug users using the opioid Opana; the program has distributed thousands of clean syringes and engaged a mobile unit to reach more users, but its future—along with broader needle-exchange legislation for other counties—is uncertain as Pence and lawmakers weigh long-term sustainability, political concerns about encouraging drug use, and funding challenges since public funds are barred and the program relies on state agency funding.

A football-obsessed boyfriend made his girlfriend Saskia take an Arsenal knowledge test styled as a school exam; she scored 43.5/50 (87%), he praised her and said he wouldn’t dump her, while giving minor feedback on a couple of questions. Saskia shared the experience on Twitter, receiving praise from fans who called the boyfriend a legend and admired her knowledge, though some felt he went too far.

An informant who spent 27 years working undercover for the DEA, Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s, helped the agency prosecute major drug figures including Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, and despite promises of U.S. citizenship, he is facing deportation and living in limbo without citizenship or social security benefits after retiring due to ill health. He __ was not paid but was promised citizenship, he aided prosecutions, including Noriega, and now fears deportation, possible death if returned to Colombia, and has had limited or no federal assistance with his immigration status.

A 14-year-old girl in Uttar Pradesh, India, allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village, set herself on fire and is now hospitalized with around 70% burns; her family reportedly urged her to stay silent, and the accused have been arrested. The passage also references ongoing national outrage over sexual assault, protests, and past high-profile cases such as Jyoti Singh Pandey's rape and murder, which sparked widespread calls for greater protection of women.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal says he dreams of beating rivals Manchester City in the derby at Old Trafford but Robin van Persie will not play due to not being fit, with Luke Shaw also unavailable; Van Gaal believes most players are fit but fitness varies, and he aims to secure a win to move the team into the top four, potentially third place, while acknowledging City as a tough challenge and stressing the importance of maintaining control and learning from the previous 1-0 defeat earlier in the season.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested rising ticket prices by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of a lunchtime Premier League match at the Emirates, highlighting banners criticizing a £64 cheapest ticket in the context of a £5 billion TV rights deal; organizers from the Black Scarf Movement, Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 called prices extortionate and urged tangible reductions to protect ordinary fans, with protests anticipated to continue after full-time.

A newborn in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, diagnosed with biliary atresia—a condition that can cause liver failure—received a life-saving liver transplant from her maternal twin sister after neither parent was a suitable donor. The baby, Star, had jaundice and blocked bile ducts; after an unsuccessful Kasai procedure, a partial liver from her aunt, Shanell Reader, was donated, and Star underwent transplant in November, spending six weeks in hospital before returning home and continuing with regular tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication. Shanell stated she would help to save her niece, and Star’s parents expressed deep gratitude for the life-saving gift.

Chelsea players, led by Eden Hazard and Nathan Aké, teamed up with teammates Loïc Rémy and Willian for Audi’s football challenge, featuring four head-to-head games played around an Audi R8 V10 Plus. Hazard and Aké won the first two rounds—firing balls into car boots and sinking long-range shots over a makeshift tennis-net obstacle—before Rémy and Willian won the final round of long-range shots. The day included a mishap when Willian smashed a wing mirror during a long-range effort, though Rémy appeared relieved and not expected to pay for repairs.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for a December 7, 2013 crash in which he drove his pickup across a median at over 100 mph, killing a Vermont couple—Amanda Murphy, 24, who was eight months pregnant, and Jason Timmins, 29—and injuring others; he told investigators he was trying to kill himself, though he later said he was not suicidal in court, while his wife defended him as ethical and frail from health problems, and prosecutors noted he had argued with his wife over medications that morning; he faces 12 to 24 years in prison and a wrongful death suit filed by Murphy’s estate, with his defense citing Ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug effects, and early multiple sclerosis as mitigating factors.

Lacey Spears of Kentucky was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her hospitalized five-year-old son Garnett-Paol Spears with a lethal salt dose, a crime prosecutors said stemmed from her attention-seeking behavior; she received 20 years to life, not the maximum 25 to life, while her ex-husband/posting on Facebook expressed violent wishes toward her, calling for her to be beaten to death in prison; the judge described the act as unfathomably cruel though tied to mental illness, and prosecutors highlighted Garnett’s years of hospitalizations and needless procedures caused by Spears, including her blogging about his illness and final hours on life support.

An updated influenza vaccine is arriving in Australia later than planned to cover two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket, after a spike in flu deaths in the northern hemisphere showed the previous vaccine was not a good match. The modified vaccine is expected to be a better match for circulating strains, and the next northern winter’s vaccine will be the same as the one used now; high-risk groups, including young children, the elderly, and most Indigenous Australians, will receive free government-funded flu shots from April 20, with experts urging broader vaccination because protecting high-risk individuals also helps shield those around them.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln’s tomb face scrutiny from National Geographic for an unflattering portrayal of the site and must navigate potential budget cuts that could merge the state historic preservation agency responsible for the tomb into another department; the site has recently undergone significant repairs and upgrades, but hours have been reduced and staffing cut due to funding shortfalls, while local supporters defend the tomb’s presentation and note ongoing projects to address waterproofing, interior repairs, and landscaping amid Illinois’s financial crisis and debates over the agency’s future.

The passage surveys 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends that are resurfacing or being debated for comeback, listing nine items—JNCO “rave” jeans, bucket hats, camouflage print, maximalist styling (taking trends to the extreme), Ugg boots, daisy dukes (tiny denim shorts), Juicy Couture velour tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers—and notes how celebrities from then and now (e.g., Christina Aguilera, Destiny’s Child, Rihanna, Kylie Jenner, Kim Kardashian, Selena Gomez, Cara Delevingne, Miley Cyrus, Elle Macpherson, etc.) have influenced their popularity or revival, with observations about their impracticality, boldness, or enduring appeal.

The passage summarizes a week of trending stories across diverse topics: four rainbows appearing over the New York area after heavy rain photographed by Amanda Curtis; rural China cracking down on vice, with exotic dancers used at wakes causing families to seek new ways to cheer mourners; Roger (RDJ) and media interviews about his private life; Kardashians spawning trends like lip plumping via the Kylie Jenner challenge; a 102-year-old Alice Barker collaborating with filmmakers to go back in time; controversy over a prom-posal referencing bombs and accusations of racism by school administrators; announcements about Ewan McGregor as Lumiere in Beauty and the Beast; Johnny Depp’s noticeable look in the Black Mass trailer; pregnancy announcements via The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air reference; and a military dad photobombing his son, highlighting a variety of online buzz and social-media interest.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory at the Miami Open with a win over Sabine Lisicki to reach the semi-finals, as Andy Murray marked his 500th win with a celebratory cake; Williams, the world No. 1, advanced to face Simona Halep after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens, while Venus Williams was stopped by Carla Suarez Navarro, leaving Serena to pursue a place in the final in what felt like a hometown event.

Sabeen Mahmud, founder of the second-floor cafe/t2f in Karachi, used her platform to host discussions on technology, human rights, and women’s entrepreneurship, attracting young Pakistanis seeking secular ideas in a society where free speech can be dangerous; after recently leading a debate on Balochistan—a topic authorities often silence—she was shot dead by two gunmen, who also wounded her mother, highlighting the risks faced by progressive voices; Mahmud was celebrated as a symbol of humanism, love, and tolerance, with T2F described as a welcoming, art-filled space that encouraged dialogue despite threats, and her death sparked national grief and calls for continued liberty and justice.

The passage describes the plight of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in Jammu and Kashmir, India—mostly Hindu families who fled Partition around 1947 and have since been denied basic rights like owning land, voting in state elections, or state government employment, leaving generations in poverty. Despite many never visiting Pakistan, about 100,000 WPRs are classified as refugees, with roughly 35,000 Hindus from Pakistan-administered Kashmir granted citizenship. The demographic balance concerns and pre-independence laws underpin the reluctance of state rulers to grant full rights. A recent shift in political momentum, with the BJP joining the Kashmir coalition, raises hope that WPRs may gain state-subject rights, though activists warn they are prepared to protest or act if promises fade.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto admitted he is still considering a potential move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, following reports of an offer (around £4 million) and Chelsea’s plan to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem, though Muto wants to join a club where he can play regularly and develop; FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane confirmed Chelsea’s interest, while Muto emphasized he wants time to decide where he can best develop, and Porto-like praise from Real Zaragoza coach Ranko Popovic highlighted Muto’s speed, intelligence, and potential; Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledged minimal knowledge of Muto and noted commercial factors in transfer policy, yet emphasized Chelsea only wants players who can help win matches.

The passage argues that countries should not restrict selections to players based on where they play club rugby, using Australia’s shift to pick overseas stars like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell as a positive example and contrasting with England’s policy of excluding overseas players. It claims the world cup hinges on fielding the best team, regardless of club allegiance, citing players such as Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon thriving after moving abroad and noting Jonny Wilkinson’s France stint as proof that overseas players can excel for their national teams. It asserts England’s head coach Stuart Lancaster should select the best starting XV without geographic constraints, as doing so would maximize chances to win the home world cup, while warning that clinging to home-only selections risks leaving “what if” headlines and weak results.

Open Garden has developed Greenstone, a small egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon/booster to strengthen off-the-grid wireless mesh networks used by the FireChat app, allowing messages to travel beyond the limited Bluetooth/Wi‑Fi range (about 200 feet) by routing data through nearby phones, which become network nodes. FireChat, launched last year, lets users chat without web or mobile signals via Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (and similar Android tech), creating local mesh networks where messages can be relayed between nearby devices, with security and anonymity features, and it has been downloaded over five million times. Greenstone currently works with FireChat within about 20 feet (6 meters) and holds up to 1,000 recent messages with a one-year battery life; it’s designed to enable resilient community, venue, or event communications when traditional connectivity is unavailable, with production partnerships in progress to manufacture and sell the device.

Lillian Bustle, a 5'3", 240-pound burlesque performer from New Jersey, uses her TED Talk to promote body positivity by reframing the word “fat” as an honest, non-derogatory self-description rather than an insult, arguing that beauty comes in larger packages and that exposure to body diversity can reduce discrimination and change perceptions; she began performing in 2012, finds burlesque empowering and affirming, and notes that while she receives some negative comments online, the overall response has been supportive, including stories from viewers who reevaluated their views on bodies.

Theo Walcott, frequently benched this season, was photographed with six Arsenal teammates—Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Özil— alongside model Olga Sherer for Lanvin, Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013. He has spent much of the season on the bench, including in a 0-0 draw with Chelsea, and was named as a substitute for 17 of Arsenal’s 33 Premier League games, with his next opportunity aiming to be his first start since March 14 as Arsenal prepare for FA Cup Final duties and an upcoming league match at Hull.

An auction in Los Angeles (and online at propstore.com) on May 29 will sell over 400 items from Rick Baker’s Cinovation Studio, including props and puppets from more than 50 productions such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, Gremlins 2, Planet of the Apes, An American Werewolf in London, Batman & Robin, Moonwalker, and Thriller, with a total estimated value around $746,100 and individual items ranging up to about $40,000, featuring pieces like the alien from Men in Black, Two-Face’s mask, the Grinch costume, Mikey and Hammerhead/MIB items, and various other iconic characters; proceeds come from a no-reserve live auction, offering collectors a chance to acquire famous Hollywood make-up effects and puppets from Baker’s 30-plus-year career.

A seven-year-old Welsh boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, died after straying from his family while skiing in Flaine, France, entering a wooded area and falling about 164 feet; police later found his body guided by footprints in the snow. Described as daring, outgoing, and loved for his laughter and kindness, he was a competent skier who had started skiing at age three and admired Bear Grylls. His family mourns a vast void in their hearts, and schools and the community express their grief as they await repatriation of his body.

A 15-year-old girl from Whitley Bay, Laura Scurr, developed anorexia after feeling pressured by the idea that girls should be “size zero.” She hid food, survived on about 100 calories a day, and sometimes just a piece of fruit, leading to near-collapse and a week on a heart monitor. Bullied and influenced by media and peers, she pursued rapid weight loss despite her mother’s attempts at a sensible diet. She describes hiding meals, lying to her mother, and feeling constant pressure to be thin, which culminated in a near-fatal health crisis. After hospitalization, she began recovery with eating disorder services and CAMHS, and has since improved, even reaching the semi-final of Miss Teen GB, an event designed to promote confidence away from size-zero ideals.

Liverpool unveiled their 2015/16 home kit, styled by New Balance in a gingham design with a memorial 96 Hillsborough tribute, as Raheem Sterling and teammates presented the strip at Anfield amid fan signs urging him to stay; despite reports he rejected a £100,000-a-week offer and links to Arsenal, Liverpool insist he will remain, while Sturridge, Skrtel, Mignolet and co. look ahead to the FA Cup semi-final at Wembley, hoping success with the fans as their 12th man, and noting that captain Steven Gerrard will not model the shirt next season.

Researchers at the University of Manchester have produced the largest HD map of dark matter to date, a 0.4 percent sky coverage (about the area of 150 full moons) from the Dark Energy Survey, using 130 million galaxy images and gravitational lensing to infer dark matter distribution. Led by Dr. Sarah Bridle and involving extensive data from the Dark Energy Camera on the Blanco telescope in Chile, the map forms part of a five-year effort to map about 12.5 percent of the sky and ultimately create a 3D view of dark matter and dark energy. The project aims to show how dark matter’s clumpiness correlates with galaxy formation, revealing large filaments and voids and testing cosmological theories, while requiring immense computing power to measure galaxy shapes with high precision.

Manchester United have made an official approach to sign Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven, with Louis van Gaal eager to secure him as one of his first summer signings; Depay, 21, has been a prolific scorer this season (20 goals in 26 league games) and helped PSV clinch the Dutch championship, while PSV have indicated bigger transfer offers from United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club are possible, and Depay is highly regarded for his pace, dribbling, and versatility on the left wing, with comparisons to Robben and Ronaldo being discussed by coaches and scouts.

Chelsea built a commanding 3-1 lead over Manchester City’s youngsters in a youth cup final at the Academy Stadium, with Tammy Abraham scoring a first-half double and Dominic Solanke adding a late third; Chelsea’s defense, including Jake Clarke-Salter and Fikayo Tomori, nullified City’s threats while Abraham’s and Solanke’s finishing sealed the win, though Abraham was substituted with an injury concern.

Marco Rubio, while announcing his presidential bid, said he believes people are born with a sexual preference but that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and should be decided by state legislatures, not courts; he would attend the same-sex wedding of someone he cares about even if he disagrees with the decision, and he emphasized respecting loved ones regardless of their choices, noting his Catholic beliefs on divorce but commitment to loving them nonetheless.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebelode are a free-spirited couple who quit their restaurant jobs to cycle around the world on a shoestring, starting in London and traveling through 16 countries over 356 days. They live with minimal costs—under three euros per person per day—using free accommodations like camping, couchsurfing, and warmshowers, and relying on simple foods and occasional invited meals. Their open-ended journey has taken them across Europe into Turkey, Armenia, and beyond, with the plan to continue into Asia and eventually the Americas, carrying about 130 kg of gear and documenting their experiences as they pedal from place to place.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 allege their photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, printed a racist slur at the bottom of photo booth snapshots from the wedding; Evans denies the claim, argues there is no evidence linking him to the captions in a party of 103, and says there was no mental anguish. The couple, represented by Cathy Hale, has filed a Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act claim for negligence and breach of contract, seeking at least an apology rather than money. Mediation is set, with trial planned for July if unresolved.

England full-back Mike Brown says he will take a cautious approach to recovering from his concussion, aiming not to rush back for Harlequins and noting he pulled out of a England- Ireland build-up game after symptoms; Northampton’s George North has suffered a fourth quick-fire concussion and will not play this season, with neurosurgeon assessment planned; Brown emphasizes heightened awareness from World Rugby online modules about concussion symptoms, advocating honesty and not risking long-term damage, and hopes his experience encourages teammates to speak up and avoid playing through symptoms.

A leading expert suggests smartphone use and constant connectivity are linked to a decline in sexual activity among Britons, with research showing couples now average about three encounters per month, down from four in 2000 and five in 1990; Spiegelhalter attributes this partly to more people living alone and, more broadly, to technology blurring home, work, and social boundaries, which intensifies busy, overlapping demands and leaves less time and focus for partners, as supported by Catherine Mercer’s remark that work emails and external demands push sex down the priority list.

Tibetan mastiffs, once valued at up to £1.2 million and celebrated as status symbols, have crashed in popularity in China due to anti-corruption crackdowns and new city-wide dog ownership bans for large breeds, leading to widespread supply issues, cross-breeding and deteriorated quality, with hundreds ending up in slaughterhouses or being stolen for meat and leather; urbanisation and shifting attitudes toward city living have further reduced demand, while rescue efforts have highlighted harsh conditions and overstocked, poorer-quality dogs from unscrupulous breeders.

Every woman surveyed in Paris reported experiencing some form of sexual harassment on the city’s public transport, with half stating they were harassed before age 18, and the survey highlighting a range from insults and intimidating behavior to sex attacks or rape. The findings show six in ten women fear attack on transit, compared to three in ten men, and note many incidents go unreported, limiting women’s freedom and ability to participate in public life. The report, prepared for the French women’s rights ministry, calls for a campaign to curb sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains and emphasizes the need for education of both aggressors and witnesses that such acts are not normal and punishable, including a five-year prison term and fines for actions like touching someone’s backside.

Leeds-based Direct Line ran the #everydayfix competition through Makerversity to design prototype products addressing common daily emergencies. A survey of 2,000 people identified top stress points, notably not being able to sleep, losing keys, and being stuck in traffic, among others. Three shortlisted concepts were Snooze (an alarm clock that silences notifications for better sleep), Forget Me Lock (a green/red lock-on key device showing door status), and Nipper (a tiny mobile phone charger powered by any household battery). The top-voted concept will be funded via a Kickstarter and developed into a real product, with voting occurring on Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag. Additional ideas that didn’t make the cut included a bone-conduction helmet for cycling directions, a parking pin that signals when a space frees up, and a relay app to share messages when a phone dies.

A police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under a Ministry of Justice investigation for allocating over £500,000 of public money to a charity she directs, Victims First Northumbria, which sits alongside Northumbria Police Chief Constable Sue Sim on its top table. Critics call the arrangement a conflict of interest and a “soap opera,” arguing it inappropriate for a PCC to fund a charity in which they have an interest. The Home Secretary had broadened PCC powers to commission victims’ services, and MOJ procedures were stated as followed by Baird, though the MOJ will review for conflicts of interest. Sue Sim, who helped run the charity and is retiring in June amid prior misconduct scrutiny, defends the decision, while colleagues defend the arrangement as properly funded via MOJ rules.

Three people were imprisoned and two awaiting sentencing for a brutal assault on 53-year-old Greg Valecce, during which he was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive imagery after Campbell and his accomplices—dubbed the “tattoo terrorists”— accused him of harming a cat and stealing, with Valecce restrained for about 42 hours in a basement torture chamber where Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, and friend Carl Halin inflicted violence and Campbell tattooed “rip pebbles” along with explicit symbols; Ng received 23 months, Campbell 20 years, Halin 20 years, while a fourth accomplice David Thomas awaits sentencing and Jennifer Pratt awaits trial.

Manchester United have officially approached PSV Eindhoven to sign Memphis Depay, with Louis van Gaal aiming to make him one of his first summer signings; Depay, 21, is starring for PSV, having scored 20 league goals this season and helped PSV clinch the Dutch championship, while PSV’s Marcel Brands notes increased transfer value and confirms contact with United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another major European club. Depay has been praised by former scouts and coaches for his pace, dribbling, and goal threat, and he has prior experience with Van Gaal in Holland’s 2014 World Cup campaign.

Chelsea built a commanding lead in Manchester with Tammy Abraham scoring twice to give them a first-half edge, followed by Dominic Solanke adding a late third as they beat City’s young side 3-1 to return to West London. The match saw strong Chelsea pressure, with Abraham’s goals and Solanke’s finishing sealing the win, while City’s youth stars—including Kean Bryan, Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, and Brandon Barker—fought hard, had moments of threat, and temporarily levelled through Buckley-Ricketts before Solanke and Chelsea ultimately sealed the result.

Marco Rubio says people are born with a sexual preference but argues that the definition of marriage should be decided by state legislatures rather than courts, insisting same-sex marriage is not a constitutional right; he would attend a same-sex wedding of someone he cares about even if he disagrees with the decision, emphasizes respect and love for family regardless of choices, and notes he is running for president with political debate and legislative action as the pathway for changing marriage definitions.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish- Latvian couple who quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester, are on an open-ended, budget-friendly cycling odyssey to explore the world “a pedal at a time,” having covered about 7,000 miles across 16 countries in 356 days since leaving London, living on under three euros per person per day by camping, couchsurfing, and light meals, with plans to continue into Asia and then the American continents, and documenting their journey on their blog thecrazytravel.

Mike Brown says he will take a cautious approach to recovering from his concussion, delaying return to action for Harlequins and highlighting that he pulled out of a England- Ireland match after experiencing symptoms; he notes improvements in concussion awareness through World Rugby online modules, which helped him recognize the seriousness of symptoms and decided not to risk playing, even with upcoming fixtures, to avoid longer-term issues like Johnny Sexton or others; George North also faces a cautious, staged recovery after his fourth quick-fire concussion, with plans to assess progress via short rides and neurosurgical evaluation; Brown emphasizes honest reporting of symptoms and would urge teammates not to play if symptoms are present, underscoring the campaign to promote real and responsible handling of concussions.

A leading expert suggests that smartphone and internet use contribute to a decline in UK sexual frequency, with research showing couples now have sex about three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five in 1990; he argues that increased connectivity blurs work and home life, making people busier and eroding boundaries, which reduces private time with partners, and notes that more people living alone and competing time demands further push sex down the list of priorities.

Tibetan mastiffs, once valued at up to £1.2 million and popular as status symbols, have fallen out of favor in China due to anti-corruption crackdowns and new bans on owning very large dogs, leading to a collapse in their market; many are being stolen or sold to slaughterhouses for meat and leather, with animal-welfare groups reporting cruelty and declines in quality due to cross-breeding and urbanization making them less suitable for city life.

Leeds-based Direct Line ran the #everydayfix design-makeathon, inviting groups to create prototypes for common emergencies and letting the public vote to pick three finalists for a Kickstarter-funded product. The shortlisted concepts address top annoyances like not sleeping, losing keys, and being late due to traffic; specifically, Snooze is an alarm clock that silences notifications for better sleep, Forget Me Lock is a key-mounted device showing green (open) or red (locked) to confirm door status, and Nipper is a tiny mobile charger that uses any household battery to boost phone power. A Twitter poll will determine the winning concept by retweets with the #everydayfix hashtag, after which it will enter crowdfunding and development. Other proposed ideas that didn’t make the cut included a bone-conduction helmet for cycling directions, a parking pin to alert when spaces free, and a relay app to nominate others to receive messages when the phone dies.
